QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL SYSTEM: INTEREST RATES
Mr HURFORD-My question is directed -to the Treasurer, and of course it is about the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. I refer the Treasurer to the reference on page 641 of the report to a consultancy study which said that, as a consequence of deregulation, the savings bank mortgage rate might reasonably be estimated to move up by some 3.5 per cent to a level some 2 per cent above the then existing bond rate. Is it a fact that current bond rates stand at between 14.6 per cent and 15 per cent and that, if mortgage rates rise by the amount predicted by that Campbell consultant, home owners could face interest rates of around 17 per cent o~ their mortgages? Would

this mean an extra $99 a month in repayments on a $30,000 loan over 25 years from a savings bank? Finally, does the Treasurer believe that higher interest rates will force prospective home buyers out of the market for loans and thus help to restrict the extent of interest rate rises?
Mr HOWARD~I am grateful that the honourable member for Adelaide, in his courteous fashion, has referred me to the consultancy report. I might refer the honourable member for Adelaide to the conclusions of the Committee on that subject. The Committee's conclusions were that the average cost of funds in that area would not vary appreciably. It concluded that there would be rises in some areas and there could be falls in others. I remind the honourable gentleman that the Committee's recommendations are now before the Government. I have already indicated in the tabling statement a number of principles which will guide the Government's deliberations. So far as the assessing of that report is concerned, those principles include a concern to concentrate on the method of providing assistance to various areas of the community and the economy and not necessarily upon the levels of that assistance. In that I am in fact mirroring the approach of the Committee. I refer the honourable gentleman to page 624 of the report. I think it is very-salient that what was said be borne in mind by people who are objectively assessing the Government's response to this report. In a chapter dealing with sectoral assistance, the Committee stated:
The Committee has not sought to assess the appropriate level of assistance to particular groups . . .
The judgments involved extend well beyond questions of economic efficiency and are outside the Committee's terms of reference. The Committee has instead focused solely on the methods of assistance and their implications for the financial system.
In adopting the approach that I outlined in my statement yesterday, the Government is being entirely consistent with the approach adopted by the Committee and is in no way in conflict with. the basic approach adopted by the Committee. .
VICTORIA: WELFARE HOUSING FINANCIAL ARRANGEMENTS
Mr FALCONER-Is the Minister for Housing and Construction aware of a recent comment by his counterpart in the Victorian Government that this year Victoria will have to pay the Commonwealth $2.6m more in interest and loan repayments than it has received in its welfare housing allocation from the Commonwealth? Can the Minister confirm that repaynients of previous loans now exceed Victoria's allocation from the Commonwealth?

3000 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Questions Without Notice

Mr McVEIGH-I.am aware of the recent article in the Press by the Honourable Jeff Kennett, the Minister for Housing in the Victorian Parliament. I advise the House that there is a basic-I suspect mischievous-inaccuracy in the statement referred to. If the Minister cares to look at Table 101 in Budget Paper No.7-it is to be hoped that he can add and subtract-he will find that the allocation the Victorian Government will receive from the Commonwealth Government is $58.5m and that his Government has to repay $56.5m. That gives the lie to his statement. However, there is a more basic and fundamental fact to which his statement must be related. It is simply that since 1945 a long list of free enterprise governments have contributed a sum of $5,000m to the States for welfare housing on the basis of very low interest loans and straight-out grants. These loans have to be repaid over a period of 53 years. Quite obviously, the greater the number of years over which loans have to be repaid the more closely will the repayments approximate the amount given by the Commonwealth to an individual State in a year. We note that these payments are made not by the Victorian Government, but by the people who have loans and who are in receipt of rental assistance.
To summarise, I repeat for the benefit of my counterpart in Victoria that this year no State in Australia will repay-not from its own money but from the money of renters and home ownersmore than it receives. I conclude by giving a couple of other examples. This year the State of New South Wales will receive $82.6m and will repay $71.4m. Queensland will receive $30.8m and will repay $19.1m. South Australia will receive $34.7m and will repay $31m. Those figures indicate that the Federal Government is quite .charitable in its contributions to the States for welfare housing. Inaccurate and mischievous sta tern en ts do nothing to improve Commonwealth-State relations.
AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL SYSTEM: INTEREST RATES
Dr CASS-I direct my question to the Treasurer. Is it a fact that the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System recommends immediate abolition of the 30-20 rule which requires certain institutions to hold a minimum of 30 per cent of their investment portfolios in government securities? Does the Committee indicate that it would be preferable to make government securities more responsive to market preferences? Would this mean that the Commonwealth, in order to market its debt, would have to raise the interest rates on

its bonds, thus setting off a round of further interest rate rises and competition for funds in all sectors, as well as necessitating increased government taxes and charges to meet higher debt costs? In addition, would State and local authorities, which are also covered by the 30-20 rule, be forced to pay higher interest rates on their borrowings and also be forced either to curtail services or to increase taxes and charges?
Mr HOWARD-The answer to the first part of the honourable gentleman's question is yes. The answer to the second part is that the real determinant of the price that governments have to pay for the amount of paper they shift is the total volume of paper they have to shift. When it comes to total volumes of paper that must be shifted, the Opposition can leave the Government for dead. The real determinant of the level of interest rates is ultimately the competitive demand for funds in the community. The best contribution that any government can make towards reducing the demand for funds in the community, and therefore reducing the price that one has to pay to raise funds in the community, is to reduce its own borrowing demands. Anybody who examines this subject knows that under our side of politics the borrowing demands of government are significantly less.
HIGH COURT DECISION ON SUPPLIERS OF INFORMATION
Mr DONALD CAMERON-I direct my question to the Minister representing the Attorney General. Does the Minister recall that earlier this year I was threatened with legal action by Medibank Private following my drawing public attention to the disastrous financial position of the fund in some States and the financial danger contributors to that fund were in if Medibank collapsed? Though I have since received an apology I am, therefore, law suit conscious. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the recent case in the High Court of Australia known as Shaddock v. City of Parramatta in which the Court has ruled that many individuals and companies providing information to others as part of a service will be liable for any negligence in providing the information if another has suffered loss by relying on it? Has the Minister considered the application of this decision to members of parliament and their staffs who are continually called upon by constituents for advice of a sometimes delicate nature which, if relied upon and incorrect, could cause a loss?
Mr VINER-I am well aware of the involvement of the honourable member with Medibank Private. I am well aware of how law suit conscious

Questions Without Notice

-18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3001

he is. I should be careful about giving a dispatch box opinion for the benefit of the honourable member. The question that he raises is a very important one for honourable members and honourable senators. As we all know, in the course of doing our duty for members of the public we are asked for and we give advice to them on a variety of matters. It is questionable whether this decision in Shaddock v. City of Parramatta would, in fact, apply to advice given by honourable members. Nevertheless, there is a word of caution to be given to honourable members.
For the information of honourable members. I just give a precis of the essence of the decision in Shaddock's case without giving any history of decisions by the Privy Council or Australian courts beforehand. The essence of the decision in Shaddock's case is that the duty of care is not so narrowly confined as was decided in an earlier case of MLC v. Evatt. A duty of care will arise whenever a person gives information or advice to another upon a serious matter in circumstances where the speaker realises or ought to realise that he is being relied upon to give the best of his information or advice as a basis for action on the part of the other party and it is reasonable in the circumstances for the other party to act on that information or advice. As to the applicability of that decision to the situation of honourable members and honourable senators, I will refer the question to the Attorney-General and provide further information to the honourable member.
Mr Armitage-Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I request that, in accordance with Standing Order 321, you require the Minister to table the document from which he has been reading. I know that he got into trouble once before.
Mr SPEAKER-The honourable member for Chifley will resume his seat. Was the honourable gentleman quoting from a document?
Mr VINER-I would be glad to incorporate the paper in Hansard because it contains a reference to earlier decisions of the High Court and the Privy Council and may be of benefit to honourable members.
Mr SPEAKER-The Minister has asked for leave to incorporate the document in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
SHADDOCK v CITY OF PARRAMATTA
(A decision of the Full Court of the High Court on 28 October 1981)
Prior to the decision in this case it was settled that when a duty of care exists a person can be liable for financial loss resulting from a negligent mis-statement of fact or opinion,

although the mis-statement was honestly made and there was no fiduciary or contractural relationship between the parties.
The Privy Council had held in MLC v EVATT (1970) 122 CLR 628 that the duty of care is casf only on a person who carries on a business or proFession which involves the giving of advice of a kind which calls For special skill and competence or on persons who, while not carrying on such a business or profession, nevertheless profess to have a comparable competence.
The essence of the decision in Shaddock's case is that the duty of care is not no narrowly confined and will arise whenever a person gives inFormation or advice to another upon a serious matter in circumstances where the speaker realises or ought to realise that he is being relied on to give the best of his information or advice as a basis for action on the part of the other party and it is reasonable in the circumstances For the other party to act on that information or advice.
AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL SYSTEM: PROPOSED DEREGULATION
Mr WILLIS-My question, which is addressed to the Treasurer, concerns the suggestion in the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System that the cost of the considerable increase in interest rates for home buyers, farmers and small businessmen that would flow from deregulation could be offset by budgetary measures such as subsidies or tax concessions. Does the Treasurer acknowledge that the cost of any such measure would have to be considerable if these groups were to be fully protected from the consequences of deregulation? Does the Treasurer also acknowledge that implementation of the taxation recommendations of the Campbell Committee would result in further considerable reductions in tax revenue? If so, does the Treasurer agree that the consequence of implementation of the Campbell Committee report and ensuring that protected groups remain protected by budgetary measures would be to greatly reduce the prospect or extent of a general tax cut which the Treasurer and the Prime Minister have previously indicated was likely to be forthcoming?
Mr HOWARD-I am not in a position to give any quantification of particular measures that a government might decide to introduce in the future, given a certain set of assumptions in a certain set of decisions in this or, indeed, any other area. I remind the honourable gentleman that this report is of very great complexity. It has only just been received by the Parliament and I hope it receives a more detailed study from the Opposition than his remarks yesterday would indicate that it has been receiving. I do not know how any party in this Parliament could have seriously studied the report in the less than 36 hours that it was available to the Opposition to enable it to responsibly reach the conclusion that it reached yesterday.

3002 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Questions Without Notice

Yet, apparently, it is within the capacity of the Opposition to reach that conclusion.
I merely repeat what I said to the honourable gentleman and the House yesterday in tabling the report-that there are certain areas where this Government has, and indeed, other governments have, over the years maintained priorities. The Committee essentially dealt with methods of assistance. It indicated in certain areas that in its view, on efficiency grounds, if governments wish to help a sector the best method of helping that sector is through direct budgetary assistance. Questions as to what volume of assistance, what direction that assistance might take and whether that method of assistance might be adopted are naturally questions for the future. I am certainly not, therefore, going to get into the business of giving hypothetical responses as to quantum and cost.
TAP BONDS
Mr BRADFIELD-I ask the Treasurer a question which does not concern the Campbell report. It concerns something more relevant. Has the recent sale of tap bonds been successful? Is the successful sale of tap bonds a necessary ing~edient for the future reduction of interest rates?
Mr HOWARD--.:It is true to say that recent sales of government paper have been more succ~ssful. In fact, it would appear that, as a combmed result of the decisions taken at the Loan Council meeting just before the Budget and also the near balance achieved in the Budget, the tone of the bond market has changed appreciably. Although I am traditionally very cautious about responding to questions in this area, I believe the outlo~k in the interest rate area is more promising than It has been for some time. It is certainly a prerequisite to any downward movement that we commence selling government paper in a very significant volume. That certainly has occurred. I naturally enter a number of cautions, including the fact that to counterbalance the sale from the tap there have been significant net redemptions of Australian savings bonds which have offset the ?on~bank take-up effect of sales out of the tap. It IS still early days but the outlook is certainly better than it has been for some months. It would appear that the market sees the rates as being totally realistic. Of course, ultimately that is what influences whether we sell paper, be it public or private.
AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL SYSTEM: PROPOSED DEREGULATION
Mr ROBERT BROWN-I ask the Treasurer: Is it a fact that the terms of reference given to the

Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System in January 1979 and the Treasurer's accompanying statement made it clear to the Committee that the Government's aim was to deregulate the financial system? Is it also a fact that in April the Treasurer described the Committee's work as a landmark in the development of the Australian financial system, that in June he said that his personal bias was towards deregulation and that as recently as four weeks ago he stated that the Government would not have established the Campbell inquiry if it did not intend to deregulate the financial system? Why, then, has the Treasurer, since tabling the Committee's final report, sought firmly to distance himself and the Government from the Committee's specific deregulation recommendations, such as the abolition of lending and interest rate controls?

Mr HOWARD-I made all the statements to

which the honourable gentleman referred. I do

not resile from any of those statements in any

way. I believe that the Committee was established

against the background of this Government's

commitment to a freer, less regulated and more

competitive financial system. We would not have

established the inquiry in the first place if we had

not believed in those objectives. I remind the

honourable gentleman that I repeated those

objectives in my tabling statement yesterday. I

said that many of the recommendations of the

Committee were fully consistent with those objec-

tives. I do not retreat one inch from what I have

said about the objectives of the Government in

this area, but that Committee itself

in no way alters the acknowledges, that

ifnacrt~aacshithneg

decisions on reports of this kind the Government

has to achieve an appropriate balance between

considerations of economic efficiency and social

-and political realities.

BEEF INDUSTRY
Mr COWAN-I address a question to the Minister for Primary Industry. In view of the problems being experienced by beef producers within Australia, is the Minister in a situation to say what consideration the Government has given to relieving producers of the export tax and the meat inspection charges?
Mr NIXON-The proposal suggested by the honourable member was brought to the Government's attention by the Meat Council of Australia, which sought relief from the necessity of raising these levies during the current beef price problem situation to ease the financial strains on the meat processing works. The Government looked at this proposition, along with a number of

Questions Without Notice

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3003

other propositions that were put at the same time, and came to the conclusion that none of the propositions would resolve the difficulties faced by the meat processing works. It would be a temporary expedient. It would not help with the rationalisation of the works-a rationalisation which, whilst unfortunate, is nevertheless very necessary for the industry right across Australia. Therefore, I have to say that the Government rejected the proposal.

Minister advise the House of the intended composition of the suggested inquiry being initiated into the marketing of petrol in Australia? Will the Minister ensure that the inquiry pays special attention to the practices of oil companies in relation to the marketing of petrol? Will the Minister ensure that the inquiry or working party, as it has been described, be composed of, as well as academics, persons who have been actively involved in the industry?

COMMITTEE OF INQUIRY INTO THE AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL SYSTEM
Mr LEO McLEAY-Has the Treasurer given the special task force examining the final report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System any deadline for its report? Will the task force's deliberations cover the same source documents, such as submissions, technical papers and transcripts of public hearings, as the Campbell inquiry used to arrive at its recommendations? Will the task force's recommendations' and comments on the Campbell report be made public? Will the Treasurer assure the House that the task force will not be preserved as a convenient means of postponing announcements of the Government's attitude to the key recommendations concerning interest rates and lending controls until after the next election?
Mr HOWARD-I hope to meet the chairman of the task force, who is the deputy secretary of my Department, and perhaps other members of that task force-one of them is a member of my own personal staff-over the next few days to discuss the methodology of the operation of the task force and to provide some guidance as to how it might operate. At this stage I do not want to respond about the scope of the documents that might be available. I do not want to be unduly restrictive but equally, having allowed a period of three years for this report to be put together, we hardly want a report upon a report to take an equally lengthy period. Without wanting or frankly being able to commit myself to a specific time, I obviously do not want to see the work of the task force wither away. I want to see it respond to the Government's request promptly. On the question of whether the task force report will be tabled, I think it is too early for f!1e to try to answer that.
PETROL PRICING
Mr GOODLUCK-Is the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs aware that there is a continued disparity in the price of petrol, firstly between the capital cities of Australia and, secondly, the country areas of Australia? Will the

Mr MOORE-At the Standing Committee of Consumer Affairs Ministers conference in Adelaide just on a fortnight ago the questions of pricing, marketing and divorcement within the petroleum industry were discussed by all the State Ministers and the Commonwealth Minister. The honourable member will be aware that there is a divergence between the States in terms of thei,r pricing policies. New South Wales and South Australia have fixed prices. Yictoria is looking at this possibility. Needless to say, Queensland has no desire to move in that area. On top of that is the question of divorcement proceedings. In that area the Commonwealth has a particular law. The Victorian Government is looking at the same question. Because of this wide range of approaches the meeting decided to establish a working party consisting of officers of the various departments involved in that meeting. They have been asked to look at the consequences of the various regulations with the hope that we will be able to develop a common approach. That will take some time.
It is probably worth pointing out that at present the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority justifies petroleum product prices in Australia, that this particular form of pricing is not accepted by New South Wales and is added to by other States by various State taxes. The price levels between the States thus vary enormously. It is also fair to say that it is a tribute to the forces of supply and demand that the prices vary enormously throughout Australia. In very few States at present are retailers getting the price for petrol justified by the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority.
FORK LIFT TRUCKS
Mr MOUNTFORD-Does the Minister for Industry and Commerce recall the recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission for the fork lift truck and associated industries, which, if implemented, would cause large scale displacement of workers in those industries? Will the Minister assure the House that the Government has no intention of implementing the recommendations of the Industries Assistance

3004 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Questions Without Notice

Commission and thus save this worthwhile local industry from closure?
Sir PHILLIP LYNCH-I am aware of the concerns which have been expressed by the honourable gentleman. I assure him that those concerns will be very much in the mind of the Government when it approaches a policy position.
AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL SYSTEM: HOUSING INTEREST RATES
Mr HYDE-My question is to the Treasurer. It follows several that have been asked already. Does the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System indicate that interest rate controls are regressive, failing to assist those for whom the controls were intended? Will the Government take into account the need to adopt policies which favour poorer rather than more well to do people in determining policy for the housing capital market?
Mr HOWARD-As the honourable member for Moore pointed out in his question, it is a fact that, according to the view of the Committee, interest rate controls have a regressive effect.
Mr Hurford-But not the view of the consultants.
Mr HOWARD-Perhaps the honourable gentleman will contain himself. That is the conclusion that is reached in the Committee's report. One of the obligations of the Government. is to assess that conclusion and to form a view as to whether it agrees with it. I find it absolutely amazing that a party that professes to be interested in the interests of low income earners in this country can, in 36 hours, dismiss a conclusion that argues against a regressive system in a report that has taken three years to compile. I think it is a very remarkable exercise in indifference towards an objective examination of whether the conclusions of the report are correct. Without seeking to pass a view as to whether the Government agrees with the conclusions of the Committee on this particular subject, I can say to the honourable member for Moore that in assessing the Committee's recommendations the Government, unlike the Australian Labor Party, will be concerned to ensure that the existing financial system does not have regressive effects on low income earners.
HOME LOAN INTEREST RATES
Mr FRY-Is the Prime Minister aware that two of his Ministers, the Minister for Trade and Resources and the Minister for Primary Industry, have long-standing government housing loans on which they are paying interest rates of 4.75 per cent and 6.25 per cent respectively? Does the

Prime Minister think it appropriate that these loans should continue at such low interest rates when the working people of Australia are being burdened with ever increasing high interest rates on housing loans, which will be still higher if the Campbell report is adopted? Will the Prime Minister request the Ministers concerned either to pay back the loans or to volunteer to pay the going interest rate which ordinary citizens of this country have to pay?
Mr MALCOLM FRASER-In the Australian Capital Territory there was a policy of making loans available to Ministers .and sometimes members of Parliament at various times. A number of members of this Parliament, I think from all parties, have probably taken advantage of that opportunity over the years. My advice is that the honourable member fot Fraser himself in fact took advantage of such a loan, and that the honourable member for St George took advantage of such a loan.
Mr Fry-Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. I am concerned that the remarks of the Prime Minister could be interpreted to mean that I received a loan as a member of Parliament. That is not correct. I received a loan as a public servant. I repaid that loan soon after I came into the Parliament.
Mr SPEAKER-I call the Prime Minister.
Mr MALCOLM FRASER-The honourable gentleman is making the point that he received a concessional loan. I am advised also that the honourable member for St George and an earlier member for Wills had the advantage--
Mr Morrison-Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. I received a loan as a member of the Departmentof Foreign Affairs. The loan was undertaken in 1963, well before I became a member of Parliament, and it was not a government house that I got the loan for.
Mr MALCOLM FRASER-The honourable member could have continued by advising us whether he still lives in the house that he bought on that subsidised loan.
Mr Morrison-Mr Speaker, I take a poiJ?t of order. I will be very happy to answer the Prime Minister's question. I do not and I have not since 1969.
Mr MALCOLM FRASER-I am also advised that a former member for Riverina, Mr Grassby, had the advantage of such a loan. I do not know whether we should give permission to the former member for Wills and to a former member for Riverina to come into this Parliament and give personal explanations in relation to this matter.
Honourable members interjecling'----

Questions Without Notice

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3005

Mr SPEAKER-Order! The House will come to order. I ask all honourable gentlemen to remain silent. The honourable ladies have not interjected. The House will come to order. I ask every member to remain silent. I ask the Prime Minister to draw his answer to a conclusion.
Mr MALCOLM FRASER-There are one or two points that need to be made seriously. Quite obviously, members from both sides of this Parliament have taken advimtage of loans that were available in the Australian Capital Territory at varying times. I want to make a point about the conduct of the Parliament and the way in which we do our business. Many former and present members of this Parliament have young families. Very few members of this Parliament can afford to have a home in the Australian Capital Territory and a real home in their own electorates or wherever they come from. For a long time. I have doubted the wisdom of moving members to Canberra on Monday or Tuesday mornings and moving them out on Thursday nights or Friday mornings. I believe that over time. I think it will take time because it is a habit that will die hard-we would probably do much better if we ultimately established the circumstances whereby members of parliament could come to this place for the session and then leave and have the electorates educated to understand that this is the way that they are going to get better service from members, electorally and through this Parliament.
The amount of time that we all collectively spend travelling every week is enormous. It is all very well for me because I use a government aircraft which is a travelling office, but it is obviously very hard to work in a commercial aircraft. So there is an enormous waste of time for all members of parliament, which is dead time to them, while they are travelling. I believe that over time it would make more sense if there were arrangements that made it possible for members to establish a home in the capital as well as in their electorates. I am not suggesting that there can or should be any early change of policy in relation to these matters, but there is no doubt that the loans that were available to enable members of parliament to purchase homes in Canberra were in part a recognition of the very plain fact that I think most honourable gentlemen recognise. We do not conduct our business in the best way, with the best use of our time and to the best advantage of our eleCtors and of the constituency at large. I think that it is petty in the extreme for members of the Opposition to raise these points when they know that these loans are matters of long standing and were available to members of all parties.

NEW ZEALAND SUPPLEMENTARY MINIMUM PRICE SCHEME
Mr LLOYD-Is the Minister for Primary Industry aware that the New Zealand Government's supplementary minimum price scheme is now estimated to cost $200m this year to support, at this stage at least, wool, beef and skim milk powder export prices? What effect could this open-ended and massively expensive subsidy scheme have on international prices for these commodities, on closer economic relations between our two countries and on the level of the New Zealand dollar?
Mr NIXON-The supplementary minimum price scheme was introduced by the New Zealand Government in 1978. It was said to be a temporary measure to assist farmers in achieving incomes which might more adequately provide for meeting farm costs than the stabilisation schemes which presently exist in New Zealand. I do not know how temporary the scheme is, but certainly this year it is estimated to cost an extra $200m. However, I note that most of that cost will not be on this year's Budget. I understand that most of that cost will be on the ensuing year's Budget. The scheme applies to lamb, mutton, cow beef, bull beef, prime beef, milk fat and wool.
The honourable member asked about the impact on the international prices of commodities. I think that is difficult to assess. It is also difficult to assess the real cost of the scheme on the value of the New Zealand dollar. I quote what the Leader of the Opposition in New Zealand, Mr Rowling, had to say about the matter. It seems to be a complete quote from a newspaper article. It states:
What we have got with the supplementary minimum price proposals is a government trying to head off the anger of the farmers by pitching SMP levels not at the market realisations or any relationship to the market realisations but at the escalating costs that are actually occurring on the farm.
I draw attention to the point he made about market realisations because I think that is the aspect of it that in terms of closer economic relations with New Zealand we, as a Government, will have to study, along with other important factors such as the difference in the value of the New Zealand dollar and the Australian dollar. The value of the New Zealand dollar is running at about 140c to the Australian dollar. I think that the impact on CER is an important impact and is something that will have to be studied more closely. One cannot assume that there will be any quick conclusion to the CER study because of all the factors that are involved. Indeed, I think one can assume that it will be a very difficult process to get agreement between the industries on a

3006 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Questions Without Notice

number of the factors that are outstanding at the moment.
AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL SYSTEM: HOUSING FINANCE
Mr HAYDENMy question, which is directed to the Treasurer, follows the answer he gave a few minutes ago in which he declared that the Opposition had arrived at conclusions repudiating recommendations of the Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System in relation to housing finance after only 36 hours of consideration of that report. Is the Treasurer aware of a consultant's report to that inquiry by a Miss Judy Yates entitled 'The Distributional Impact of Interest Rate Regulation on the Household Sector'? I ask him whether he has had the opportunity of noting part 3, 'Conclusions', which declared, inter alia:
The first is that the argument that regulation has regressive effects is not supported conclusively because of the contradictory evidence from the various surveys.
Has he also had the opportunity to consider in detail this report and, more specifically, the recommendations for overcoming the nature of regressiveness to the extent that it may occur in the provision of housing finance within the regulated system of financial availability? Is he aware that this report has been available to the Opposition and, indeed, to the public since March 1981? Is he aware that the report is very much the basis for the conclusions which have been reached by the Opposition in response to the Australian financial system inquiry report and therefore vindicates the declaration of the Opposition that it has been a very careful consideration that has led, very properly, t<;> its repudiation of the recommendations of the Campbell inquiry which can only serve to pander to the interests of powerful sections of the corporate part of the economy at the expense of the great mass of people, especially home buyers, farmers and small business people in the community?
Mr HOWARD-The answer to the first part of the honourable gentleman's question is yes. I am fully aware of that consultancy report and I am fully aware that that consultancy report would have been available to the Opposition for many months. I merely remind the honourable gentleman that on page 647 of the report the Committee came to the following conclusion:
. . . interest rate controls are an inefficient and ineffective means of assisting low income potential home buyers. They have regressive distributional consequences, harming many of those they are intended to benefit, and benefiting--
Mr Hayden-They have drawn their conclusion out of self-interest. You have all the representatives of big business interests. You have no

one representing the average community. They jumped to a conclusion which is quite contrary to the consultancy submission.
Mr SPEAKER-Order! The Leader of the Opposition will remain silent. He asked his question , in silence. I ask him to listen to the answer in silence.
Mr HOWARD-For the benefit of the Leader of the Opposition, I will start that again. The report states:
In summary, interest rate controls are an inefficient and ineffective means of assisting low incomepotential home buyers. They have regressive distributional consequences, harming many of those they are intended to benefit, and benefiting many who do not require assistance. In short, they can be said to have been counter-productive in achieving their welfare objectives, while hurting the community at large by impairing the efficiency of the financial system.
That is the Committee's conclusion. I am not standing here and saying that that is right or wrong. We have to assess that. I am saying, and I repeat, that the Opposition was irresponsible to reject that conclusion in a mere 36 hours.
