Question so resolved in the affirmative. Original question resolved in the affirmative.

CONSTRUCTION OF ADDITIONAL TRAINING AND SLEEPING
ACCOMMODATION AT RAAF BASE, LAVERTON, VICTORIA
Reference of Work: Public Works Committee Act
Mr McVEIGH (Darling Downs-Minister for Housing and Construction) (5.34).-1 move:
That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Commillee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the parliamentary standing committee on public works for consideration and report, namely: COl)struction of additional training and sleeping accommodation at RAAF Base, Laverton, Victoria.
The proposal is for new facilities to support an increase of about 17 per cent in the number of staff and students at the Royal Australian Air Force school of radio. The RAAF needs more people skilled in electronics and radio for new equipments being introduced into the service such as the new tactical fighter, The work will consist of the following elements: Two-storey cluster groups of accommodation units for 208 airmen, a threestorey training building and associated external

RAAF Base, Laverton, Victoria

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3039

works, services and landscaping. The estimated cost of the proposed work is $5.6m at August 1981 prices. I table plans of the proposed work.
Mr SCHOLES (Corio) (5.35)-1 want to make only a few remarks about the matter under consideration by the House. The situation relating to general living standards and the maintenance of accommodation at Defence Force bases throughout Australia is of growing concern to a large number of Service personnel. It is one of the areas about which the greatest number of complaints come from Service personnel, especially
the families of Service personnel. For several years now the maintenance and the provision of what are basically decent standards of living for persons who are required to move regularly because of their defence commitments and to live in government provided accommodation have
caused concern. This motion is welcome in that it seeks to improve one of those areas.
I draw the attention of the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh) and the House to the fact that an enormous backlog of unmet and substandard accommodation is being utilised on a regular basis by members of the defence forces and their families. Much of this accommodation is obsolete in modern accommodation terms. A good deal of it would be deemed to be below standard by State housing authorities if, in fact, they had the option of condemning government dwellings. I point out also that there are serious problems in a number of areas with the
locations of Defence Force housing accommodation which is quite unsuitable and unrelated to the persons who are expeCted to live in it. There is, as I mentioned before, a serious tardiness in this area. In Darwin, for instance, which is not directly related to this motion, there are still houses which have not been adequately repaired as a result of the damage which was caused during Cyclone Tracy. I think it is unfortunate that this sort of
situation continues. It is causing problems with maintaining the skills and the levels of trained manpower that are necessary in the defence forces. Once a family becomes dissatisfied and if the accommodation that is provided is below the standard which that family is entitled to expect, problems will occur. I raise this matter briefly today because there are very few opportunities to debate this type of matter in the House. I draw to the Minister's attention the very bad state of a great deal of government accommodation in the defence area.
Mr McVEIGH (Darling Downs-Minister for Housing and Construction) (5.37)-in reply-I am grateful to the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) for drawing those matters to my

attention. I just formally advise him that I will bring his comments to the notice of the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) whose responsibility this matter is.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL (No.2) 1981
Second Reading
Debale resumed from 28 October, on motion by Mr Howard:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Mr WILLIS (Gellibrand) (5.38)-The Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No.2) deals with two sets of amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act. These involve, firstly, the taxation of payments made to workers who have been on strike or stood down during a dispute and, secondly, the tax treatment of housing provided at a subsidised rate to workers by their employers. Both matters obviously have important industrial relations connotations as well as tax connotations.
I propose to deal firstly with the set of amendments which seek to provide a more concessional basis for determining the value of employer subsidised housing for income tax purposes. These amendments do so by providing that where certain sets of eligibility criteria are met the value of such housing for tax purposes will be 10 per cent of the market rental value of that housing, less any rent paidby the employee. Taxpayers can be eligible for this concession under one of two sets of conditions. First, taxpayers living and working in remote areas qualify if it is customary in the particular industry for employers to provide free or subsidised housing for their employees and if it is necessary in each case for the employer to provide such accommodation due to lack of suitable alternative accommodation or the need for employees to move frequently from one location to another. Under this legislation a taxpayer will be deemed to be located in a remote area if he or she does not reside or work in, or adjacent to, an urban centre. Under the terms of the Bill this means within 100 kilometres of a town or a city with the popUlation over 130,000 or within 40 kilometres of a town of over 12,000 people-both cases are based on population figures from the 1976 census.
The second set of eligibility criteria was clearly formulated to cover workers in the sugar industry along the north coast of Queensland who also benefit from employer-subsidised housing. These criteria state that where a taxpayer does not meet the remoteness tests I have just mentioned and

3040 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Income Tax Assessment Bill (No.2)

lives in, or adjacent to, an urban centre that taxpayer may also be entitled to the 90 per cent concession if all of a number of conditions are met. Those conditions are: It must be customary in the industry for employers to provide such housing, there must be no suitable alternative accommodation available, the conditions of occupation of the accommodation must be onerous because of proximity to the work place and, finally, at least
six other employees must receive such housing. Finally, just in case there is a chance that any other taxpayer will become liable to pay tax on subsidised housing, the Commissioner of Taxation will have discretion to treat a person who resides or works in, or adjacent to, an urban centre as residing or working outside that area if persons residing or working near to that person are regarded as being in a remote area. These amendments are proposed to have effect in respect of assessments for 1977-78 and subsequent income years and the Commissioner will be empowered to amend any assessments made before these provisions come into operation in order to reduce the value of assessable housing benefits included in assessable income.
My explanation of the terms of this amendment has necessarily been lengthy because this is a lengthy and extremely complex proposal. It is a proposal which, I am sure, officers of the Australian Taxation Office would not have relished having to prepare and it is a proposal which, yet again, will add to the complexity of an alreadyextremely complex and difficult to comprehend Income Assessment Tax Act. Whilst we in the Opposition support the legislation it is legislation which we feel has been necessitated only by the incompetent administration of the tax Act by this Government. Had the Government accepted the attitudes of previous Administrations which, since the mid 1960s, have not taxed such housing benefits, the lengthy and costly disputes in regard to this matter would not have arisen.
In order to illustrate the Government's ineptitude on the issue it is necessary to briefly sketch the events leading up to the amendments contained in this Bill. Since 1967, miners on the central Queensland coal fields, where this dispute was centred, have been supplied with company houses at relatively low rents of around $5 to $16 a week-well below market values. To the miners cheap housing is seen as some compensation for working in remote areas away from established townships with minimal social amenities, harsh climate and much more expensive living costs. Once the mineral deposits are exhausted the mining townships have little future and in such circumstances the miners are precluded from

investing in their own homes which, presumably, most would do in more established townships. In these conditions cheap housing is seen as essential to attracting workers to these areas.
This Government, however, has taken a different view from that taken by previous administrations. In 1978, it was decided to apply the provisions of section 26 (e) of the tax Act to miner's housing. This section is designed to include in a taxpayer's assessable income all compensation given in money or kind as a direct or indirect benefit of employment. Section 26 (e) has to date been enforced in a very inconsistent way by this Government. While attempting to crack down on the miners the Government has ignored various tax free perks and fringe benefits which have been widely employed for many years by high income earners to reduce their tax. Top executives and other high salary earners, unable
to enjoy the delights of the more blatant tax avoidance schemes, now insist that their incomes be based on so-called remuneration packages or some other euphemisticly titled arrangement. Such packages often contain up to one-third of salary in fringe benefits such as company credit cards, entertainment allowances, use of company facilities and other non-taxed perks. An executive who would otherwise earn, say, $40,000 in taxable
income, can reduce his tax by over $5,000 simply by taking $30,000 as taxable income and $10,000 worth of fringe benefits which are not taxed. Although the Commissioner of Taxation has recently implemented a selective crackdown in areas such as expense accounts and the use of cars, it still seems that many benefits remain untouched. The large amounts of tax revenue lost through these perks warrant tough action by the Commissioner to stamp out such abuses. In our view, such a crackdown would be far more justified than attempting to tax the miners on a thoroughly deserved concession which would have yielded little revenue to the Government by comparison.
It is worth pondering why the Government chose to apply these provisions to the miners' housing after it had gone untaxed for such a long period. It is not going too far to suggest that the Government took these steps in retaliation for large pay increases awarded to Utah employees in early 1978. These increases of about $95 a week took average wages for Utah employees from about $19,000 to $23,000 a year and were much criticised by the Government at that time. It seems to be far from coincidental that the crackdown on housing benefits occurred shortly after these wage increases were granted. The Opposition believes that the tax system certainly should

Income Tax Assessment Bill (No.2)

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3041

not be used in such a discriminatory way to cover up for the Government's complete lack of a comprehensive wages policy.
The Australian Taxation Office first attempted to apply this tax in 1978 when a circular was sent to employers in the Queensland coalfields stating that workers should pay the equivalent tax on an extra $1,000 income if they received fully subsidised company housing. This, translated, meant an extra weekly tax bill of about $7. The miners not surprisingly, refused to pay the extra tax and 2,000 workers stopped work for two weeks in an ende.avour to have the operation of section 26 (e) modIfied to take account of the special circumstances of thei~ employment. The miners were joined in their protest by teacJ'iers, rural and constr~ction workers and even, remarkably, by local polIcemen, all of whom received subsidised housing. The Government backed down on the issue and on 12 July 1978 the Treasurer (Mr Howard) announced that the Government had commenced a review of the application of section 26 (e) to these circumstances. He said that the review would be completed as soon as possible and that the Commissioner would not pursue current initiatives in the matter pending the outcome of the review. In addition, according to officials of the combined mining unions, a deputation of union officials met the Treasurer in Canberra and received an assurance that they would not be taxed on housing benefits.
Nothing more was heard from the Government until June I979-virtually a year later-when the Treasurer announced that the Income Tax Assessment Act would be amended by the insertion of section 26AAAA to limit the operation of section 26(e). Under the amendment the Commissioner, when considering the value of housing benefits, would be required to take into account all relevant factors, such as isolation, custom in the industry, the standard of accommodation' the lack of alternatives and the onerous conditions under which the employees were working. Where such considerations applied, the value of the housing was to be reduced as appropriate to the circumstances. These amendments were not debated in this House for a further nine months-not until March 1980. They in no way removed the liability of the workers to pay the tax; they only formally incorporated in the Act matters to which the Commissioner was already giving consideration. However, the miners had clearly been led to believe that this would be the end of the matter and that no further tax would be levied.
In June 1979 the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) visited Blackwater in Queensland and told a deputation of miners that in respect of this

matter they could 'sleep tight at night', to use his exact words. This assurance was given in the presence of various Queensland Federal and State politicians. They were allIed to believe that there would be no tax. In addition, Canberra journalists heard the Prime Minister say that the men would not have to pay tax on their housing. The journalists reported his statements in the Age and the Australian Financial Review on the following day, 15 June 1979. However, when this issue blew up again last year the Prime Minister's Press office, which, I understand, devotedly transcribes every word the Prime Minister utters, could not find the transcript of the Prime Minister's remarks, attributing the loss to a 'failure in the system'. It is more likely, I imagine, that the records were deliberately lost once the Prime Minister realis~d that his assurances were, once again, not being translated into practice. Whatever happened, the miners firmly believed that the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, had promised that they would not be taxed on their housing. This view was reinforced by a letter dated 26 July 1979 from the Prime Minister to Mr Andrew Vickers, President of the Central Queensland Combined Mining Unions, which letter was reported in the Australian" Financial Review of 8 August last year. The key paragraph of that letter states:

The Government has carefully considered the implications of these long-standing arrangements for taxpayers in relatively remote or isolated areas and is reluctant to see them substantially disturbed.

Most interpretations of that phrase would indi-

cate that the Government would continue not to

levy the tax. Certainly, that was the impression

that was given to those who read the letter. The

Treasurer used the same phrase in his Press re-

lease of 13 June 1979 announcing the amendment

to the Income Tax Assessment Act. Given these

assurances by the Prime Minister and the

Treasurer, it is little wonder that the miners were

incensed Taxation

in June 1980 when indicated that the

tphre~vCisoimonms iossfiosencetrioonf

26 (e) would continue to be enforced and, despite

the earlier amendments, miners would still be

assessed on the value of their housing. This incom-

prehensible decision, given earlier assurances, led

to a prolonged, bitter and costly dispute on the

Queensland coalfields. Almost 4,000 employees

engaged in the mines in the Queensland towns of

Blackwater, Emerald, Dysart, Moura and Moran-

bah were involved in a lO-week stoppage. This

needless stoppage involved massive costs for all-

costs which could have been forgone had the

Government stuck to its earlier assurances. The

Queensland Government lost $3m a week in rev-

enue; the miners lost $2m a week in wages for-

gone; the Commonwealth Government lost $8.6m

3042 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Income Tax Assessment Bill (No.2)

a week in income tax, coal export duty and excise; and the Utah Development Company-the major employer involved-estimated its production losses to be $19m a week. Of great significance also would have been the' damage done to our reputation overseas as a reliable coal supplier. These massive costs were incurred for what was an almost insignificant tax take for the Government. According to one commentator, some $21,000 a week would have been raised in taxes on subsidised housing from the central Queensland coalfields. That is a quite miniscule amount for all the disruption, bitterness and losses involved.
The tax revolt by the miners on this issue fired public imagination. Understandably, the public at large was fed up after five years of increased taxes and broken promises from the Fraser Government and the miners received strong support. In the face of this strong backing for the miners, and only a few months before an election, the Government was forced to give ground. Initially the assessed rental value of miners' housing was put at $45 a week. Before the dispute commenced, this was reduced to $20 a week under the operation of section 26AAAA, to which I previously referred. The miners, .however, would not accept the extra tax of between $6.50 and $9 which would have resulted from the decision. The Government's first backdown-the first of three backdownscame on 11 July 1980 when the Treasurer offered to phase in over three years the tax on the difference between $20 and the rent actually paid, if any. This proposal was rejected and on 6 August 1980 the Treasurer offered to reduce the assessed rental valu!:; to $16 in greater recognition of the remoteness and common practice in the industry. Again, this proposal was rejected. Finally, the Government capitulated on 2 September 1980closer to the election-when it announced that the assessed rental value would be discounted by 90 per cent to $4.50 a week. Because rents actually paid-typically $5 a week-usually exceeded this figure, no tax would be paid on such subsidised housing.
On any view the miners had achieved a resounding victory over the Government. But this victory had been achieved at great cost in lost wages, lost production, lost revenue and deep seated bitterness and division. The Government must bear the blame for the effects of this dispute, which spread over three years and resulted entirely from the Government's intransigence. This disruption need not have occurred had the Government not attempted to overturn long standing arrangements which had been accepted

by successive governments for many yearsmerely, it seems, from a motive of retribution and possibly also from a thirst for extra tax revenue. Had the Government dropped the proposals in 1978 when the miners first expressed their total opposition and had it decided to honour undertakings given at later dates, this entire mess could have been avoided. The Government's use of the tax system in this case deserves to be condemned outright and, while we on this side of the House support the amendments now before the House, we reiterate that in our view they should not have been necessary in the first place.
At this stage, I turn to deal briefly with the second set of amendments contained in this BiIlthose dealing with the taxation of so-called dispute settlement payments. This set of amendments seeks to rectify the current situation in which lump sum payments paid at the end of an industrial dispute to compensate workers for the hardship of being on strike or stood down during a dispute, or simply to induce them to return to work, are tax free as the law now stands. This Bill ensures that any such payment made after 11 August 1981 will be taxable and that pay-as-youearn tax deductions at the rate of 32 cents in the dollar will be deducted from them.
These measures arose out of a settlement agreement negotiated to end a lengthy dispute at the Loy Yang power station construction site in the Latrobe Valley in Victoria last year. The dispute arose when members of the Builders Labourers Federation were dismissed for refusing to lift an overtime ban on concrete batching imposed because of wage demands and a demarcation dispute with members of the Australian Workers Union and the Federated Iron workers Association of Australia. Following the dismissal of the Builders Labourers Federation members, 600 other workers were dismissed by site contractors unable to continue working without reliable concrete supplies.
One of the key points of the agreement reached to settle the dispute was the payment of back pay to these 600 workers and the members who originally created the dispute for the 33 weeks that they were off work. These hardship payments, as they were termed, were calculated on an average of the employees' after tax earnings over the four weeks leading up to the dismissal, less any earnings from social security or other employment during the strike. It was estimated that the payments to employees varied between $10,000 and $12,000 because of the agreement. These payments were exempt from tax because any sums received by way of compensation for loss of the

Income Tax Assessment Bill (No.2)

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3043

opportunity to earn income, or for the abandonment of rights to income under a contract of service, are regarded as being capital payments which are non-taxable, rather than income payments which are taxable. The Treasurer announced on 18 December last year that the Government was concerned at this aspect of the agreement and would examine the use of such lump sum payments. Finally, on 11 August this year he announced that any future lump sum payments made as part of a return to work agreement would be fully taxable.
While the position of the majority of the workers in the Loy Yang case is understandable in that they were dimissed through no fault of their own but rather as victims of a dispute to which they were not a party and the payments they received were calculated on an after tax basis, we consider that the Government is justified in amending the law to make such payments taxable in future. It will still be open to employers to make such payments, but the clear implication of this measure is that payments will have to be much higher in order to achieve an equivalent after tax payment. The Government should understand that this is likely to be the result of the measure which it is now putting through this House.
It is considerations of equity which motivate the Opposition to support these measures. In brief, as we see it, it would be totally unfair to tax employees who receive an amount while still at work, whilst other employees on strike or being stood down could receive the same amount of money eventually tax free. Let us take the case of the Loy Yang dispute. If employees were to receive $10,000 when they had not been at work and were to pay no tax, it seems inherently unfair that other workers who received the same amount of money for working the same time should have to pay tax on the same amount of income. Because of that clear anomaly which exists in the tax law as it presently stands we believe we have to support the legislation which is now before the House in respect of these dispute settlement payments. For those reasons we support the legislation.
Sitting suspended from 5.59 to 8 p.m.
Mr BRAITHWAITE (Dawson) (8.0)-Few Bills that have been presented to this House, would have had such a long pregnancy and such a difficult birth as the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill. I refer particularly to the part of the Bill dealing with employees' housing. The

pregnancy survived a rather heavy handed approach by the tax officials to the original valuations of sugar mill staff to housing in 1976-77. This was followed by a false alarm that brought out the amendment to section 26AAA on 22 November 1979. There was then a coal miners' strike in July, August and September 1980 and a very concerted case which was put to the Australian Taxation Office by the sugar milling staff. The birth of the Bill occurred in the form of the proposed new section 26AAAB. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the Cabinet are to be congratulated on their preparedness to accommodate the views of many members and senators and to have the benefits from the new provisions more equitably spread, without opening any floodgates to tax avoidance. That is very important. Our appreciation is sincere for the result that has been achieved.
For many decades the assessable income aspect of subsidised housing rentals came under section 26(e) of the Income Tax Assessment Act. There are other aspects of section 26 (e) but I want to concentrate on the housing rentals aspect which is involved in proposed new section 26AAAB. The Taxation Office administered section 26 (e) up to 1976-77 sensibly and fairly. Whilst only some industries came to the notice of the officials, rental values were set taking into account the conditions of employment and the nature of the housing provided. In a review of rentals on 30 June 1968 values for sugar mill housing were agreed to and set at about $5 or $6 per week. Apparently few other industries were caught in the tax web at that time. The mining industry development of the seventies came apparently unnoticed to the Taxation Office. But it became traditional for mining companies to offer accommodation in towns set up specially for employees to mine a finite product. Small rentals in the range of $5 to $10 per week were charged by the companies much in line with the sugar industry values then applied by the Taxation Office. In time, some companies escalated their basic rentals while others did not change.
The Taxation Office in late 1976 went about the reassessment of rental values in a manner which was a substantial departure from the previous policy of recognising the disadvantages of living in rental accommodation in industries that require employees to live in close proximity to their work. Assessments for mill employees in employer accommodation where issued for the year ended 30 June 1978 on values sometimes ten times greater than the 1968 values. There was, of course, an immediate reaction with those affected

3044 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Income Tax Assessment Bill (No.2)

taxpayers lodging objections against the assessments as the increases were far in excess of the simplest of indexes, mainly the consumer price index. I believe this approach was heavy handed, not realistic and did not take into account traditional arrangements. The taxation officials then sought other avenues in which to apply the values and collect additional tax. Values were established on the minefields at roughly equivalent values to those in the sugar industry.
This was not a reaction, as the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) said, to the pay increases on the mine fields themselves. It was a follow-on from the assessment of the increased values within the sugar mills. The coalminers struck in 1979 over this issue although the values had not to then been applied in their industry. I must point out that to this time employees in the sugar industry which had been singled out, were expected to pay the additional tax which other, similarly placed employees in other industries, did not. Sugar industry staff, in spite of their objections, never took strike action but received little recognition for their restraint and certainly no gain. They received little recognition from the Opposition. The honourable member for Gellibrand, who led for the Opposition in this debate, did not mention that at no time was the sugar industry involved in the dispute.
After the first strike by coal miners, section 26AAAA was introduced to provide for a discounting of the market value because of certain remoteness factors. The results desired by the coal miners were not achieved under a strict interpretation of that section although an additional discounting factor was established and available. This was followed by the Central Queensland miners strike of 1980, a strike which some commentators suggest resulted in a loss of $200m. The profit on revenue to the miners, the mine owners and the Governmental authorities was delayed to that extent.
Again I pay a tribute to mill staff and mill employees during this time. They did not resort to strike action but were prepared to maintain their representation through the proper channels. Their reward will be that because of the retrospective provisions of this section to 1 July 1977, refunds of overpayments will be made to them and justice long denied, will now be available.
Another example of the ineptitude of the taxing authorities at this time was the fact that at a time when rentals were being reassessed upwards, at a time when assessments were threatened and when strike action had been taken the Taxation Department had available to it, a previously issued undertaking to representatives of a mining

company that values for taxation purposes of subsidised housing for the following ten years would remain at the same relatively low values of $5 to $10. This undertaking had been given, I understand, in the early part of the 1970's.
The withholding of the information, or the fact that it was overlooked, led to the situation of confrontation that was entirely unnecessary. I also mention the inconsistency of some of our Queensland State Government colleagues, some in ministerial positions, who while arguing the case for miners to pay rents at levels no higher than $5 per week, were actually charging their own State employees, school teachers particularly, amounts of $32 per week for married accommodation often inferior to the miners' accommodation.
Yet these people, for their own particular political advantage, added considerably to the difficulties of settlement of the dispute and helped bring about the confrontation that took place.
For many years, the taxing arrangement was administered under the tax law, with an interpretation of the Act that showed a proper and practical understanding of all the issues involved in employer supplied accommodation in particular industries and in remote areas. Taxpayers now fail to appreciate, and so do I, why there is now a necessity to detail the law and provide for legislation, which was not previously necessary when a practical and common sense understanding of the position existed within the Department and was applied in an appropriate manner. Proposed new section 26AAAB provides for the discounting of normal market rental value by 90 per cent in determining its assessable value in the hands of an employee. This amount is reduced for assessment purposes by the amount of any rent paid by the employee. The discount will apply to an employee who resides in a remote area and this is determined by a distance of 100 kilometres or more of the centre of a town or city with a population of more than 13,000 or 40 kilometres or more ora town with a population in excess of 12,000.
The second test is the close proximity to the work place. There are seven main tests for this and these are: The nature of the employer's business is such that employees are liable to frequent movement from one residential location to another; in the area in which the employee is employed there is not sufficient suitable residential accommodation otherwise available; the custom in the employer's industry to provide free or subsidised housing for employees; the employer's industry is one in which it is customary to provide subsidised housing for employees at, or in close

Income Tax Assessment Bill (No.2)

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3045

proximity to, the work place; the employee has no alternative to occupying the accommodation provided because suitable alternative accommodation: is not available at, or in close proximity to, the work place on reasonable terms and conditions or the employee is required by the employer to live at, or near, the work place and to be on call; the conditions under which the employee occupies the accommodation are onerous because of its proximity to the work place; and the employer of the taxpayer provides accommodation connected with the taxpayer's work place for at least six employees.
These values are applied from the year of income that commenced on 1 July 1977 and subsection 4(a) of the principal section, is the authority for retrospective amendments to apply where eligible taxpayers have been assessed on amounts in excess of the values now calculated. As I understand it, this means that those taxpayers who objected, and those who did not but who have been assessed on excessive rental values, now have the opportunity of having those assessments amended retrospectively to the year ended 30 June 1978. Those affected taxpayers should, upon royal assent being given to this Bill, approach the Taxation Office within their State for amendments.
Again I express the appreciation of many constituents of Dawson and remote areas of Australia and in on-locality industries for the Government's legislation on this housing rental issue. I wish to express my own appreciation to other members who assisted in bringing this legislation to fruition. I mention particularly the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Dean), the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Adermann), several senators and also officials within the sugar industry representations of the Australian Sugar Producers Association, the Proprietary Sugar Millers Association and the Co-operative Association. There are many people who assisted in this matter. The rural committee and the taxation committee of the Government backbench were of tremendous assistance in bringing this to the notice of the Government. I also acknowledge the patience and perseverance of those taxpayers in sugar mill housing accommodation and hope that their reward is as sweet to them as this result is to me.
Mr HUMPHREYS (Griffith) (8.12)-It is not very often that the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) and I agree in discussions in this House, but I agree with the honourable member on this occasion. I remember the occasion of a public meeting held by the miners in the town of Blackwater in Queensland.

That town is not in the honourable member's electorate but he had the intestinal fortitude to go to the meeting and to speak to the miners. Before he was allowed to speak, I had to defend him a little and cool the miners. I felt sorry for the honourable member on that occasion because he was defending a policy of his Government which he knew was wrong. I must say that he fought hard for the people in those isolated areas and that he knows the problems that they have to put up with. The members whom he was praising a moment ago did not have the intestinal fortitude to front up at that meeting but he did, so the honourable should hav~ not have given as much praise to those members as he has done. That is all I have to say to him; I agree with him.
As my colleague the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) pointed out, the Opposition supports the amending Bill now before us which deals with the tax treatment of employees occupying subsidised housing. Almost by default the Bill now makes possible a much more realistic and reasoned approach to those employees than was formerly the case. I say 'by default' because in 1978 the Government would probably never have countenanced such a concession. As my colleague the honourable member for Gellibrand also stated, the hard-won concession which was so grudgingly given by the Government enables the Commissioner of Taxation to treat the value of subsidised housing as 10 per cent of the market rental value of housing in the capital cities of the States less any rent paid by the employee.
An innovation in the Bill is the extension of these provisions to employees in industries other than the mining industry if the following conditions are met: The nature of the employers' business is such that employees are liable to frequent movements from one residential location to another; in the area in which the employee is employed there is not sufficient suitable residential accommodation otherwise available; or the custom of the employers' industry is to provide free or subsidised housing to employees. A further innovation is that an employee who lives in or adjacent to an urban centre is entitled.to the concessions provided all the foregoing conditions are satisfied. In addition, the Bill extends the concession to employees who occupy accommodation under conditions which are onerous because of its proximity to the work place and to taxpayers whose employer provides accommodation connected with the taxpayers' work place for at least six employees.
By extending the 90 per cent concession to employers in other industries, the Bill is potentially applicable to a host of other industries outside the

3046 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Income Tax Assessment Bill (No.2)

mining industry. A sample of occupations now eligible would be those connected with building, metal, power, gas, mining, timber, entertainment, postal and telecommunications, clubs and hotels, hospitals, local government, police, teachers, watchmen and Federal and State public servants. As my colleague the honourable member for Gellibrand has also pointed out, the provisions of the Bill permit seasonal employees in the north Queensland sugar industry to benefit from the concessions.
In case there is any lingering doubt in the minds of honourable members opposite that employees in remote areas are not deserving of such assistance, let me briefly describe some of the disadvantages that accompany that lifestyle. I can speak with authority about people living in isolated areas because for many years I travelled in outback Queensland, in the Channel country, through the Northern Territory and through the Kimberleys of Western Australia. The conditions that they have had to put up with over the years are arduous, as you would be well aware, Mr Deputy Speaker. They have to run their cars on dirty and dusty roads and as a result their tyres suffer many fractures. Just the expense of running
a motor vehicle in those areas is astronomical, not to mention having to live in dingy housing. I am sure honourable members are aware of the difficulties of trying to educate children in those areas-how it costs a tremendous amount of money to send children into the city, thus splitting up families and causing hardship. We need those people. out there. Some people say that those people do not have to live there and that they can
live in a city. But what would happen to Australia if those people were not living in those isolated areas? They are wonderful people-I have had a lot to do with them-and they deserve looking after. We in the Australian Labor Party will be looking after them.
Mr Hodgman-Next century.

are of fibro construction and are not insulated; nor are they air conditioned. It is abundantly clear, therefore, that employees in subsidised housing are not living in palaces by any stretch of the imagination.
I hope that the Government's experience arising out of and occasioning this Bill has taught it two lessons. The first lesson I hope that the Government has learned, and which Australian taxpayers made crystal clear during the miners' tax revolt, is the message that came from the taxpaying community that Australians have been taxed enough. A survey conducted in late August of 1980, after the miners' revolt had been running for 9 weeks, indicated that almost 60 per cent of Australians supported the miners. It is significant that the miners' revolt was not a strike in the community's eyes. The miners slogan became: 'Eureka No.2-miners' revolt 1980'. The miners were pathfinders and their struggle symbolised and tapped an undercurrent of disillusionment running through the community.
The second lesson I was hoping that the Federal Government had learned through the bitter experience of the tax revolt-alas, 1 regret to say it has not-is that when the taxpayer says 'Enough is enough', the Government must listen and respond immediately. It has taken three years to get this Bill and the concessions granted in it for people and workers living in isolated areas. There is little point in pouring salt on to old wounds, but the similarity between this and other broken tax promises is too evident to overlook. Just as the Government's intransigence in respect of the miners' revolt cost a high price, that is, the loss of millions of dollars of revenue and export earnings, so will the Government's broken promises-the promises that were made by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in March of this year-ultimately lead to the Government's downfall at the next election.

I think what we must recognise is the fact that the kind of assistance encompassed in this legislation, which is theoretically to the miners of Queensland, is in fact not assistance to the miners at all. It is assistance to the multinational coal proprietor and proprietors who will in fact receive the benefit of this reduction in their real costs of production to the disadvantage of the mining companies and the miners of the underground coal mines in New South Wales in particular. It seems to me absurd that the Government, as a result of political necessity, was forced to give way, and forced, I might say because of the political expediency of the Labor Party, which now says that it is opposed to the proposition but which, before the general election, was in favour of it. The reality of this situation is that by allowing an internationally dominated coal mining company to pay wages that are lower than it would otherwise pay, if in fact the full cost of housing was applied to the residences of the miners, and to allow that company to face a lower cost of production is to give it an unfair commerical advantage over the coal mines of New South Wales, for example, and certainly an advantage over the coal miners who live in my electorate.
It is extraordinary that the coal miners in my electorate were conned by their Queensland brethren to provide financial support for the strike of the coal miners in Queensland and that the successful outcome of that strike resulted in a situation in which there would be unfair competition against the New South Wales coal mines from Queensland coal mines subsidised, in effect, by the taxes of the Australian people. It seems to me to be totally improper that those big coal mines in Queensland which have a generally much lower cost of operation and which are earning profits should be benefiting to the competitive disadvantage of south coast coal mines, many of which are suffering enormous losses. I have a great deal of concern about the general principle of using the tax Act in this way, as the honourable member for Gellibrand has now properly expressed. He appears to be in conflict with the rest of his party. I also have a great deal of concern on the simple ground that this legislation is specifically and unfairly to the disadvantage of voters in my electorate.
Mr Hodgman-You always fight for the underdog.
Mr BAUME-Well, the underground dog in this case. I hope that the Government will not

proceed in this way in other matters. I recognise, though, the particular pressures which were imposed by a political environment in which I must say the Labor Party participated. We have heard honourable members from the other side of the House talk in disparaging terms about the general tax situation. This kind of problem is no doubt part of a general situation affecting the tax Act which does need improving. Undoubtedly, there are many hidden pieces of support for various sections of the community which cannot be assessed because they cannot be seen. The size of the assistance cannot be established when the tax Act and deductions under the tax Act are used to provide benefits. This is, I think, the general point that the honourable member for Gellibrand was making, but it seems to me that it is part of the total misunderstanding about the .proper role of the tax Act and the proper role of various kinds of taxes in Australia.
It is most unfortunate that any sensible attempts to discuss tax in Australia are continually frustrated by the actions of the newspapers, in particular, which unfortunately are the major method of communicating the messages from within this place to the general public. There is such a committed view, such a locked-in position, for example, among the newspaper proprietors who see tax particularly through the glasses of a 2+ per cent tax on newspapers-that is, the sales tax-that it is impossible to get across an accurate, reasonable and proper discussion of this vital matter. Some years ago, we even saw sections of private enterprise preventing the proper discussion of the tax system and certainly the indirect tax system when the retail traders of this nation involved themselves in a dishonest and disgraceful campaign to prevent even an inquiry into the proper methods of indirect taxation.
Whenever a government faces those kinds of problems it is inevitable that it cannot publicly discuss things because of the way in which special interest groups whip up massive antagonism. It cannot prepare itself effectively within the governmental structure because of the enormous volume of leaks that take place in discussions with that small, but nonetheless effective, minority of public servants who have a greater sense of loyalty to the political party they support than to the government they are supposed to be serving. Government cannot even discuss in great detail within departments the consequences of specific action it may want to take. This is a problem that confronted the Labor Party in government and which confronts this present Government. It is

3048 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Income Tax Assessment Bill (No.2)

disastrous that there cannot be a sensible examination in great detail within the departments themselves and that there certainly cannot be public discussion either.
It is in that environment, for example, that the people of Australia at present have fallen for one of the most deceptive propaganda campaigns I have seen in my time in parliament; That is, Australians now wrongly believe that the recent Budget sales tax rises represent a big, new and disastrous attack on their living standards. Everyone here knows that the total increase in indirect taxes this year will be the lowest in real terms for four years and will be less than half the indirect tax rise which took place in the last Hayden Budget. In fact it is only one-quarter the size of indirect tax rises of four years ago.. Yet the newsprint media is not prepared to report those facts. I might say that they have never been reported outside this chamber even though they have been said repeatedly by me and by the Treasurer (Mr Howard). No newspaper in the metropolitan areas of Australia has reported those facts-that this is the lowest indirect tax rise in four years and less than half the Hayden rise.
Mr Hodgman-Has the Illawarra Mercury reported that fact?
Mr BAUME-I might say that within my electorate the newspapers are sufficiently sensible to recognise the truth and to print it. However, no major metropolitan newspaper has reported these facts and it is as a result of overt and direct censorship that the newspapers refuse to print these facts. I have written for the Sydney Morning Herald in my role as chairman of the Government members taxation sub-committee an article outlining these facts. The Sydney Morning Herald has chosen not to print that article. It may well be that my journalistic efforts are of a very poor quality and therefore should not be printed, which would be an interesting contrast to the view that that same organisation held when it employed me as a super A journalist as investment editor of the Australian Financial Review.
It is fascinating that as a result of all these curious situations where we have the misuse of the tax Act-and this piece of legislation is another example of the misuse of the tax Act-we cannot have a proper, sensible approach to the whole question of taxation. To that extent, I support the comments of the honourable member for Gellibrand. I regret that so far this year we have not been able to see the sort of discussion of tax and the recognition of the reality of the reduced burden of indirect taxes that we should have seen. I conclude my remarks by pointing out to those

who are obsessed with sales tax that the Budget Papers dramatically show that had ther e not been the introduction of additional sales taxes, real indirect taxes actually would have fallen this year. That is another fact but one which has not been reported and which, I presume even after tonight, will not be reported from the empty Press Gallery.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Third Reading
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Hodgman) read a third time.
CENSUS AND STATISTICS AMENDMENT BILL (No.2) 1981
Second Reading
Debate resumed from 15 October, on motion by Mr Howard:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Mr WILLIS (Gellibrand) (8.30)-This Bill seeks to amend the Census and Statistics Act. It relates mainly to the privacy sections of that Act. The main provisions seek to tighten the confidentiality sections of the Census and Statistics Act so that suppliers of information can be assured that information relating to their personal or organisational activities will not be released to the public except in the case of an organisation where there is good reason to do so. It introduces a means by which information relating to an organisation which otherwise would not be publishable because publication would contravene the confidentiality sections of the Act can be published where there is good reason so to do. It also varies some penalties provided under the Act. It rearranges the Act in a more co-ordinated and well ordered way. Of course, it must be understood that this Act is one of the oldest Acts of the Parliament and was in substantial need of some reorganisation and amendment.
I will look in more detail at the provisions of the Bill, particularly at the way in which the confidentiality provisions have been tightened. As I mentioned, that has been done in several ways. I will refer to a couple of them. One is by increasing the penalty for unauthorised disclosure by officers or past officers of the Bureau of Statistics. The penalty is being increased from $1,000 or 12 months imprisonment or both to $5,000 or two years imprisonment or both. This is a substantial increase and particularly so when it is realised that the current penalty in the Act was introduced

Census and Statistics Bill (No.2)

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3049

only in May of this year. Prior to that it was only a $100 fine. Thus, in the course of this year, the maximum fine on Bureau officers for unauthorised disclosure has been increased 50-fold and a possible two-year gaol sentence has been added.
No explanation of the need for such a large rise in the penalty has been given by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in his second reading speech, which is rather poor to say the least. Indeed, the Treasurer misled the House in that speech by saying:
Maximum penalties incorporated in the Bill are similar to those enacted by Parliament in the autumn sittings.
He went on to make the exception of a deletion of the penalty of imprisonment for another offence. In fact, the penalty for the Bureau officers is not similar to those introduced in the autumn sittings. As I said, the fine is five times higher and the level of imprisonment has been doubled. The Government's cavalier treatment of such an amendment is contemptuous of Parliament in our view. Whilst we understand the intention of the amendment, we are not told why it has been deemed necessary to apply such an increase. Such action seems to us to be further evidence of the need to establish a sentencing council, as recommended by the Law Reform Commission in its fifteenth report entitled 'Sentencing of Federal Offenders'. In that report, recommendation 24 called for a sentencing council to be established to standardise penalties for Federal offenders. This seems to be a very sensible recommendation. At present, as in this Bill, the setting of penalties is absolutely on a rule of thumb basis. The Government introduced a penalty in May and then increased it five times in one respect and doubled it in another respect in a Bill in the next session. Where are we going? There has been no explanation to the Parliament as to why that level of penalty has been adopted. Obviously, it has been adopted on an absolute rule of thumb basis.
This is shown also by another amendment to the Act reducing a penalty which was increased only last May. The penalty concerned is that applying to persons who knowingly provide false information. Last May that penalty was increased from $100 to $1,000 or six months imprisonment or both, again without any reason being given other than the need to update the penalties. Now the Act is being amended to remove the penalty of imprisonment, again without reason as to why that is being done. When the Act was amended in May I drew attention, on behalf of the Opposition, to the stiffness of this penalty and expressed the Opposition's concern in regard to that increase. This was the subject of an amendment in

the Senate to remove the penalty of imprisonment. The Government used its then majorityone which it subsequently lost-to defeat that
amendment.
Apparently the Government has had second thoughts on this matter and has decided to do what the Senate amendment sought to achieve. In so doing it is, in effect, conceding that it was acting oppressively in threatening citizens with imprisonment for giving false information which, in some cases, could be rather harmless to the value of the statistics. For instance, someone who gives his name on the census form as Donald Duck or Mickey Mouse or who understates his age by five years or whatever could be under the threat of imprisonment under the law as amended last May. This information obviously does not make a great difference to the standard of the statistics, and threats of imprisonment for such offences seem to be rather oppressive. The Opposition, therefore, is pleased that the Government has decided now to retract this thoroughly unnecessary and excessive penalty.
Another way in which the confidentiality provisions of the Act are being amended is the introduction of a specific provision that statistical information shall not be published or disseminated
in a way which would enable identification of a particular person or organisation. Having specifically provided that prohibition, there is then the problem that, for example, production statistics in some areas, such as iron and steel to take an obvious example, could not be published because it would identify information provided by one organisation, to wit, the Broken Hill Proprietry Co. Ltd, which is virtually the sole producer of iron and steel in this country. So there is a problem clearly in relation to sole suppliers or predominant suppliers in an industry.
The way around that adopted in the Bill is to provide for a ministerial determination procedure authorising the Statistician to release information relating to an organisation but not a person and
for such a determination to be subject to disallowance by either House of Parliament. The determination may allow the Statistician to make such information available to a particular person who may be required to give an undertaking not to disclose any of that information and be subject to a
fine of up to $5,000 or two years gaol or both for breach of that undertaking. SUbject to what I have already said regarding penalties, the Opposition regards these measures as sensible and worthwhile amendments. They have, I understand, been put to and approved by the Australian Statistics Advisory Council, which advises the Statistician on statistical matters.

3050 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Census and Statistics Bill (No.2)

The only concern we have in relation to this procedure is that it does not seem to provide that the approval of the provider of the information is required before such information can be released.
The Treasurer said in his speech that the Statistician will, in making a decision about the release of such information, 'continue to be guided by an overriding concern to maintain the confidence and trust of respondents to statistical collections'. I have no doubt that this will be so, but such respondentswould probably feel more secure if it were specifically provided in the legislation that their approval, as well as that of the Statistician, was needed before a ministerial determination authorising the release of such information could be made. However, despite that slight concern and despite the concern I expressed previously about the increase in the fine without any rule other than that of the rule of thumb for arriving at a particular level of penalty, the Opposition is fully in support of the measures which are being
taken.
I want to make it clear that in approving of what the Government is doing in general in this Bill I am in no way implying that we approve of the way in which the Government has been handling the process of statistics collection in this nation during its period of office. Indeed, its record has been one of reckless unconcern for the quality and quantity of official statistics published in this country. I will refer briefly to some of the ways in which this Government has sabotaged the quality and quantity of official statistics in this country during its period of office. One way in which this is being done is by the application of
reduced staff ceilings to the Australian Bureau of Statistics along with most of the rest of the Public Service. There is no doubt that such reduction has caused a deterioration in the service provided and prevented desired improvements from being made. The Bureau's number of operative staff fell from 3,670 in June 1975 to 3,445 in June 1980, which was a fall of 225 or 6 per cent. Certainly, the number had gone up to 3,505 by the end of June 1981, but it went up because of the census which was held at the time.
So we are concerned at the fact that the staff has been reduced to this extent. Quite obviously
that has impaired the ability of the Bureau to undertake various activities which it would have wanted to undertake had adequate staff been available. In a minute to the Treasurer that became public some years ago the Statistician has made it clear that staff ceilings were having an adverse effect on Bureau performance. Since then I have noted that the Crawford Study Group on Structural Adjustment, the Australian Statistics

Advisory Council, ana the Bureau in its 1980 annual report, have all drawn attention to the detrimental effects that staff shortages are having on the Bureau's ability to maintain essential statistical output and to maintain a standard of accuracy and reliability of that output. As a consequence of the cutbacks in Bureau activity we have seen cutbacks in all types of publications. In 1976-77, the first financial year in which this Government was in charge of this country, it ceased the monthly survey of aggregate import orders; reduced the output of the foreign participation section; excluded unlisted companies from capital raising statistics; reduced the agricultural finance survey sample; reduced the frequency of data collection in some manufacturing production; excluded small business from the survey of manufacturing production; and reduced samples for surveys of earnings and hours, all of which, of course, reduced either the availability or the reliability of statistics.
By 1978 the Statistician was clearly worried and he pointed out in this minute to the Treasurer that many requests for information, especially from the States, had had to be refused which raised the question of whether the Government was abiding by the integration agreements, that is, the agreement by which the Commonwealth agrees to provide the States with adequate statistics in return for the States not running their own statistical service. He also pointed out that various planned surveys had had to be scrapped or postponed, for instance, the household expenditure survey which had been held in 1974 and 1975. It was to be held annually and was regarded as being important particularly as providing a sound basis for revision of the basket for the consumer price index, but it was not held after 1975.
Of course, that is something which is of real importance for this nation because it means that one of our key statistics-the inflation statistic, the consumer price index-is based on information which is inadequate. For us to have the proper information to have a really accurate assessment of inflation in this country we need revisions of the basket base and the weights of items in that basket based on a household expenditure survey. The Government's refusal to conduct such a survey means that we have a consumer price index which increasingly will reflect inaccurately the rate of inflation in this country. In the minute to the Treasurer in 1978 the Statistician said:
Faced with the task of getting required resources down to a level I judged likely to be accepted by the Government, I have excluded the survey--
That is, the household expenditure survey-
