me a great deal of harm in my own party. I wish that he would stop.
Mr Malcolm Fraser-Mr Speaker, I can afford to do it now that the honourable gentleman's position is secure.
Mr HAYDEN-It may well be true, as the Prime Minister observed earlier, that the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) and I will be going to the Sinai together. The Prime Minister's problem is that he cannot find anyone to go to the barricades with him. As I was saying, it is a great honour to serve in this Parliament and a great privilege to serve the people of this community. There are many trials and tribulations for all of us. Many problems confront us in the nature of the service that we seek to discharge as members of parliament, but it is a very satisfying service because it allows us to make some contribution in one way or another to the community.
In that respect, I note that the Prime Minister was being extraordinarily unfair to the honourable or, I suppose it is, right honourable-to what extent he is often right and, even less, to what extent he is honourable is a matter of dispute-the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman). I thought it was very harsh and cruel to discriminate against him. The Prime Minister said that the people who were unseen and unheard made the workings of the Parliament possible. I would have thought that the Minister for the Capital Territory made some contribution but one could never say that he was unseen and, least of all, that he was unheard. The Prime Minister said that on this occasion he would be merciful and not subject us to a 40-minute recantation of the record of Government in the past 12 months. We would have welcomed even four minutes of recantation of the record of the Government in the last 12 months. It is a record about which the Australian public deserves to be reminded. The occasion is such that I shall not explore that point further.
As this is a moment of good will, I turn to you, Mr Speaker. You are a man who is loved by all but who, perhaps, is frequently not appreciated. We are disappointed to hear that you are probably about to depart from this chamber to take up an appointment in the service of the community in the State of Victofia on behalf of Her Majesty. We wish you God speed and happy service in that part of Australia. It is not an easy task for you to serve the Parliament. I take the opportunity, should the report that we see in the newspapers be an accurate one and should the appointment take place before. Parliament resumes, of wishing you

well there. Apparently the newspaper reports may be correct.
Mr N. A. Brown-You are a bit behind in the news.
Mr Malcolm Fraser-It has been announced.
Mr HAYDEN-Has it really?
Mr Malcolm Fraser-Yes.
Mr HAYDEN-Oh my God, Mr Speaker, you missed out! I have to say that I am not so happy now that I have found that you have missed out. Once again Malcolm Fraser has let you down. You cannot rely on him. We commend the Hansard staff for the valuable contribution they make here in dissecting, faceting and polishing the priceless gems which we toss their way. Those gems must make their task much easier. The Clerks, of course, we respect highly. Their diaries of the indiscretions of members of parliament are something that they discreetly ensure are never presented to public life. For that we are eternally thankful.
It is, I repeat, a privilege to serve in this Parliament. It is sometimes a test of one's fortitude and even more of one's good will and, I suppose, common.Christian values for those among us who are Chri~tians, and for those of us, like myself, who are humanists our humanist values to serve here. For all that I am pleased to have completed my twentieth year in an environment which is always challenging, which is always stimulating and I trust one in which we all seek to the best of our abilities to make a constructive contribution. We are, as the Prime Minister commented, greatly improved in the work we seek to do by the myriad of people who work in this chamber, outside the chamber supporting the people in it and those behind them in places like the Parliamentary Library, which in my view constitutes the sinews and the sort of arterial system that allows Parliament to function properly. I reciprocate the seasonal greetings that the Prime Minister expressed. I reciprocate them in particular in respect of honourable members on the Government side. I sincerely trusUhey have enjoyed the past 12 months in government. The period ahead of them in government is extremely limited. We can assure them that the cushions on this side of the House are waiting to welcome them in the very near future.
Mr ANTHONY (Richmond-Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade and Resources) (12.17 a.m.)-I would like to join the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) in using this occasion while there is a ceasefire to extend cordial

Special Adjournment

19 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3085

seasonal greetings to all members of this chamber. I wish them a very happy Christmas and a very good New Year. We have performed this little ceremony on many occasions over the years. I suppose to some people it may seem a repetition of expressing appreciation to the many people who make this Parliament perform and fulfil its functions. But all those people give of their very best and so many of them are absolutely devoted to their cause.
I thank the members of this House for their very assiduous work within the chamber and on the committees in seeing that the functions of our national Parliament are fully performed. Of course this year we have had a good many new members come into this chamber. For them it is a unique experience. There is nothing like your first year in Parliament. It is always a bit strange. But I hope that those who have come here this year will by the end of the year be starting to settle down and will realise that there are certain values. I hope as the days go by they will live up to those values and try to sustain them because if we do not as a group sustain them then the place will fall apart. With those new members we have had the addition of three women to this chamber. Of course that is a great novelty because it is many years since we have had any ladies here. I think it has been very difficult for most of us to refer to them as honourable members rather than honourable gentlemen but we are learning and amending our ways, especially you, Mr Speaker. I notice that you do not make many errors in that respect now. I think the addition of the ladies to the chamber has made a marked improvement to the behaviour of us all. I think we have behaved better this year than we have behaved for many years, and no doubt it is because of the ladies.
Apart from the achievements of getting legislation through, time has been spent during the year in expressing our condolences to members of the Parliament who have passed away. During this year two members of the Parliament diedour colleague Eric Robinson and Senator John Knight. Everyone here would like to say that they will be thinking of those families during this Christmas which will be a particularly sad time for them. I will be thinking of them and I am sure everybody else will. Family life is the hardest part of being a member of parliament. It imposes an enormous strain on one's wife and one's children, particularly in these circumstances.
Mr Hayden-We, too, sympathise with Margot.
Mr ANTHONY-I sympathise very much with your wife, Bill. Mr Speaker, I also express

appreciation to you for your unfailing patience and forbearance with the members of this chamber and, I suppose, myself. You have done a very distinguished job, as you normally do. I thank you, the Chairman of Committees and his deputies, the Clerks, the Serjeant-at-Arms, the parliamentary attendants-a multitude of people-and the people up in the Australian Broadcasting Commission who spread our good messages around Australia. I thank them. I thank the members of the Hansard staff who do a remarkable job, as the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) mentioned, in making our speeches legible and intelligent. I thank them very much. I also thank the Parliamentary Library and people like that wonderful institution, Gordon Pike, for whom we all have affection and great respect. It goes further afield. I would even like to pay a tribute to the gardeners around Parliament House. I think that they do a tremendous job. I doubt whether anywhere in Australia there is a finer display of roses at the moment than in the parliarnentary gardens. The honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) makes a few comments. We have some finer feelings on this side of the House. It is on occasions like this that we like to display them. The Opposition thinks it has a monopoly even on the roses. I assure it that it has not. Rather than take up the time of the House I again express Christmas greetings to everybody. I hope they re'turn to this Parliament in 1982 in the very best of health having had time to do their electoral chores and also to get themselves fit for another vigorous year of parliamentary activities.
Mr SPEAKER-I would like to make a couple of points. Firstly, I thank the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) for his good wishes to me! Although the patience required from the Chair can be relaxed on this occasion, I must say to the Leader of the Opposition that the dignity of the place is not added to by the lack of sincerity in what he said. The other point I wish to make is that if one speaks of the dignity of the House, one must look at the commencement of the day's sitting. We have petitions presented and the petitions usually last for 10 or more minutes. In the course of that 10 or more minutes it is natural that honourable members preparing for the day's proceedings talk to each other and the level of conversation in the chamber is very high. It is obvious that the petitions are not being listened to. I think that the Leader of the House (Mr Sinclair) ought to take action for the House to consider the way in which it ought to dispose of the issue of petitions and not submit the petitions to lack of consideration or the House to lack of dignity.

3086 REPRESENTATIVES 19 November 1981

Special Adjournment

The next point I wish to make is that almost all of the members on occasions hear extracts. from the House of Commons in Westminster, and on occasions even from the United States House of Representatives or from the Canadian House of Commons. It is not possible for the radio media in Australia to play extracts from this chamber. I think that is a matter which should be corrected. My observation, or my hearing of what has been done by the radio stations, is that there is a great deal of responsibility in ~he way those extracts are presented.
The next point I wish to make is that from my observation the commencement time of the House of Representatives, 1.45 p.m., is a great difficulty not only for honourable members but also for staff. I hope there will be a change in that commencement time which, I am sure, will enable honourable members to conduct their business in the mornings. As we all know, the mornings are fully occupied by us all. Finally, I wish to take the opportunity of saying that a man I have known for the period I have been in Parliament is about to retire. He is Mr Wally Sharpe, a driver who may be known to honourable members. He is about to retire after almost 50 years' service. He will retire before we come back. I join in the general good wishes to all honourable members. I hope they will have a very enjoyable Christmas period with their families. I hope the break will be very good for them all and that we can come back in February with a great deal of compassion and good will, one to the other.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
House adjourned at 12.27 a.m. (Thursday) until Tuesday, 16 February 1982, at 1.45 p.m., unless otherwise called together by Mr Speaker or, in the event of Mr Speaker being unavailable, by the Chairman of Committees.
NOTICE
The following notice was given:
Mr Porter to move-
That this House-
(I) affirms that decisions about the functions to be performed by a Department of State and the number of people to be employed are decisions for government, not unions or individual employees;
(2) affirms that taxpayers are entitled to have the public servants they employ carry out the work they are employed to do;
(3) deplores the use of bans and disruptive procedures by the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association as an industrial weapon to interfere with the processing of pensions and benefits in the Department of Social Security thereby threatening the welfare of pensioners and beneficiaries, and
(4) calls on the ACOA to lift the bans without delay.

REPLIES TO REQUESTS FOR DETAILED INFORMATION
Department of the Parliamentary Library
On 20 October 1981, Mr John Brown asked Mr Speaker:
(I) Is it a fact that (a) 104 full-time staff ceased duty in the Parliamentary Library over the 3-year period 1975-77 and (b) the corresponding figure for the years 1978-80 was 148; if so, does this represent an increase of 42%.
(2) On what date did Mr Harold Gibson Weir (a) commence duty as a 2nd Division Officer of the Parliamentary Library and (b) become Parliamentary Librarian.
(3) Does the increase in separations since 1978 pose a serious problem for the Library in terms of maintenance of efficiency and morale.
(4) What reasons are there for the accelerated separation rate.
(5) What action (a) has been taken and (b) is planned to reduce the separation rate to a more tolerable level.
Mr Speaker-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes.
(2) (a) August 1976, (b) August 1978.
(3) Separations arise for a number of reasons but a principal factor is career opportunity. For example, a study conducted in December 1980 of all separations of permanent officers from the Legislative Research Service for the period January 1970-December 1980 indicated that, given the limited promotion opportunities within that Service, many officers regarded employment within the Department as a stage in a general Public Service career. Of the 50 separations in that period, 31 officers transferred or were promoted to other Departments or authorities, while 16 resigned to take appointments in private industry, academic institutions and so on. There were 3 separations for other reasons, e.g. retirement, death. Over the same period, 27 officers transferred into or were promoted to the Legislative Research Service, while 23 were recruited from private industry, academic institutions etc.
Separations cause concern because of limited staffing and existing workloads and because of the delays and expense involved in filling vacancies. As such these can reflect on both efficiency and morale.

Repliesfor Detailed Information

19 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3087

(4) No study has been conducted on a Department wide' basis. However the above study showed that improved employment prospects for economists particularly and lawyers were an influential factor in total separations between 1977 and December 1980. The difficulties experienced in attracting replacement staff bear out this conclusion.
(5) (a) and (b) The matter has been under study and plans have been made for separation interviews to take place in order to provide necessary information. However, a high separation rate appears inevitable given the existing career opportunities.
Department of the Parliamentary Library
On 20 October 1981, Mr Kerin asked Mr Speaker:
(I) Who instituted the practice of including in answers to Requests for Detailed Information relating to the administration of the Parliamentary Departments the amount of time taken to prepare the answer.
(I) Is the intent of this practice to discourage the asking of these questions; if not, what is the reason for this practice.
(3) Will he issue an instruction that the practice is to cease; if not, why not.
(4) Is it the right of all Members to ask Requests for Detailed Information without reservation or exception; if not, why not.
Mr Speaker-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) The practice was instituted by Mr President and myself as Presiding Officers in May 1981 in respect 'of the Department of the Parliamentary Library.
(2) No. The intention is to provide information concerning the amount of staff time taken to prepare answers. The practice is consistent with that already in existence for other client services of the Library.
(3) No. See (2) above.
(4) Yes.
Department of the Parliamentary Library
On 20 October 1981, Mrs Child asked Mr Speaker:
(I) Was finance provided in the 1981-82 Budget for the acquisition of an additional word-processing unit for the Parliamentary Library.
(2) Who made the decision to acquire this unit and what is iis cost.
(3) Which (a) section and (b) officers of the Library will be using this unit.
(4) What studies have been carried out to ensure the (a) cost efficiency of the unit for its purpose and (b) safety of the unit for the operators.
(5) Who carried out these studies and when were they carried out.
(6) Have the persons intended to operate the unit been (a) advised of this intention, (b) consulted as to (i) the practicality of the unit's use in the intended area and (ii) the unit's safety; if not, why not.
Mr Speaker-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) $11,000 was allocated for purchase of word processing equipment for 1981-82 financial year.

(2) The then Parliamentary Librarian decided in the context of Departmen'tal developments in 1981-82 that additional word processing capacity in the Department was desirable and should be provided for in the Estimates. An additional machine will cost approximately $11,000.
(3) (a) and (b) Yet to be determined. Areas requiring word processing capacity include the Technical Services Section, Current Information Section-Transcript Service and the Office of the Parliamentary Librarian.
(4) (a) Cost efficiency studies were carried out prior to the acquisition of the first units by the Department in 1978. In work involving high levels of text editing or repetitive typing, word processors have reduced typist tedium and mistakes and have increased productivity.
(b) Operator safety has been discussed with appropriate sectors of the Public Service Board and their advisers and with union officials. Current reports published in the literature from time to time are also monitored. The Department believes that the units are safe for normal operation.
(5) (a) Members of Library staff in consultation with an officer of the Public Service Board.
(b) Both the APSA and Public Service Board advisers have the results of a number of studies relating to the safety of computer related screens reported in recent years.
(6) (a) and (b) General discussions have taken place but until a decision is made concerning the location of an additional machine specific considerations are delayed.
Department of the Parliamentary Library
On 20 October 1981, Dr Blewett asked Mr Speaker:
(I) Who made the decision to acquire a telefacsimile machine for communication between the Parliamentary Library's Parliament House and former Hotel Kurrajong locations.
(2) What was the cost of this machine.
(3) Was the decision to buy the machine based on proposals to relocate (a) all or (b) part of the Legislative Research Service at the former Hotel Kurrajong; if not, on what was it based.
(4) Where are the 2 terminals for the machine located in Parliament House and the former Hotel Kurrajong.
(5) Who is responsible for the actual operation of the machine at each end.
(6) What is the estimated (a) number of sheets which will be transmitted each year and (b) annual operating cost, inclusive of materials, maintenance and staff time.
Mr Speaker-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) The decision to acquire a telefacsimile machine was made by the then Parliamentary Librarian and senior officers involved in preparing the Departmental estimates for 1981~82. This was as a result of an undertaking given to a Senate Sub-Committee earlier in the year which was inquiring into accommodation matters.
(2) $607 per month per machine.
(3) The decision to lease machines was based on two major consider a tions:
(i) A requirement to have high speed transfer of documents between Parliament House and the Hotel Kurrajong for the Statistics Group of the Legislative Research Service, Management Services Branch and Systems and Co-ordination Unit, which are all at the Kurrajong Annex.

3088 REPRESENTATIVES 19 November 1981

Replies for Detailed Information

(ii) For some years the Department and the Joint Standing Committee on the Library have been examining systems for high speed transmission of documents between Parliament House and Senators' or Members' electorate offices. Telefacsimile transmission appears to be the most suitable means for achieving this purpose. The present installation will be used to evaluate the suitability of such a service.
(4) The telefacsimile machines are located:
(i) Room Bl4-Hotel Kurrajong (ii) Photocopy area-Basement-Parliament House
(5) At Parliament House the staff in the photocopying area are responsible for sending and receiving copy. At the Kurrajong Annex the person sending the text is responsible for operating the machine.
(6) (a) Initially it is expected that the number of sheets to be transmitted will be moderate, with a rapid increase as the capability of the equipment becomes better known. The estimates for the first two years of operations are:
Year 1-5,000 sheets Year 2-8,000 sheets
(b)Machines-lease plus maintenance, $1214 per month. Consumables-of the order of $0.12 per sheet Staff time-of the order of 2-3 minutes per transaction,
i.e. $0.50 per transaction.
Consumable and staff time will, therefore, add approximately $3,000 to the machine cost in the first year of operation.
Department of the Parliamentary Library
On 28 October 1981, Mr Morris asked Mr Speaker:
(1) Who initiated the current User Needs Survey of Members and Senators which is being conducted on a random basis by the Parliamentary Library.
(2) Was there any consultation with client services staff in the preparation of this survey; if so, what are the details; if not, what is the reason.
(3) How many Members and Senators will be surveyed, who are they, and how were they chosen.
(4) What is the purpose of this survey and will it be a regular occurrence.
(5) Does the Survey specifically relate to current services offered by the Library.
(6) Will the expansion or contraction of existing client services, or the introduction of new services, depend on the results of this survey.
(7) What cognisance was taken of both the debate on the Library's appropriation in Senate Estimates Committee A, and the report of that Committee, in the preparation and conduct of this survey.
(8) Was the joint Library Committee consulted in the preparation of this Survey.
(9) Which Library staff members are responsible for (a) the conduct of the survey and (b) the analysis of its results.
(10) Will the results of this survey be made known; if so, in what form and to whom.
Mr Speaker-The answer to the honourable members' question is as follows:
(1) The Head, Systems and Co-ordination Unit. The survey was initiated as a basis for considering improvements to existing systems and services.
(2) Yes. The HeaJ Librarian nominated staff from the Current Information Section and ALERT service to work on

a planning committee. Subsequently advice and assistance was received from the Statistics Group of the Legislative Research Service.
(3) Invitations to participate in the survey were sent to 60 Senators and Members. It is hoped that at least 40 will agree to be interviewed. They were chosen using a table of random numbers from a list of all Senators and Members excluding the Presiding Officers and Ministers. All other Senators and Members will receive a copy of the questions and will be asked to respond by mail. Thus all Senators and Members will be included. A list of the Senators and. Members invited to participate in interviews is held by the Acting Parliamentary Librarian.
(4) The purpose of the survey is to gather accurate data on the current information needs of Senators and Members for news information and current published material in those areas of public affairs in which they take a special interest and wish to keep up-to-date. Similar surveys have been conducted on two occasions in the past II years and may be conducted at periodic intervals in the future. Future surveys may also focus on different aspects of the Department's services.
(5) No. However, the survey is focused on client needs for current awareness services and selective dissemination of information services, both of which are partially covered by existing Library services and are named in the survey questions.
(6) The results of the survey will be used to seek to improve the effectiveness of Library services. The availability of resources will affect the rate or direction of change and other factors, for example, the relevance of new technology, will also be taken into account.
(7) Views expressed on the provision of news information services and current 1jwareness services were noted.
(8) No. Any proposals for changes or improvements to Library services resulting from the Survey would be referred to the Client Services Sub-Committee and then to the full Committee.
(9) (a) and (b) Officers from the Systems and Coordination Unit, Library, Reference and Information Services, Current Information Services and ALERT service.
(10) Yes. Initially in a report to Principal Officers which will subsequently be circulated to staff. See also the answer to Question 8.
Department of the Parliamentary Library
On 29 October 1981, Mr Holding asked Mr Speaker:
(I) With respect to the statement by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senate Hansard, 27 October 19in, page 1649) that the cut in the Parliamentary Library's funds is a matter for the Presiding Officers and the Joint House Department to determine what is done, can he state (a) for how long has it been the policy for the Joint House Department to determine internal matters of the Parliamentary Library or any other Parliamentary department, and (b) is this policy a result of recommendations in the Urwick Report.
(2) Are discussions currently proceeding for the amalgamation of the Departments of the Parliamentary Library, Parliamentary Reporting Staff and Joint House; if so, what are the details.
Mr Speaker-The answer to the honourable members' question is as follows:
(I) (a) and (b) There is no such policy.
(2) A meeting has been held with the Permanent Heads of the Parliamentary Departments. Details of that meeting are not available.

Answers to Questions

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3089 AN~.wERS TO QUESTION~,

The following answers to questions were circulated:

Boeing 707 Aircraft: Communications Equipment
(Question No. 165)
Mr Morris asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 26 November 1980:
(I) Did he endorse supplementary information' supplied to House of Representatives Estimates Committee A (Estimaies Committees A and B Hansard, 25 September to 23 October 1979, page 472) that the two Boeing 707 aircraft used by the Prime Minister would be fitted with secure voice communications equipment during 1979-80; if so, has this fitting been completed.
(2) If the fitting of this equipment has been completed what was the cost of (a) supply and (b) installation in each aircraft, registered Nos. A20-624 and A20-627.
(3) If the fitting of the equipment has not been completed, (a) when will the installation be completed and (b) what is the anticipated cost of installation in each aircraft.
(4) Was this question first asked on 9 September 1980 and did it remain unanswered at the termination of the 31 st Parliament.
Mr Newman-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) My predecessor endorsed the supplementary information supplied to the House of Representatives Committee on 9 Novem ber 1979.
(2) and (3) The Department of Defence has advised that the installation of the communications equipment incorporating a secure teleprinter facility (in lieu of the secure voice facility originally proposed), to be carried out by Qantas, has not yet started due to components not being available but is expected to commence early next year although some items of equipment will still not be immediately available. It is anticipated that installation will be completed by April 1982.
The Secure Communications element within the project approval of $14.575m for acquisition of the two aircraft is estimated at $662,000.
(4) Yes.
Vietnam: Use of Herbicides and Pesticides
(Question No. 486)
Mr Holding asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 5 May 1981.
(I) Has his attention been drawn to an article headed 'KRIEGSRAISON GEHT VOR KRIEGSRECHT-The Cause of War goes before the Law of War' (Pacific Defelice Reporter, November 1980, pages 59 to 68).
(2) If so, did the use of herbicides and pesticides in Vietnam follow from the application of the doctrine of military necessity.
Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes.
(2) Detailed information on Australian use of herbicides and other pesticides in Vietnam is contained in papers I tabled

in the Parliament on 27 March 1980 and in a report coordinated by the Department of Health, entitled: 'Pesticides Used in Vietnam Hostilities and Their Use in Australian Agriculture: a Comparative Study', a copy of which has been placed in the Parliamentary Library.
Migrant and Visitors' Visas
(Question No. 2638)
Mr Young asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 10 June 1981:
(I) How many applications for migration to Australia, and from which countries, were received each year since 1978 and during the period I January to 9 June 1981.
(2) How many applications for visitors' visas were received for the same period.
(3) How many of the applications for (a) migration and (b) visitors' visas received in each country were (i) accepted and (ii) rejected.
(4) What were the major causes for rejecting applicants for (a) migrant and (b) visitors' visas in each country.
(5) What sum was raised through (a) migrant and (b) visitors' visas.
(6) How many persons were employed in (a) Australia and (b) each overseas country to deal exclusively with the (i) migrant and (ii) visitors' visa applications since 1978.
Mr Macphee-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) See Table A.
(2) See Table B.
(3) (a) See Table A; (b) See Table B.
(4) (a) No register of the reasons for refusal of migrant entry applications is maintained.
However other statistics kept indicate that where applications are rejected prior to interview the reasons are usually because either applicants do not fall within one of the eligible categories or, if they do, they would obviously not be able to achieve sufficient points under NUMAS to justify the costs associated with further processing.
The main reason applications are rejected after interview are unacceptable occupational qualifications, unsatisfactory personal and/or settlement factors and failing to meet health or character requirements.
(b) No register of the reasons for refusal for visitor applications is maintained.
Most refusals are where officers are of the opinion that applicants do not intend a bona fide visit but rather intend to remain permanently in Australia. Some refusals are on character grounds.
(5) Neither the application for, nor the grant of, a visitor or migrant visa is subject to the payment of a fee.
(6) (a) (i) 64 persons, on average, were employed to deal exclusively with migrant visa applications.
(ii) 27 persons, on average, were employed to deal exclusively with visitor visa applications.
(b) Not available. The Department does not disaggregate workforce participation in work performed at overseas posts.

Illegal Entry to Australia
(Question No. 2643)
Mr Young asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 10 June 1981:
(I) Is his Department conducting an inquiry into allegations that many South Koreans have entered Australia illegally; if so, has the inquiry been completed.
(2) If the inquiry has been completed do the results show that South Koreans were being employed in Australia in crafts in which they had no proper qualifications to undertake.
(3) What action has been taken against persons found to be entering Australia illegrlly and/or against those who supplied any false documents to assist their entry.

Mr Macphee-The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:
(1) The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs began investigations some time ago. In the light of evidence that some South Korean nationals had, through false representations, obtained visas to travel to Australia and that some, when in Australia had obtained residence by false representations, the investigation was continued by the Australian Federal Police. I understand that the Police investigations are virtually completed but that some action as a result of those investigations remains to be taken.
(2) The investigations revealed that some people did not take up employment in the field in which they claimed trade qualifications. More detailed investigations revealed that in some cases those persons did not in fact possess qualifications

Answers to Questions

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3093

which would permit them to operate within the claimed trade or craft.

(3) Generally the investigations revealed that proper entry and residence permits had been issued although some of them
had been obtained through the use of supporting documents which were false.

As a result of Australian Federal Police inquiries within Australia a number of persons have been charged with offences and it is expected that (a) further charge(s) will be laid.

One of the prosecutions has resulted in a guilty plea and has

been referred to the District Court Sydney for sentence on a

date yet to be established.

.

The immigration status of persons who obtained visas and entry permits by false representations will be considered individually.

Some of the persons concerned were applicants under the recent Regularisation of Status Program and these are being'
considered within the spirit of that Program.

National Crimes Commission
(Question No. 3111)
Mr Jacobi asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 16 September 1981:
(I) Further to my call for the urgent establishment of a National Crimes Commission, has the Attorney-General's attention been drawn to a recent Press article relating to statements made by Mr Fred Sylvester, Director of the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence, stating that (a) petty jealousies between State Police forces were allowing organised crime to gain an increasing national foothold, (b) he had recommended to the Royal Commission the establishment of a Federal Crime Commission, wider powers for his own organisation and more contact with overseas drug and intelligence agencies to allow the Australian Federal Police to fight entrenched organised crime effectively, and (c) organised crime had spread throughout Australia and no individual State could control it.
(2) If so, is the Attorney-General sympathetic to these submissions and will he reconsider my repeated request and take immediate steps to implement the detailed recommendations for a Crimes Commission which have been published by the Australian Institute of Criminology and which would incorporate not merely the need for investigation into scandals of this kind but the more practical planning ahead through economic and social measures to reduce the opportunities for organised and white collar crime.
Mr N. A. Brown-The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:
(I) A number of the Press reports of the statements referred to in the honourable member's question have been drawn to my attention.
(2) As the Attorney-General informed the honourable member earlier this year in reply to Question No. 174 which raised the same point, the Government does not propose to establish a National Crimes Commission in relation to organised crime but rather to tackle identified problems in the area of organised crime with selective investigative machinery, involving the State Governments as appropriate. For example, the Government, in conjunction with the Governments of the States of New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland recently appointed Mr Justice Stewart to be a Royal Commissioner to inquire into a number of matters including the activities of Terrence John Clark and person associated with him and whether those activities involved a

contravention of laws of the Commonwealth relating to the importation or possession of drugs. Subsequent events have not provided any reason for the Government to change its views on this matter.
Another major initiative in the area of combating organised crime has been the establishment by the Commonwealth and State Governments of the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence as a body to gather and disseminate criminal intelligence for all police bodies in Australia.
Australian-produced Wine
(Question No. 3216)
Mr Kerin asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 23 September 1981:
(I) What are the regulations governing the use of (a) flavouring and (b) concentrate in Australian-produced wine.
(2) Have there been any occasions when Australian wine has been withdrawn from sale as a result of the use of flavouring or concentrate.
(3) Was a line of traminer riesling produced in New South Wales recently withdrawn from sale because of a breakdown suspected to have been caused by the use of flavouring.
Mr Nixon-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) In Australia standards for wine are a State and Territory responsibility. The relevant regulations are:
New South Wales-Pure Food Regulations. Queensland-Food and Drug Regulations. Victoria-Food and Drug Standards Regulations. South Australia-Food and Drug Regulations. Western Australia-Food and Drug Regulations. Tasmania-Public Health (Food and Drug Standards) Regulations. Australian Capital Territory-Public Health (Sale of Food and Drugs) Regulations.
No relevant regulations are in force in the Northern Territory.
(2) and (3) I am not aware of any case where the State and Territory authorities which administer the relevant regulations have caused a wine to be withdrawn from sale as a result of it containing or having been suspected to contain flavouring or concentrate. Individual winemakers withdraw wine from sale from time to time for a variety of reasons but I am not aware of a New South Wales produced traminer riesling or any other wine having been withdrawn from sale because of a breakdown suspected to have been caused by the use of flavouring.
Woodchips: Export
(Question No. 3303)
Mr West asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 14 October 1981:
(I) Has his Department received an application to export 100,000 tonnes of woodchips from Harris Daishowa Pty Ltd.
(2) If an application has been received are the woodchips to be obtained from Victorian forests; if so, from what areas of the forests will the wood be cut and by which companies.
(3) Has the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act been invoked; if so, has an environmental impact statement been called for.
Mr Nixon-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes.

3094 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Answers to Questions

(2) Yes; I am advised that the Victorian Government has granted short term pulpwood licences to 27 sawmillers in the Cann River and Orbost areas to harvest the pulpwood in conjunction with their normal logging operations for a trial period ending 31 July 1982.
(3) Yes; decisions concerning the environmental assessment of proposals are the responsibility of the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment.
Naval Exercises: Western Australia
(Question No. 3345)
Mr Beazley asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 15 October 1981:
(I) Has his Department scheduled naval exercises for the Lancelin Naval Gunfire Support Range of Western Australia for 5 days, 5-10 February 1982.
(2) If so, were these dates arrived at to meet the convenience of United States of America Navy units which will be participating in the exercises.
(3) Will the exercise involve closure of a sea area of 23km by 8km at the height of the Western Australian rock lobster fishing season.
(4) Has his attention been drawn to the fact that the closed area normally would contain some 4,000 rock lobster pots at that time and his Department's attitude of conveniencing the US Navy will mean serious loss of revenue to Western Australian lobster fishermen who earned Australia $60 million in export income in 1980.
(5) Has he previously received letters of complaint from the Australian Fishing Industry Council concerning the lack of consulation by naval authorities in the timing of exercises. .
(6) Will he reconsider the timing of this forthcoming exercise to protect the position of persons engaged in the industry of increasing importance to Western Australia.
Mr KiIIen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) The Department of Defence has not yet scheduled naval exercises for the Lancelin Naval Gunfire Support Range in February 1982. Proposals have been received from United States authorities to conduct exercises on those dates and these are presently being evaluated by the Department of Defence.
(2) The dates for the exercises were proposed by the United States Navy. The Department of Defence has informed United States authorities of the problems which are caused to the rock lobster fishing industry by the conduct of naval exercise in the Lancelin area at that time of the year. The Department of Defence is continuing negotiations with the aim of either postponing the exercises to a more suitable date, or, by consulation with local fishermen and the Australian Fishing Industry Council, to establish restrictions on exercise activities that are acceptable to the fishing industry. Some meetings have already been held in this regard between the Naval Officer Commanding West Australia Area (NOCWA), the Australian Fishing Industry Council (WA Branch) and local fishermen.
(3) No.
(4) Yes.
(5) Yes, on matters concerning consulation by Naval authorities with the Australian Fishing Industry Council prior to exercise activities at the Lancelin Range. Liaison is now well established between NOCWA and executive Officer of the WA Branch of the /' Jstralian Fishing Industry Council.
(6) Yes.

Exposure of Australian Servicemen to War Gases During Second World War
(Question No. 3349)
Mr Holding asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice on 15 October 1981:
(I) Has his attention been drawn to claims made in an AAP Wire Service article by correspondent Craig Skehan, dated 14 October 1981, relating to exposure of Australian servicemen to war gases during the Second World War.
(2) If so, is he able to confirm whether these tests took place.
(3) If they did take place (a) how many servicemen or women were exposed to various gases during the tests, (b) what gases were tested, (c) what was the full military designation of the Chemical Research Unit, (d) which officer or officers were responsible for authorising the conduct of the tests, (f) was any medical monitoring of those personnel carried out by Australian military forces, for any period whatsoever after the tests; if so, what are the details, and (g) were the service personnel exposed to the gases acting as volunteers or in some other capacity; if so, what.
(4) With respect to the claim that 50 Australian pilots had taken part in a poison gas bomb experiment on an island off Cairns, Qld, on 21 January 1944, which resulted in the death of a number of American prisoners serving life sentences, is there any substance to the claim; ifso, will he supply all details of the incident.
Mr KiIIen-The answer to the honqurable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes.
(2) and (3) As is a matter of public record, chemical warfare experiments took place in Australia During World War II. I refer the honourable member to my statement in the House of Representatives on 27 October 1981, which incorporated details. A considerable amount of more detailed information is available to public researchers through Australian Archives.
Work is underway in the Department of Defence to pass to Australian Archives other relevant records which have not yet been cleared for public access. This work is being given high priority, taking into account the need to preserve the privacy of individuals.
(4) I refer the honourable member to the answer to a Question Without Notice asked of the then Minister for Defence on 15 April 1975 (House of Representatives Hal/sard, pages 1579-1580).
Defence Services: Recruitment
Question No. 3351
Mrs Darling asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 20 October, 1981:
Further to his reply to my question No. 1050 (Hal/sard, 9 September 1981, pages 1123-4) is he prepared to commission an inquiry within his Department to determine whether persons enlisted at the minimium age and for the maximum period of service are more likely to seek discharge before their period of enlistment is completed than older recruits; if not, why not.
Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
No. For 1980 alone a manual search of over 1600 personal files would be required. I cannot see any benefits arising out of such an inquiry that would justify the diversion of resources involved.

Answers to Questions

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3095

P.T. Australian Indonesian Milk Industries Incorporated
Question No. 3398
Mr Kerin asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 22 October 1981:
(I) Is the Australian Dairy Corporation to sel1 its 50 per cent shareholding in one of its subsidiaries, P.T. Australian Indonesian Milk Industries Incorporated.
(2) If so, is the money from this sale to be used to undertake further investment in overseas projects.
(3) On what basis does the Government justify the continued operation of the remaining subsidiaries of the Corporation which sel1 products otlier than milk, such as orange juice and biscuits.
(4) As the Government has stated that the aim of the Review of Commonwealth Functions was to withdraw the Government from functions more appropriately handled by private enterprise, why was the sale of Corporation subsidiaries, already the subject of controversy and an example of Government operating in a traditional1y private enterprise area, left untouched.
Mr Nixon-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) The chairman of the Australian Dairy Corporation (ADC) announced recently that the Corporation had received an offer for its shareholding in P.T. Australian Indonesian Milk Industries (P.T. Indomilk) and that the Corporation was negotiating the sale of its shareholding.
(2) Proceeds from any sale would be paid into the Dairying Industry Stabilization Fund and would be available for the benefit of the dairy industry generally in accordance with section II of the Dairying Industry Act 1962.
(3) Guidelines are currently in the process of final consideration between myself and the Boards of ADC and Asia Dairy Industries (H.K.) Limited (AD!) which will enable the AD! to participate in ventures al1ied to but not solely invol ved with dairy food manufacture. This was considered by the Government to be desirable as it would widen the base for product development and could result in cost reductions through more efficient use of facilities.
(4) This is a matter of Government policy.
Army Artillery
(Question No. 3401 )
Mr Kerin asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 22 October 1981:
(I) Was the artil1ery discussed in his statement of 20 October 1981 (Hansard, page 2200) previously promised to be delivered to the Army in1981.
(2) When wil1 the artil1ery be delivered to the Army.
Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Previous statements on Defence planning indicated that replacement of light and medium artil1ery weapon systems was proposed in the early 1980s. In this planning replacement of the medium guns always had the higher priority. Orders for the 155 mm guns have been placed with the United States and deliveries are expected to commence in 1984.
(2) With regard to the I05mm guns referred to in my statement of 20 October 1981, it is now intended to manufacture this type of gun in Australia. The next step is to make two preproduction models for trial in 1985. Subject to satisfactory

production and trial it should be possible to begin equipping the Regular Army with the new weapons in 1988.
Defence Report 1981: Delay in Presentation
(Question No. 3419)
Mr Morrison asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 27 October 1981:
(I) Was the Defence Report 1981 transmitted to him by the Chief of Defence Force Staff and the Secretary of his Department on 18 August 1981.
(2) Did he table the Report on 20 October 1981.
(3) Why was the Report not available for the information of Members during the Budget debate and during consideration of the proposed expenditures of his Department by Estimates Committee A.
(4) What were the reasons for the delay of over 2 months in presenting the Report to the Parliament.
Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) No. I first saw the Report, at that stage in page proof, in early October 1981. The Report carries the date of the most recent information it contains, in this case 1981 budget figures: 18 August 1981 was budget day.
(2) Yes.
(3) Publication of the Report, a process not under Defence control, took eleven weeks.
(4) There was no delay in presenting the Report to Parliament. It was tabled the day after receipt from the printer.
Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme: Appeal Tribunals
(Question No. 3430)
Dr Blewett asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 27 October 1981:
(I) What is the process by which tribunal officials are nominated to the Commonwealth Government Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme appeal tribunals.
(2) What are the required qualifications for tribunal officials.
(3) Are there standard procedures for the assessment of student appeals by tribunals; iF so, what are these procedures; if not, on what basis do officials assess an application.
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) The members of Student Assistance Review Tribunals are not Government officials but part time members chosen largely from the legal and academic communities. The procedure for the establishment of the Tribunals is prescribed by the provisions of the Student Assistance Act 1973 and its regulations. Each Tribunal consists of a Chairman and two members. The Tribunal Chairmen are normal1y selected from former members of the judiciary, the magistry, retired public servants with a background in law and senior academics with legal training. In the case of members, nominations are sought from the principals and registrars of various tertiary institutions including universities, colleges of advanced education and TAFE institutions, and in relation to student members, from the Australian Union of Students.
(2) Chairmen and members of the Tribunals are expected to be conscious of the needs of students, to be impartial and to be wel1 informed on the provisions of the legislation under which the student assistance schemes operate.

3096 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Answers to Questions

(3) The Tribunal procedures are standard to the extent that they are required to follow the Student Assistance Act 1973 and regulations. For example, the Act provides that proceedings be conducted with as little formality and technicality and with as much expedition as possible and consistent with proper consideration of each appeal. The Tribunal is not bound by rules of evidence. Proceedings before a Tribunal are in public unless the Tribunal gives direction to the contrary. The actual form in which the hearing is conducted is, subject to the Act and regulations, at the discretion of the Chairman and members of the Tribunal. Generally, the appellant personally attends the hearing though he may, if the Tribunal thinks fit, be represented by another person not being a legal practitioner (and the appellant is on occasion accompanied by a member or members of his family). The officer of the Commonwealth Department of Education who was responsible for the decision which is the subject of appeal may be present or is represented.
Tribunal members are supplied with copies of the appellant's application for assistance and of correspondence exchanged with the Department of Education relating to the decision under review, prior to the hearing. An appellant may subsequently lodge a submission in writing to the Tribunal if he wishes. In most cases the hearing begins with the Chairman asking the appellant to give a brief account of his case and the officer of the Department of Education who made the decision, or his representative at the hearing, is invited to explain his decision. Tribunal members then follow up any matters which seem relevant in order to gain a clear understanding of the case prior to retiring to come to their decision.
Children's Services Program
(Question No. 2393)
Mr Armitage asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 3 June 1981:
(I) What are the full and precise details of each project approved under the Children's Services Program since January 1976.
(2) What funds have been approved for each of the projects.
(3) In which Electoral Division are each of these projects located.
Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
I regret to inform the honourable member that expenditure information is not compiled in my department in the form that he has requested, and that I am not prepared at this stage to allocate the considerable staffing resources that would be required to compile the data requested.
However, I intend to provide the honourable member with a preliminary listing by Federal Electorate of all services supported under the Children's Services Program which have been funded or approved for funding since 1978, excluding State pre-school and vacation care services. Pre-school and vacation care services are funded via block grant arrangements with the States.
This preliminary listing is still to be refined and therefore is not currently available for general circulation.
Commonwealth Development Bank
(Question No. 2462)
Mr Kerin asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 5 June 1981:

(I) Is it a fact that, in March 1981, he and the Prime Minister agreed to 'make available to the Commonwealth Development Bank an extra $20m; if so, why have the funds not been made available to the Bank.
(2) Has the Australian Loan Council rejected the Commonwealth Development Bank's latest application for permission to raise funds commercially; if so, on what grounds was the application rejected.
(3) What has been the monthly rate of lending from the Commonwealth Development Bank, in terms of the number of applications approved and the average loan amount, for 1980-81.
(4) What was the total number of applications received during the'same period.
(5) How many loan applications were (a) received and (b) approved during 1979-80 and what was the average loan sum.
(6) What level of funds does the Commonwealth Development Bank currently have available for lending and what is the source of these funds.
(7) What level of funds has the Bank had available for lending in each of the last 10 years and what was the source of these funds.
(8) Are nationality requirements imposed on individual borrowers or companies seeking finance from the Commonwealth Development Bank; if so, what are they.
Mr Howard-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) and (2) I announced in my statement to the House on 2 December 1980 on the subject of interest rates that the Government proposed to approach the Loan Council for approval to increase the borrowing capacity of the Commonwealth Development Bank for 1980-81 by $20m.1 referred to the matter again in answer to a question in the House on II March 1981.
In the event, the Government decided not to approach Loan Council for such an approval. This subsequent decision reflected our concern at the emerging implications of a rapidly expanding public sector borrowing requirement for pressures on financial markets and the general level of the interest rates. In those circumstances the Government decided that it would not be appropriate to support in Loan Council any additions to the 1980-81 borrowing programs of either Commonwealth or State authorities. However, I mention that, in accordance with Loan Council procedures, I approved the transfer of another Commonwealth authority'S unused 1980-81 borrowing program of $3m to the Commonwealth Development Bank.
(3), (4) and (5) Lending figures for 1980-81 as a whole are now available and these' are shown, together with those for 1979-80, in the following table:

Year

No. of Loan applications
Received Approved

In addition, the Development Bank approved 5,000 new equipment finance transactions in 1980-81 compared with 4,606 in 1979-80. Corresponding average transaction sizes were $12,977 and $12,310 respectively.
(6) and (7) The Commonwealth Development Bank has approval under Loan Council arrangements to raise $45.65m in 1981-82 ($17.0m new loan raising; $28.65m provision for

the operations of the Bank (in particular, loa!] repayments and retention of profits), together with usage of the Primary Industry Bank of Australia refinance facility, add significantly
to the Development Bank's capacity to lend. Some of these sources of funds are subject to seasonal industry fluctuations and are therefore difficult to quantify. The Bank has also
entered into an arrangement with the Commonwealth Savings Bank to obtain further funds from that Bank.

The various sources of funds available to the Development Bank should en<\ble it to maintain a lending program in 1981-82 that will at least match that achieved in 1980-81.

Base Rate Pension
(Question No. 2987)
Mrs Darling asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 9 September 1981:
(I) When will the base rate of pension exceed the tax free threshold under the present policy in respect of adjustments

to the tax free threshold, and twice yearly indexation of pensions,
(2) What"i~ the difference at present between the pension
and the tax free threshold.
Mr Howard-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) and (2) The maximum rate of single age pension from I November 1981 is $69.70 a week. This is equivalent to $3624 per annum, well below the maximum taxation threshold for 1981-82 of $4195. The Government has decided that future adjustments to the taxation scales will be made on a discretionary basis. In making those adjustments, the Government will bear in mind the position of those people whose sole source of income is social security payments.

(3) Will the Minister provide similar information in respect of carpal tunnel.

(I) Yes,

Parliamentary Liaison Officers under the Treasurer
(Question No. 3038)
Mr Les McMahon asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 9 September 1981:
How many Parliamentary Liaison Officer positions have existed in the Minister's Department and each statutory authority under the Minister's jurisdiction in each State, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory for each year from 1970 to 1981.
Mr Howard-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
During the period 1970-81, there has been one position of Parliamentary Liaison Officer in the Treasury, This position, which is located in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT), is currently classified at the Class 8 level. There are at present

Answers to Questions

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3099

six other clerical and clerical assistant positions in the Parliamentary Liais.on Sub-Section in the ACT, the occupants of which assist in the parliamentary liaison function to varying degrees.
There is no position on the establishment -of the Australian Taxation Office with the designation of Parliamentary Liaison Officer, nor is there a position the duties of which relate solely to that function. Since July 1981 there have been three positions of Advising Officer Grade I, Class 7 in the Policy and Legislation Division of the Australian Taxation Office which include as part of their duties a requirement to act as Parliamentary Liaison Officer. However, the occupant of only one of these positions carries out these duties at anr one time. Prior to July 1981 the role of Parliamentary LiaIson, Officer was included in the duties' of a single position of Advising Officer Grade I, Class 7, which was established in March 1973. Until this position was provided there was no position with specific responsibility for Parliamentary Liaison Officer duties.
There have been no positions in the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) formally designated as Parliamentary Liaison Officers from 1970 to 1981. Two ABS officers have been nominated for contact purposes as Parliamentary Liaison Officers and, in addition, three other ABS officers regularly have some involvement with Parliamentary liaison duties. For all five officers, Parliamentary liaison is only part of their total duties.
Kampuchea
(Question No. 3318)
Mr Fry asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 14 October 1981:
(I) Is he able to say approximately how many Kampucheans were killed by the forces of Pol Pot between the overthrow of Lon Nol and the establishment of the Heng Samrin regime.
(2) What approximate percentage of these casualities were Kampuchean civilians.
(3) Have any Australian citizens been killed by the Pol Pot forces since 1975; if so, how many.
(4) Is he able to say whether the Heng Samrin regime carried out any killings of Kampuchean civilians, if so, how many.
Mr Street-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) No reliable statistics are available and estimates vary widely. The best assessment we can make is that several hundred thousand people lost their lives under the Pol Pot regime. Many were executed while others died as a result of starvation.
(2) No estimate can be made.
(3) The Government is aware that two Australians, Mr Ronald Keith Dean and Mr David Lloyd Scott, are believed to have been killed by the Democratic Kampuchean authorities after their boat was intercepted off the Kampuchean coast in 1978.
(4) No information is available.
Victorian Transport System: Grant of Special Assistance
(Question No. 3340)
Mr Morris asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 15 September 1981:

(I) What criteria were used in the decision to grant the Victorian Government $35m special assistance for 1981-82 and 1982-83 for upgrading its transport system.
(2) To what specific projects are the funds to be applied.
(3) Was similar special assistance granted to any other State government for upgrading of its transport systems; if not, why not.
Mr Howard-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) The decision to grant the Victorian Government $35m special Commonwealth assistance for 1981-82 and 1982-83 for transport purposes was taken after consideration of a request by the Premier of Victoria which drew attention to, inter alia, the need for Victoria to upgrade its public transport system and the special additions to Loan Council borrowing programs approved in recent years for other States.
(2) The funds are to be applied at the discretion of the Victorian Government to transport expenditure.
(3) Commonwealth assistance has been provided to all States for the upgrading of urban public transport systems since 1973-74. In addition, several States-but not Victoriahave previously received special additions to their Loan Council borrowing programs in respect of expenditure on public transport. Examples include the special temporary addition to Western Australia's larger authorities program for the Kwinana-Koolyanobbing railway upgrading and the infrastructure borrowing programs approved for Brisbane Rail electrification and for New South Wales rail electrification projects.
Bank for Small Business Sector
(Question No. 3363)
Mr Humphreys asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 October 1981:
(I) Would the Government welcome proposals for the establishment of a bank which would cater expressly for the needs of the small business sector.
(2) Has the Government ever considered, or is it now considering, such a proposal.
(3) What is the nature of any proposal presently under consideration.
Mr Howard-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I), (2) and (3) There have been several recommendations to Government relating to institutional arrangements for the provision of equity and long-term finance for small business. In particular the Study Group on Structural Adjustment (the Crawford Committee) recommended in 1979 that consideration be given to arrangements for the provision of equity and long-term finance to small firms by either an extension of the powers of the Commonwealth Development Bank or a new specialised financing institution. The Government decided to refer that recommendation for consideration by the Inquiry into the Australian Financial System (the Campbell Committee) which had then been established. A number of submissions have been made to the Inquiry on this subject on behalf of the small business sector. Thefinal report of the Inquiry into the Australian Financial System has recently been released and the Government will give very careful consideration to its recommendations and findings including those relating to the needs of small busine~s.

3100 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Answers to Questions

Granny Bond Scheme (Questi~n No. 3369)"'" .
Mr Humphreys asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 20 October 1981:
(I) Is the Minister currently considering proposals to introduce a special Granny Bond Scheme to allow pensioners to protect their savings and still obtain pension fringe benefits.
(2) If so, will this proposal permit pensioners to qualify for a full pension and fringe benefits irrespective of income obtained from investments held in Granny Bonds.
Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(I) and (2) 'Granny Bonds' schemes are one possibility which will be considered by the Government as part of its ongoing review of retirement arrangements. No specific option, however, is under consideration at this stage.
Access to Satellite Photographs
(Question No. 3379)
Mr Lloyd asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 21 October 1981:
(I) Are any of the United States of America NOAA meteorological satellites orbiting the earth above Australia and sending photos back to the USA.
(2) Does Australia have access to these photos for either meteorological, agricultural or environmental purposes.
Mr Thomson-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes. NOAA-6and NOAA-7.
(2) Yes. The photographs are primarily for meteorological purposes but may have agricultural and environmental applications. The Bureau of Meteorology now usually relies on the Japanese Geostationary Satellite as its source of meteorological satellite pictures over Australia and adjacent oceans. However twice daily pictures are received from each of the NOAA-6 and NOAA-7 satellites and are of great value in preparing meteorological analyses over the southern ocean near the Antarctic continent and the central Indian Ocean.
Additional NOAA-6 and NOAA-7 pictures covering the remainder of the southern hemisphere are relayed to the Bureau via theU .S. GOES satellite and are used in preparing hemispheric weather maps. These maps are essential background to the Bureau in preparing its four day forecasts.
As well as pictures, information on upper atmosphere temperature is received from the US. satellites via meteorological telecommunications links from Washington and, more recently, from a direct reception station in Melbourne.
Englisb as a Second Language: Courses at Rivett Primary School
(Question No. 3570)
Mr Young asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:
(I) Will English as a Second Language (E.S.L.) courses at the Rivett Primary School, Australian Capital Territory, be discontinued; if so, what alternatives are being proposed.
(2) How many pupils are in need of E.S.L. education in the Rivett area.

(3) How many students and teachers were there in E.S.L. classes at Rivett in (a) 1978 and (b) 1979-80.
(4) Did the Chairman of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority in a meeting with the Rivett Primary School Board suggest they use political means to achieve solutions to Rivett Primary School needs, as the Schools Authority could operate only within Government staff ceilings and that the most politically sensible and best defined target would be the E.S. L. provision.
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) No.
(2) The verified number of E.S.L. students currently attending Rivett Primary School is 74.
(3) 1978-no students identified; 1979-40 students I teacher; 1980-50 students 1.4 teachers.
(4) I understand that a delegation from the Rivett Primary School Board, who met with the Chairman of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority on 14 September 1981 has attributed such a statement to him. They met to discuss demands for staff additional to the school's entitlement generated by the staffing formula including provisions for E.S.L.
I have been informed that the Chairman advised the delegation that as a government agency the Authority must work within resources made available to it by the Government. He indicated that he could not foresee the Authority's giving priority to the claimed needs of the school over other needs of the Australian Capital Territory government school system. Other than by successful appeal direct to the Government by the school community he could not see how the Authority could be in a position to provide additional resources to the school beyond the currently prescribed formula.

Parliamentary Liaison Officers: Department of Housing and Construction
(Question No. 3046)
Mr Les McMahon asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 9 September 1981:
How many Parliamentary Liaison Officer positions have existed in the Minister's Department and each statutory authority under the Minister's jurisdiction in each State, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory for each yearfrom 1970 to 1981.
Mr McVeigh-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
Since 1970, there has been one position formally nominated as Parliamentary Liaison Officer in the Department of Housing and Construction, or in each of its antecedent departments.
In addition, the parliamentary section of the Department currently has one other position engaged full time in parliamentary liaison duties.
No similar positions have been identified in the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation or the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation, nor in the Department's Regional Offices in the State or Territories. All parliamentary liaison activities are undertaken through the Central Office position.
Kakadu National Park
(Question No. 3310)
Mr Holding asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 14 October 1981:
(1) Is it a fact that traditional Aboriginal owners of land within the Kakadu National Park entered into an agreement with the Commonwealth for the operation of the Park and that leases were entered into between the Directors of the National Parks and Wildlife Service and Kakadu Aboriginal Land Trust under the terms of which the Director specifically agreed not to make any arrangements with the Government of a State for the performance of functions within the Park without the approval in writing of the Northern Land Council (NLC).
(2) Is the Public Service Board now endeavouring to implement the directions of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions (RCF) in order to hand over the effective administration of the Park to the Northern Territory contrary to specific legal agreements signed by the Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service on behalf of the Commonwealth.

Answers to Questions

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3103

(3) Was the RCF statement made without any consultation with or approval of traditional owners or the NLC.
(4) Is he concerned that the breaches of both the spirit and terms of the leases signed represents a new low in Government-Aboriginal relations; if so, will he now undertake to declare to the House that the Government will stand by the leases entered into by the Director on its behalf.
Mr Wilson-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) The terms under which Aboriginal land in the Alligator Rivers Region of the Northern Territory became part of Kakadu National Park are set down in an Agreement between the Northern Land Council (NLC) and the Director, National Parks and Wildlife (NPW), and three leases made by the Kakadu Aboriginal Land Trust to the Director, NPW.
The Agreement with the Northern Land Council states at paragraph 3:
The Director agrees that he shall not, without the prior written consent of the N LC, make any arrangements under section 36 of the Parks Act for the performance of functions or the exercise of powers under that Act in relation to the said lands except arrangements for the performance of functions and the exercise of powers in relation to the said lands by officers or employees of the Northern Territory Parks and Wildlife Commission who are responsible to the Director and under the direct supervision of officers or employees of the National Parks and Wildlife Service who are resident on the said lands.'
(2) The Government has made clear that the Agreement made with the NLC will be honoured. No action is being taken which would be contrary to that Agreement.
(3) Yes. I wrote to the Chairman of the NLC advising him of the Government's RCF decisions on 28 May 1981.
(4) See 2. No breach of the spirit or terms of the leases has occurred.
Interscan Systems
(Question No. 3452)
Mr Barry Jones asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 28 October 1981:
(1) How many Interscan systems, the sophisticated electronic guidance system devised by CSIRO, have been (a) ordered or (b) installed and where is each located or to be located.
(2) What firms are manufacturing and/or assembling the elements which comprise lnterscan.
(3) What proportion of manufacturing or assembling capacity for lnterscan is in Australia.
(4) What royalty is payable to CSIRO in respect of Interscan and what sum has actually been paid.
Mr Thomson-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
I (a) No Interscan system has been ordered.
I (b) A demonstration prototype has been installed at Richard Gebauer Airfield near Kansas City, in America.
(2) Four firms have been involved in the Australian development program. They are:
(a) lnterscan Australia Pty Ltd, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Australian Industrial Development Corporation (AIDC);
(b) Amalgamated Wireless Australia Ltd; (c) Hawker de Havilland Ltd; and

(d) Wilcox Electric Inc, an American company.
(3) The production of Interscan is intended to be divided equally between Australia and America.
(4) No royalty is payable to CSIRO in respect of Interscan-the commercially significant patents have been transferred to the AI DC subsidiary company, lnterscan Australia through which royalty benefits will be achieved.
No royalty payments are due in respect of the Interscan technology.
