Customs and Quarantine Passenger Statement Form
(Question No. 1690)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:
(I) When was the Australian customs and quarantine passenger statement form last reviewed.
(2) When next being reviewed will he consider including in the quarantine declaration specific reference to (a) rocks and sand, (b) herbs and spices, (c) vegetables, (d) wool and horns and (e) native artifacts.
Mr MacKellar-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) I am advised that arrangements are in hand for the AustralianCustoms/Quarantine passenger statement form to be printed following a revision completed late last year. It is intended that the revised form be printed in a number of languages.
(2) The proposed quarantine wording on the revised form is as follows:
'During the past three months have you while overseas
visited a place where farm animals are kept including farming communities, research farms, sanctuaries and saleyards
visited an abattoir or meat packing place.
Do you have in your possession or in the baggage accompanyingyou
FOOD OF ANY KIND (including tinned or packaged), including meat, sausages, salami, ham, poultry, fats, eggs, milk, baby food, butter and cheese.

3104 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Answers to Questions

PLANTS or parts of plants, live or dead, including Fruits, nuts, seeds, bulbs, flowers, mushrooms, straw, bamboo, wooden articles or articles made of plant material.
ANIMALS, reptiles, fish, birds or insects (or parts thereof) alive, dead, stuffed or mounted
ANIMAL PRODUCTS, including semen, feathers, hair, skins, shells and hatching eggs
EQUIPMENT used with horses or other animals BIOLOGICAL SPECIMENS, including vaccines, cultures and blood SOIL'
Although specific reference to herbs and spices was not included on the revised declaration it is considered that the question relating to 'plants or parts of plants, live and dead' would be normally interpreted to include these items.
Vegetables have not been specifically included on the declaration but consideration will be giv!(n to including them as a separate category when the declaration is next revised.
Rocks and sand are not significant quarantine risks and therefore have not been included.
Space limitations on the form preclude reference to all specific items of quarantine concern.
Quarantine: Foot and Mouth Disease
(Question No. 1694)
Mr Bungey asked the Ministe~ for Health, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:
Following the announcement by New Zealand of an infection in pigs which could be foot and mouth disease, were any Australian veterinary officers or quarantine officials sent to New Zealand to assess New Zealand's quarantine action; if not, why not; if so, who was sent and what deficiencies did they detect in the New Zealand procedures and measures.
Mr MacKellar-The answer to be the honourable member's question is as follows:
A quarantine veterinary officer was not sent to New Zealand until after the completion of all diagnostic tests and New Zealand had completed its investigation into the incident.
However, a Quarantine Veterinary Officer, Mr K. J. Dunn did visit New Zealand on 4-8 May 1981, after the ending of the emergency, to review quarantine procedures and measures which had been adopted in New Zealand in relation to their effect on Australia.
No deficiencies were detected.
Dialysis Treatment
(Question No. 2037)
Mr Milton asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 5 May 1981:
(I) Are shortages of staff and Facilities in Victorian hospitals threatening dialysis treatment for those who need it.
(2) Is it a fact that patients over 60 years of age may be refused treatment.
(3) If so, will he take action to prevent this life-saving treatment from being curtailed.
Mr MacKellar-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I), (2) and (3) Under the new health funding arrangements, the Commonwealth provides funding to Victoria for the operating costs of public hospitals, services previously

funded under the Community Health Program and the School Dental Scheme through general revenue grants at the level of funding provided in 1980-81, plus ten per cent, less a share of the revenue-that Victoria can reasonably be expected to raise by the introduction of appropriate inpatient and outpatient charges from I September 1981, having regard to the new health insurance arrangements that came into operation on that date.
With the revenue increase arising from increased hospital charges, Victoria will have at its disposal increased resources in 1981-82. The Commonwealth is not involved in any decision as to how these resources should be allocated by a State. The matter of priorities is entirely one for Victoria.
Therefore, the Victorian Government has the responsibility to determine its own priorities in the delivery of health care and to allocate funds to individual hospitals and related health services in accordance with those priorities. In this context, consideration of the need for additional staff and Facilities for renal dialysis patients in Victoria is a matter solely for the Victorian Government.

Health Insurance Industry
(Question No. 2702)
Dr Klugman asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:
Has his attention been drawn to the statements by Mr David Gadiel of the H.C.F. Sydney, as reported on page 155 of the 'Proceedings of the Second Australian Conference of Health Economists', that (a) a major component of the health insurance industry is in fact insolvent, (b) actual evidence suggests that reserves and provisions need to approximate a minimum of 43 per cent of break-even contribution income to meet liabilities and a solvency margin, (c) there were 12 open funds whose reserves were less than 20 per cent of their breakeven contribution income on 30 June 1979 and (d) there are a further 8 funds including the fourth largest fund in New South Wales and the third largest fund in Victoria whose reserves and provisions are 20-30 per cent of income and which must be regarded as fairly shaky; if so, is there any substance to these statements.
Mr MacKellar-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
At the outset, it should be made clear that in suggesting that a major component of the health insurance industry was 'technically insolvent', to use his words, Mr Gadiel was not implying that organisati<;lI1s were unable to pay contributors' claims and other debts. Clearly. this was not the case. There is a practical difference between a test of technical solvency COIlsidered by Mr Gadiel to be desirable and the ability of funds,

3106 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Answers to Questions

by having.a surplus of assets, to meet claims and other liabilities as they fall due. His test of solvency w~.sthat combined reserves and provisions should be equivalen't"io not less than 43
per cent of break-even contribution incollie in order to meet liabilities and to provide a 'solvency margin '.

With regard to the reserves component, under present
Government policy a level of about two months of break-even
contribution income is considered appropriate for large organisations and about four months for small organisations. These levels alone are equivalent to about 16 per cent of break-even
contributions for large funds and 33 per cent for small funds. In arriving at these ratios, the Government struck a balance between the needs of financial viability and of not placing an unnecessary burden on contributors.

The other component within the 43 per cent mentioned
above is the level of provisions for liabilities. These provisions are primarily a matter for determination by each organisation
by reference to the estimated level of outstanding claims, long
service leave commitments and other liabilities for which provision should be made. For example, organisations with relatively high incidences of claims should raise higher provisions
for outstanding claims than organisations with lower claiming experiences.

In the circumstances, therefore whilst a combined reserves

and provisions figure of 43 per cent might be apprepriate for

some organisations, it cannot be said that such a level is

necessarily appropriate fo. all organisations registered under

the National Health Act.

.

In conclusion, I might mention that preliminary unaudited data for the year ended 30 June 1981 indicate that, in general,
the financial stiuation of organisations is stronger than in the
year ended 30 June 1979, the period to which Mr Gadiel's remarks related. In considering proposals for contribution rates from I September 1981, the Registration Committee, so far as it was possible to do so, satisfied itself about the adequacy of
provisions and that, where necessary, the rates would achieve within a reasonable time an appropriate level of reserves.

Concessional Book Post Rate

(Q"estion No. 2708)

Mr Barry Jones asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:

(I) How many countries'within the Universal Postal Union (a) grant and (b) do not grant, special rates for book post.

(2) Which countries do not grant special rates.

(3) Does Australia offer a concessional book post rate; if not, why not, when its problem of communications within a widely-spaced population is one of the most extreme on earth.

(4) Will he undertake to pursue with the Government the
making of a grant to Australia Post sufficient to compensate it for the introduction of a concessional post for books.

(5) Is there any substance to the recent statement of

Australia Post that a special book post was introduced in the

Australian colonies in the 19th Century when there was a real

need to assist and encourage the dissemination of news and in-

formation, and to develop greater literacy in the Australian

community, but these purposes have largely lost relevance in

today's environment.

.

Mr Sinclair~The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(1) (a) and (b) Australia Post has no information as to
which of the 164 member countries of the Universal Postal Union (UPU) grant or do not grant special postal charges for the transmission of books in the domestic post.

For the international post, UPU legislation provides for rates of postage, which are somewhat lower than the charges

for letters, to be applied to printed papers, including books. (All member countries of the UPU are bound to adhere to UPU legislation and, consequently, all members of the Union provide a reduced rate service for printed papers, including books, sent in the international post.)
(2) See (1) above.
(3) No. Under the terms of the Postal Services Act 1975, Australia Post is required to price its services to recover operating costs and to provide at least 50 per cent of its capital expenditure from revenue. Australia Post has received numerous requests for a postal concession for books. Australia Post's decision not to provide such a concession is based on the adverse effect on postal revenue which would result, and which could require other postal users to pay higher postage charges than would otherwise apply.
Moreover, Australia Post receives many requests for postal concessions of various types. It would be inappropriate to provide a concession tor books while denying similar concessions to other groups/organisations which may consider themselves to be no less entitled to such concessions.
(4) No. The introduction of such a grant would be inconsistent with the Government's policy of restraining outlays in the public sector. Book distributors may avail themselves of existing concessional postage rates by using local delivery mail and bulk presented mail services.
(5) The statement referred to was included in a letter from the Managing Director of Australia Post to Mr Zifcak of the National Book Council written some four years ago. Australia Post maintains that the statements made in that letter still hold true today.
Australian Capital Territory: Indigenous Population
(Question No. 2833)
Mr Hayden asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 26 August 1981:
(1) Further to his answer to question No.2 (Hansard, 28 May 1981, page 2849). on what date and in what. form did each State and the Northern Territory make known its view that its Aboriginal population was not an indigenous population within the meaning of International Labour Organisation Convention No. 65-Penal Sanctions (Indigenous Workers),1939.
(2) Is the Aboriginal population of the Australian Capital Territory an indigenous population within the meaning of the convention.
(3) Is it a fact, as expressed by a former Minister for Industrial Relations (Hansard, 23 February 1977, page 405), that the convention deals with indigenous workers/populations.
(4) On what date did a review of unratified conventions by his Department reveal the existence of a number of provisions in the legislation of New South Wales, Queensland, the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory which were inconsistent with the convention (Hansard, 4 October 1977, page 1607, Question No. 874).
(5) Is he able to say whether Victoria still agrees that the convention should be ratified (Hansard, 9 October 1979, page 1805, Question No. 4404).
(6) Have officers of his Department had discussions concerning the convention with the International Labour Office as they had concerning Convention No. 107-Indigenous and Tribal Populations 1957 (Hansard, 19 November 1968, page 3007, Question No. 768; 24 April 1971, page 2122, Question No. 29(;9; 31 May 1972, page 3408, Question No. 4975; 24 October 1972, page 3110, Question No. 6219); if so, what was the date and outcome of the latest discussion.

member's question is as follows:

(2) This question is being examined.
(3) Convention No. 65-Penal Sanctions (Indigenous Workers) 1936, applies to all contracts by which a worker belonging to or assimilated to the indigenous population of a dependent territory of a Member of the Organisation (lLO) or belonging to or assimilated to the dependent indigenous popUc lation of the home territory of a Member of the Organisation, enters the service of any public authority, individual, company or association, whether non-indigenous or indigenous, for remuneration in cash or in any other form whatsoever.
(4) The review of Convention No. 65 was conducted by my Department in 1977.
(5) The Government has not been advised of any change of view by the Victorian Government.
(6) The Department has not had any detailed formal dis~ cussions with the International Labour Office concerning Convention No. 65 as the impediments to its ratification have been clear.

Construction Industry
(Question No. 2960)
Mr Barry Jones asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 20 October 1981:
(I) Is it a fact that the total annual output of the construction sector in Australia is approximately $16,000 million; if so, is this equal to the combined value of agriculture and mining.
(2) Is it also a fact that total building and construction research, including private, government and industry, amounts to only 0.2 per cent of the total value of output.
(3) Does the CSIRO Division of Building Research deal with approximately 40,000 inquiries each year and does it make a very valuable contribution to standards in the construction industry.
(4) Does the Government propose to cut back the provisions of building advice as an economy measure.
(5) If so, what sum is expected to be saved by this cutback.
(6) Will the Government reconsider this decision.
Mr Thomson-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) The value of output of the Australian construction sector obviously depends on the definitions chosen for both 'output' and 'construction sector'. The figure for output can vary

widely with the definitions chosen. I am aware that an estimate of $16,000 mi!lion in 1978-79 has recently been mentioned. This has been on an extrapolation of figures in the Australian Bureau of Statistics publication 'Australian National Accounts: Input-Output Tables 1974-75'. There are other ways of measuring output, and I would suggest that the most authoritative, widely accepted, and widely used figures are those published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in 'Australian National Accounts: National Income and Expenditure'. The most recently published (1981) edition of these national accounts gives a provisional figure for 1978-79 (latest available year) for gross domestic product at market prices of the construction industry, of$7,053 million.
The corresponding figures for agriculture (including forestery, fishing and hunting), and mining, are $6,481 million and $5,363 million respectively. These together total $12,204 million, or some 73 per cent more than the construction industry.
(2) The most reliable source of figures on research expenditure in Australia is 'Project SCORE, Research and Development in Australia'. The most recently available, complete figures in this series are for 1976-77, produced by the then Department of Science and the Environment. These show that total funding of reseach and development in the objective category of 'Construction' for that year was $8.089 million. This was 0.13 per cent of gross domestic product at market prices of the construction industry in that year. It should be noted that the level of indigenous Rand D does not depend only on the economic importance of the sector. Research intensity opportunities for research, and use of overseas technology rather than indigenous research, must also be taken into account.
(3) No strict account of the number of inquiries received by the Division of Building Research is kept. The Division has, however, estimated that it has dealt with about 40,000 inquiries per year in each of the last few years. About twenty officers of the Division are involved in standards activities; this includes regular meetings with committees of the Standards Association of Australia to develop standards in the areas of building and construction, and the publication and implementation of some of the Division's research results as standards.
(4) The Government has no plans to cut back the provision of building advice as an economy measure. The Division of Building Research has itself recently decided to close its own Consumer Information Service in recognition of other services now available, but it is expanding its Industry Liaison Service for architects, engineers, builders and other members of the building industry and allied trades.
(5) No estimate is available of the savings to the Division of the termination of the Consumer Information Service, as it occurred at the same time as other organizational rearrangements in the Division, most significantly the expansion of its Industry Liaison Service.
(6) As noted in (4) above, this was a decision not of the Government but of the Division of Building Research in response to its own perception of its priorities within the overall resource allocation for the Division determined by the CSIRO Executive and the Institute ofIndustrial Technology.

Parliamentary Liaison Officers under the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs

(Question No. 3043)

Mr Les McMahon asked the Minister for Em-

ployment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, an 9

September 1981:

.

How many Parliamentary Liaison Officer positions have
existed in the Minister's Department and each Statutory Authority under the Minister's jurisdiction in each State, the

3108 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Answers to Questions

Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory for each year from 1970 to 1981.
Mr N. A. Brown-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
No full time position of Parliamentary Liaison Officier exists or has existed in the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs since it was established in December 1978. However, one position in the Department's Central Office in Canberra has been nominated to carry out Parliamentary Liaison Officer duties together with other duties. That position is supported by four other positions which, similarly, are engaged on parliamentary liaison duties on a part time basis.
Disabled Persons: Use of and Access to Commonwealth Buildings
(Question No. 3059)
Mr Les McMahon asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 9 September 1981:
(I) Further to his answer to Question No. 901 (Hansard. 2 April 1981, page 1340) what is the progress to date on each of the 3 projects listed for modification to improve access by disabled persons.
(2) In regard to the modifications to the Commonwealth Centre, Chifly Square, New South Wales, what is the cost of the (a) new automatic sliding door entry, (b) new taps, (c) modification to cafeteria food race and (d) disabled persons toilet.
(3) Where are the new taps to be installed in the Commonwealth Centre and how are these intended to assist the disabled.
(4) Have any additional buildings in Sydney been identified as providing facilities for access for the disabled.
(5) Does Australia House, Sydney, have ready access for the disabled; if so, why was it not listed in part (I) of his answer; if not, why is a disabled person's toilet being installed inside Australia House.
Mr McVeigh-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Progress to date on each of the three projects listed in answer to part (2) of Question No. 90 I, is as follows:
(a) Australia House, Sydney-unisex disabled persons toilet-work completed.
(b) Commonwealth Centre, Chifley Square, Sydneynew automatic sliding door entry, new taps, modification to cafeteria food race, lower public telephone shelf-work completed. It was not possible to include the disabled persons toilet in the 1980-81 modification program, but it is now intended to execute the work as part of the 1981-82 modification program.
(c) 5-7 Hickson Road, Circular Quay-disabled persons toilet-work completed.
(2) The costs of the items listed are:
(a) New automatic sliding door entry-$4,435.
(b) New taps-$5,030.
(c) Modification to cafeteria food race-$I ,274.
(d) Disabled persons toilet-estimated $10,000.
(3) A modified tap was installed over one hand-basin in each of the male and female washrooms on each floor. The modified taps enable easier use by all people, especially disabled people.

(4) No additional Commonwealth buildings in Sydney have been identified as providing facilities for access for the disabled.
(5) Australia House, Sydney does have ready access for disabled people, as one entrance to the building is at street level.
As Australia House was included in part (2) of the answer to Question No. 901 as being modified to provide access, it was not listed in part (I) of the answer to that question.
Sale and Supply of Oxygen to Patients
(Question No. 3067)
Dr Blewett asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 September 1981:
(I) What are the procedures covering the sale and supply of oxygen to patients in nursing homes and outside approved hospitals.
(2) Who are the major suppliers of oxygen.
(3) Can patients requiring oxygen for medical reasons become dependent on oxygen.
(4) Has any investigation been made of the possibility of all distribution of oxygen outside approved hospitals being placed under the control of a hospital.
Mr MacKellar-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) I understand that the sale and supply of oxygen to patients outside recognised hospitals throughout Australia is generally dependent upon such medical requirements being either initiated or confirmed by at least a general practitioner. In nursing homes, the supply of oxygen to patients is either initiated by their own doctor or the nursing home staff. I am not aware of the existence of any State legislation or regulations controlling the supply of oxygen to patients in the above categories.
(2) The major suppliers in Australia of oxygen for medical purposes are Commonwealth Industrial Gases Ltd (C.LG.) and Liquid Air Australia Ltd.
(3) Yes. It is possible for patients requiring oxygen for medical purposes to become psychologically or physiologically dependent on its use.
(4) No.
Norfolk Island Airport
(Question No. 3126)
Mr Humphreys asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 16 September 1981:
(I) Is it a fact that the approval of funds for the upgrading of Norfolk Island Airport facilities was to be subject to controls being negotiated between the Norfolk Island and the Australian Governments over frequency of /lights and size of aircraft to be used.
(2) Is work due to commence in late 1981.
(3) Did the Norfolk Island Select Committee Report on Tourism of May 1981 state that the controls referred to in part (I) have not yet been negotiated.
Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) and (3). No. The Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works in its report, recommended that the Australian and Norfolk Island Governments should negotiate to ensure that controls of tourism, transit air passengers, airline

Answers to Questions

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3109

schedules and types of aircraft using the Norfolk Island Aerodrome are effective in preserving the Norfolk Island environment and economy.
In accord with the recommendation, I have reached agreement with the Norfolk Island Minister for Resources and Planning that there will be consultation with the Norfolk Island Government when a request is made which could have a major effect upon the provision of air services to Norfolk Island.
(2) Work on the aerodrome is expected to commence early in 1982.
Anencephalix
(Question No. 3220)
Dr Blewett asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 23 September 1981 :
(I) How many cases of anencephalix were reported in each Canberra hospital in each month during 1980.
(2) If there were any noticeable variations in the pattern of reported cases has any investigation been made by health authorities as to its cause.
(3) What studies are made of each anencephali x episode.
Mr MacKellar-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) During 1980 Royal Canberra Hospital reported one case of anencephalus in January. Woden Valley Hospital reported a total of three cases-in March, April and September of 1980. No cases were reported in Calvary Hospital.
(2) and (3) The Capital Territory Health Commission's Maternal, Perinatal and Infant Mortality and Morbidity Committee routinely monitors incidence of birth defects. Statistics of anencephalus in the Australian Capital Territory are shown in the table below. Fluctuations in the numbers of deaths are to be expected where small numbers are involved.

Because the occurrence of four cases in 1980 was not unusual, no special investigations were made.

Brisbane Airpo'rt: Re-Iocation
(Question No. 3287)
Mrs Darling asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:
(I) Where will the proposed flight paths of the Brisbane Airport be following the re-Iocation of the airport in 1986,
(2) What will be the noise exposure forecasts for lands adjacent to the new airport in respect of these flight paths.
(3) In particular, what is the expected noise level for residents of (a) Nudgee Beach, (b) Shorncliffe, (c) Sandgate, (d) Brighton and (e) Nudgee,
(4) Will the proposed cross-wind runway be used only when weather conditions do not permit landing or take off on the main runway,
(5) Will the proposed cross-wind runway be restricted to general aviation use only.
(6) Will the cross runway on the existing Eagle Farm Airport site be used for air traffic following completion of the redeveloped airport; if so, for what purpose,
(7) What recreational uses will be made of Commonwealth Government land adjacent to the redevelpped airport site.
(8) Will he ensure that whatever increase in inconvenience caused by higher noise exposure from the new airport is suffered by Nudgee Beach residents is offset by extensive recreational use of land adjacent to the airport.
(9) In relation to runway 02/20, on present indications, what percentage of (a) take offs and (b) landings at the new airport will take place over Moreton Bay.
(10) In relation to the proposed cross-wind runway 14/32, on present indications what percentage of (a) take offs and (b) landings will take place over Bramble Bay.
(II) At what stage is the Government's proposal to build a widely spaced parallel runway on the redeveloped airport site and where will the runway be located in relation to the main runway 02/20.
Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) There are two aspects of the flight paths at the redeveloped Brisbane Airport; firstly the number and type of aircraft using each runway and secondly the flight paths followed by each aircraft from the runway to the inbound or outbound route. The following table shows the expected proportion of all aircraft types using each run)Vay at the redeveloped airport.

Owing to the differing characteristics of the two runways,
only aircraft about the size of an F27 or smaller, can use the cross-wind runway on a regular basis, while all types of aircraft can use the major runway. The exact fdaght paths that aircraft will follow between the runway and the inbound and
outbound routes have not yet been determined.

(2) The noise exposure forecast (NEF) for lands adjacent to the redeveloped Brisbane Airport is depicted in Drawing No.3 to the Department of Transport's Statement of Evidence to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for the Redevelopment of Brisbane International Airport-Further Dredging and Reclamation. This evidence was submitted to the Committee on 2 September. Land within the 25 NEF zone is limited to areas of the suburbs of Meandah, Pinkemba, Myrtletown and Cribb Island, A total of 41 existing houses in Pinkemba and Myrtletown will be within the forecast areas.
(3) Nudgee Beach, Shorncliffe, Sandgate, Brighton and Nudgee are all well outside the 25 NEF zone, Typical estimated maximum noise levels at any of those locations would not exceed 75 decibels (a weighted peak noise level). These noise levels would be produced from possible overflight by propeller-driven aircraft up to Fokker F27 size, either approaching on base leg to, or on setting course after taking off from the proposed cross-wind 14/32 runway.
(4) No. The cross runway will be available at all times,
(5) No. However, the proposed length and strength of the runway will prevent its use by current airline aircraft larger than the F27.
(6) No, The existing runways will be closed on commissioning of the redevelopment airport.
(7) The Commonwealth land and waterway comprising the flood way on the western side of the airport are the only areas being considered for recreational use. The Joint Government Co-ordinating Committee is currently considering the development constraints and types of activities which will not impair the prime function of the area as a floodway and not affect the operation of the airport.
(8) Aircraft noise exposure to Nudgee Beach residents is likely to be minimal. Apart from the powers available under Building Height Control Regulations the Commonwealth has no powers over land outside the Commonwealth's acquisition boundary. The Commonwealth has no objection in principle to recreational use of the flood way, subject to the' conditions mentioned in (7).
(9) The proportion of total movements over Morlon Bay is given in the answer to part (I) of this question; aircraft landing on runway 20 and laking off from runway 02 pass over Moreton Bay.
(10) The proportion of lhe lotal movements over Bramble Bay is given in lhe answer to part (I) of this question; aircraft landing on runway 14 and taking off from runway 32 pass over Bramble Bay.
(II) The Government has no current proposal to build a widely spaced parallel runway, Planning for the development of the site allows for the construction of a runway 2000 metres to the west of the initial 02/20 runway. On current forecasts the construction of a limited length runway suitable for the smaller general aviation aircraft may be required in the mid-I 990s.
Commonwealth Road Grants
(Question No. 3337)
Mr Morris asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 15 October 1981:
(I) What was the projected increase in road construction costs made by the Government at the commencement of each year from 1976-77 to 1981-82.
(2) What was the actual increase in road construction costs, as measured by the Government index for each year from 1976-77 to 1980-81.

Answers to Questions

18 November 19&1 REPRESENTATIVES 3111

(3) What was the percentage real change in Commonwealth road grants to the Stafes and the Northern Territory, for each year from 1976-77 to 1980-81, using the actual increase in road construction costs referred to in part (2).
Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) The Government has not had available to it annual forecasts relating specifically to movements in road construction costs. In the years (i.e. 1978-79,1979-80 and 1980-81) where the level of Commonwealth roads grants was fixed with a view to maintaining the level of expenditure in real terms,

the grants have been adjusted in line with forecast movements in the implicit price deflator for gross fixed capital expenditure on private non-dwelling construction. This index was considered to provide a reasonable approximation of cost movements in the road construction sector (see also answer to Question No. 3338) but makes no allowance for productivity growth or changing profit margins.

Road Construction Costs
(Question No. 3338)
Mr Morris asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 15 October 1981:
(I) For which years has the Government used the implicit price deflator of gross fixed capital expenditure on private non-dwelling construction to measure road construction cost increases.
(2) Is it a fact that this index does not include provision for bitumen prices; if so, what is the rationale for using the index and not another more appropriate index.
(3) For what period does the Government intend to use this index.
Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) In each of the years 1978-79, 1979-80 and 1980-81, the Commonwealth used forecast movements in the implicit price deflator for gross fixed capital expenditure on private nondwelling construction as the basis for adjusting the overall level of Commonwealth roads grants.
(2) The deflator referred to in (I) above does not include provision for bitumen prices. The Government saw the need to adopt an index for which up to date forecasts would be readily available in the annual budgetary context. In the five year period prior to 1978-79 movements in the deflator for private non-dwelling construction had closely approximated movements in other indexes designed to specifically measure historical changes in road construction costs (e.g. State Road Authority indexes).
(3) The Government has announced levels of assistance to the States and Northern Territory for roads for the period 1981-82 to 1984-85. These amounts were determined after taking account of a range of factors including the likely effect of the Government's economic policies on the general rate of

inflation. The Government has provided no undertaking to further adjust the grants according to movements in any index.
Qantas Services via Damascus
(Question No. 3433)
Mr Jull asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 28 October 1981:
(I) How many Qantas services operate from (a) Australia to Europe and (b) Europe to Australia, via Damascus, weekly.
(2) How many passengers terminating in Damascus in each direction were carried by Qantas during 1980.
(3) How much freight destined for Damascus was carried in each direction by Qantas 10'1980.
Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Qantas operates one service per week from Australia to Europe via Damascus and one service per week from Europe to Australia via Damascus.
(2) In 1980 Qantas carried 687 passengers from Australia to Damascus and 956 passengers from Damascus to Australia.
(3) In 1980 Qantas carried two tonnes of freight from Australia to Damascus and three tonnes of freight from Damascus to Australia.
National Highway between Newman and Port Hedland, Western Australia
(Question No. 3436)
Mr Campbell asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 28 October 1981:

3112 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Answers to Questions

(I) With reference to his declaration document NH 6-8 declaring the national highway route in Western Austraia, including a zone of study between Newman and Port Hedland, to select the ultimate route for its national highway between the two centres, does the study rule out the existing alignment.
(2) What is the difference in distance and cost between the existing alignment and the proposed route.
(3) What is the latest estimated time of construction.
(4) When is it now proposed to start construction of the highway.
Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) No. The alternative routes which have been agreed by the Commonwealth and Western Australia for the study include the existing route via Marble Bar.
(2), (3) and (4) This study is in progress and is due to be completed by the end of March 1982. Consequently, it is too early to provide information on the lengths and costs of alternative routes and no decision has been made on the proposed route for the National Highway or on the timing for the commencement or duration of its construction.

Alice Springs-Darwin Railway Construction Project
(Question No. 3515)
Mr Morris asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:
(I) In relation to Division 655, Sub-Division 3, Item 12, of the estimates of expenditure for his Department for 1981-82 explanatory notes, what progress has been made in the (a) route identification survey, (b) detail design and (c) preparation of cost estimates being undertaken by the Australian National Railways Commission in respect of the Alice Springs-Darwin railway construction project.
(2) What specific information is he able to provide on the results of any cost efficiency studies for that may have been carried out on this project.
Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) As previously announced the Government has committed $IOm for preliminary planning and design work for the Alice Springs to Darwin railway project. $280,000 was provided in 1980-81 and $3m is to be provided in 1981-82. It is an- .ticipated that sufficient planning work will be completed for the Government to consider construction 'options by the end

of 1982. At this stage work is concentrating on route identification.
Aerial photography and mapping is complete for the section Katherine to Darwin. Aerial photography is complete for the section Alice Springs to Tennant Creek. Detailed ground survey is underway for the section Alice Springs to Bond Springs.
(2) The report of the Joint Commonwealth/Northern Territory study on the feasibility of constructing the rail link was released last year.
Apart from economic considerations, the report emphasised the defence, social and developmental aspects of the railway.
Sale of International Airline Tickets
(Question No. 3619)
Mr Morris asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:
(I) What consideration has his Department given to prohibiting the sale of international airline tickets which do not clearly indicate conditions and restrictions governing travel on the ticket.
(2) What action is he able to take to ensure that all restrictions attaching to airline travel being sold are clearly shown on the ticket at the time of sale.
Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) and (2) In developing its aviation policy the Government has attempted to create an environment responsive to the needs of both consumers and carriers. The basic aim of the

Answers to Questions

18 November 19&1 REPRESENTATIVES 3113

policy has been to encourage airlines to provide a comprehensive range of cost related fare and rate types to be available on a non-discriminatory basis. In accordance with this policy, and with the agreement of our bilateral partners, the airlines introduced on our major routes a ra'nge of fare types designed to cater for the different sections of the travel market. The fares normally range from the flexible on-demand types to which very few conditions attach (First Class, Sleeper, Business Class, Economy) through to the low cost promotional fare types involving more restrictive ticket conditions (Excursion Fares, Advance Purchase Fares, Group Inclusive Fares).
With respect to the promotional fare types, the Government, in co-operation with our bilateral partners, Quntas and the designated carriers of the countries involved, have developed arrangements to ensure that intending passengersare adequately advised of important fare conditions that may afl'ect their travel plans. Any advertising of advafwe purchase fares, for example, must include as a minimum requirement a statement of the advance purchase period and the fact that a cancellation penalty applies. Further, it is an important ticket requirement that passengers intending to buy advance purchase fares must not only be advised of the cancellation/refund conditions by the airline/travel agent involved, but a statement to the effect that the total fare is not refundable if not used on the fligh(s)/date(s) shown, must also appear on or be attached to the ticket itselr. In addition, passengers purchasing advance purchase fares must also be advised of the availability of insurance cover, which may assist in guarding against unforseen changes to travel plans.
In deciding whether or not to impose special consumer warning notices on tickets my Department has had to balance the consumer interest against the legitimate need of the industry to minimise airline and travel agent administrative costs. It should also be noted that administrative costs also affect the consumer interest through their impact on fare levels.
It would appear, from information available to the Department of Transport, however that consumers have readily accepted the more restrictive conditions on the promotional fare types in exchange for lower cost travel.
Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd
Mr Newman-On 24 September 1981 (Hansard, page 1735) Mr Cunningham asked me a question, without notice, concerning police inquiries into the activities of the former Chairman of Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd. I answered the honourable member at that time and he later wrote to me seeking clarification of two points.
( I) Why the first report was never released;
(2) When Mr Webster or his legal advisers were last interviewed.
The answers to the honourable member's further questions are as follows:
(I) I refer the honourable member to the statement made by my colleague, the Minister for Primary Industry in the House on 29 October 1981 (Hansard, pages 2681 to 2686). In the course of that statement, the Minister tabled a comprehensive report by the Australian Federal Police covering its investigations.
(2) I am advised by the Australian Federal Police that Mr Webster was personally contacted by investigating police on II September 1981 but he stated he did not wish to participate

in any further interviews and declined to answer any questions.

Mining Industry Income: Proportions Payable Overseas
(Question No. 2470)
Mr Uren asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 5 June 1981:
(I) What proportions of total company income in (a) the minining industry, (b) the manufacturing industry, (c) the finance sector and (d) all industries were payable overseas in each year since 1970-71.
(2) What proportions of income payable overseas in (a) the mining industry,(b) the manufacturing industry, (c) the finance'sector and (d) all industries were retained in Australia in each yea'r sihce 1970-71.
Mr Howard-the answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) (a) (b) (c) and (d) Estimates of the proportions of total company income (after income tax) in the mining industry, manufacturing industry, the finance sector and in all industries that were payable overseas in each year from 1970-71 to 1979-80 are as follows:

Mining

Manu-

All

facturing Finance industries

1970-71 1971-72 1972-73 1973-74 1974-75 1975-76 1976-77 1977-78
1978-79 1979-80

per cent 46.5 25.1 41.2 51.3 52.2 42.5 47.8 39.5 30.8 n.a.

per cent 27.0 27.3 26.3 24.6 19.9 27.3 31.1 30.7 31.7 n.a.

per cent 18.3 21.5 22.6 21.7 8.8 29.7 16.8 54.2
15.3 27.1

percent 29.0 26.9 31.2 30.9 25.5 32.6 34.1 37.9 32.7 36.5

These estimates have been derived from data provided by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS). The method Followed in the calculation of the estimates is in accordance with that used For the preparation of the data on the proportion of total company income payable overseas that were released on 31 March 1980 (Press Release by the Treasurer, No. 35).
The estimates are subject to the qualifications noted in that press release. In particular, it should be noted that the proportion of total company income payable overseas is not a reliable measure of the extent of Foreign participation in the economy. It is subject to a good deal of short-term fluctuation and apparent trends may be subject to reversal as revised and more recent data become available. Moreover, the proportion, apart From being calculated From data that are subject to problems of statistical estimation, is affected by various influences in addition to the level of Foreign ownership. These include any tendency for the profitability of Foreigncontrolled enterprises to differ From that of Australiancontrolled enterprises and For the profitability and taxation payments of sectors in which foreign ownership is relatively high to vary relative to other sectors. For these reasons, great care should be taken in drawing any conclusions relating to foreign participation from the data.
In addition to these general qualifications, it should be noted that some of the data required for the calculations of the proportions of company income payable overseas in respect of the mining, manuFacturi ng and finance sectors were not available, with the result that certain assumptions and approximations had to be made. A major qualification to the proportions for these sectors is that the estimates of income payable overseas are derived from data For groups of related

Answers to Questions

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3115

enterprises classified according to the 1961 Population Census Classification of Industries, whereas the estimates of total company income relate generally to single enterprises classified according to the Australian Standard Industrial Classification.
Hence, the reliability of the estimates for the industry sectors shown in the table is severely limited, both as regards levels and year to year movements in the proportions, by the lack of consistency on an industry basis between the income payable overseas data and the total company income data, and also by the assumptions and approximations that have had to be made.
The following notes regarding the calculations,of the proportions of company income payable overseas should also be taken into account when interpreting the data shown in the table:
(i) In order to derive the proportion of total company income payable overseas, withholding tax has been added to the income payable overseas data. (Although withholding tax reduces the income received by the foreign owners of Australian businesses, it is the amount of income generated by these businesses, rather than the amount payable to their owners, that is relevant for the purpose of obtaining an indication of the share of foreign investors in total company income.) It was not, however, possible to make this adjustment in respect of the data for the industry sectors.
(ii) Information is not available to permit the proportions for the mining and manufacturing industries to be estimated using numerators consistent with the denominators in that the denominators do not include dividends received.
(iii) The data used for tax payable by mining companies and manufacturing companies were approximations and included estimated adjustments for late assessments.
(iv) The estimated company income after tax of financial enterprises included data relating to institutions engaged mainly in financing. Data relating to companies engaged in financial service activities (eg stock or commodity exchanges, financial consultants or brokers) were not included.
(v) The company income data used to derive the proportions in the table are before deducting any allowance for stock valuation adjustment (this is a measure of the 'paper profits' derived from stocks as a result of rising prices). This ensures that both the company income and the income payable overseas data are valued in the same way.
(2) (a) (b) (c) and (d) The proportions of income payable overseas on direct foreign investment in the mining and quarrying industry, manufacturing industry, the insurance, banking and other finance and property sectors, and all industries that were retained in Australia in each year since 1970-71 were as follows:' ,

Taxation Incentive: Investment on Films
(Question No. 2488)
Dr Klugman asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 5 June 1981:
(1) Did he receive a submission from Mr James Mitchell, Executive Director, Film and Television Production Association of Australia, dated 12 May 1981.
(2) If so, does the submission state On page 2, in regard to the 150 per cent incentive investment write-off on films and the other promised tax concession, that. the original estimate of $2 million per year cost to revenue was based on total investment in production of $20 million.
(3) Can he say whether a similar calculation convinced the Prime Minister and the former Minister for Home Affairs and Environment to promise these benefits during the last election campaign.
Mr Howard-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) and (2) Yes.
(3)- As I indicated in my response to the honourable member's question in the House on 28 May 1981, the original estimate of cost of the policy speech proposal was based on estimates supplied by the Au~tralian Film Commission. The concession was proposed as an incentive to the Australian film industry. The projected cost was one of the factors taken into account in developing the proposal.

Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting TaskForce
(Question No. 2648)
Mr Hayden asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:
(1) What are the (a) numbers and (b) salaries of (i) Second, (ii) Third and (iii) Fourth Division officers participating in the Commonwealth Heads of Government .Meeting Task Force.
(2) What was the total cost of salaries and overtime for members of the Task Force during 1980-81.
(3) Are all the members of the Task Force officers of his Department; if not, which other Departments are represented on the Task Force, and by how many officers from each Division.
Mr Malcolm Fraser-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) There were 459 staff attached to the Task Force as outlined in the tabulation below. Of these 77 were on the Task Force payroll whilst the remainder (382) were attached on a very short term basis and counted on the payrolls of their parent departments. The 382 short term staff included 133 Delegation Liaison Officers, 60 pass checkers and 50 keyboard staff who were employed for a period little more than the duration of the meeting..

Advertising and Promotion: Department of Industry and Commerce
(Question No, 2653)
Mr Les Johnson asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 18 August 1981 :
(1) What sum was spent by the Minister's Department on adverising and the promotion of Government programs and services during the period (a) 1 January 1980 to 18 October 1980 and (b) 19 October 1980 to 17 August 1981.
(2) What was the cost of each campaign undertaken.
(3) Under which item of expenditure were funds allocated for each campaign.
(4) Which advertising agencies or consultants were used for each campaign.

(5) What was the total sum paid to each agency or consultant for each campaign.
(6) How was each agency or consultant selected.
(7) By what percentage has the departmental cost of advertising increased or decreased year from 1975 to 1980 and duringtheperiod I January 1981 to 17 August 1981.
(8) What is the estimated cost of advertising and the promotion of Government programs and services for 1981-82.
Sir Philip Lynch-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1)-
Project Australia Campaign: (a) $787,968.00; (b) $634,335.00.
Shorter Working Week: (a) Nil; (b) $545,360.00. Small Business Program: (a) $3,378.65; (b) $12,390.70.

3118 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Answers to Questions

Points of First Contact (Business Information Centre): (a) $14,713.58; (b) $2,127.58.' .
The following expenditure figures relate to part (b) only as the areas which incurred the expense were not part of the Department of Industry and Commerce prior to I November 1980.
Government Aircraft Factories-Fishermen's Bend: (b) $168,316.00.
Australian Defence Equipment Catalogue: (b) $8,395.00.
.Pacific Defence Reporter: (b) $5,585.00.
(2) The cost of each campaign and a brief outline of the campaign follows:-
Project Australia Campaign: $1 ,422,303.00.
The broad objectives of the campaign are: to heighten community awareness and appreciation of
Australian skills, achievements and potential. to highlight the role of individual initiative in the econ-
omy;and to promote improved product quality, design, pro-
ductivity and marketing; and to encourage the purchase, use and transport of Australian products, services and technology so as to increase employment opportunities.
Shorter Working Week Campaign: $545,360.00.
The Government decided in March 1981 that there should be a media campaign pUblicising the costs and consequences of a shorter working week. This publicity campaign is aimed at informing the public of the effect on the economy of a shorter working week.
Small Business Programme: $15,769.35. In October 1976 Commonwealth and State Ministers responsible for industrial and commercial developments agreed upon a broad program of assistance to small business with emphasis on co-operation between the Commonwealth and States and a rationalisation of services and assistance provided. The basis of the agreed program is that the States assume responsibility for the provision of direct services to small firms in such fields as information, counselling, and training. The Commonwealth provides support services in such areas as publications, training materials, and research and also undertakes a co-ordinating role.
Points of First Contact (Business Information Centres): $16,841.16.
In February 1980, Business Information centres were established on a trial basis for the purpose of providing "points of first contact" for businessmen in relation to Government programs and assistance. The trial project was terminated on 30 April 1981.
General Advertising(i) Government Aircraft Factories-Fishermen's Bend:
$168,316.00 The advertisements placed by G.A.F. relate to pro-
motion of programs and services International Advertising campaign on Nomad aircraft project ($165,301.00) Occupational Health (Australia and New Zealand) ($370.00) International Herald Tribune of Paris, France ($2,580.00) Little Athlete of Melbourne ($65.00)
(ii) DepartmentalAustralian Defence Equipment Catalogue $8,395.00. This catalogue lists all defence orientated equipment produced by both private enterprise and by Government Factories. Pacific Defence Reporter $5,585.00. This publication advertises services performed by the factories as a whole, it advertises Department of

Industry and Commerce as a supplier of Defence equipment in order to expand markets for the future.
(3) Listed below are the heads of expenditure where funds were allocated for each campaign:-

Curriculum Development Centre
(Question No. 2773)
Mrs Darling asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:
(I) Has he received correspondence from Mr Graham Evans, President of the Mathematics Education Research Group of Australasia expressing total opposition to the decision taken by the Government in relation to the Curriculum Development Centre and the Education Research and Development Centre.
(2) If so, did the President cite the long term effects on the quality of educational opportunity offered to Australian children and the quality of trained personnel needed for the growth and development of Australian technology as reasons for reconsidering the Government's decision.
(3) Will he reconsider the decision of the Government in this matter; if not, why not.
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) I have received a letter from Dr Graham Jones, President of the Mathematics Education Research Group of Australia, in which reference is made to the Government's decision in relation to the Curriculum Development Centre.
(2) Dr Jones did express concern about the potential long term implications of the decision for the development of trained personnel needed for Australia's prosperity and growth.
(3) No; the Government decided in June that $2.04m would be provided for CDC activities in this financial year. The Commonwealth is still to decide which projects it will continue to fund as projects of particular national significance. It will be prepared to join in funding other projects sponsored by the Australian Education Council.
Education: Commonwealth Contribution
(Question No. 2774)
Mrs Darling asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:
(I) Did he state in his letter to Members of Parliament, dated 7 May 1981, concerning improved recognition of the Commonwealth Government's financial contribution-to education, that his Government would attempt to receive more recognition for education funding by way of plaques.
(2) If so, has any State Education Minister replied to his suggestion by saying that such a concentration of interest by him on the wording of plaques is petty.
(3) Will he consider having future plaques made from tin instead of brass in view of budgetary restraints and general reductions in Government expenditure.
(4) If not, will he transfer the money allocated for plaques into one of the many areas of expenditure affected by cuts recommended by the Government's Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions.
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes.
(2) No.
(3) No.
(4) No.

Training Opportunities for Aboriginals
(Question No. 2813)
Mr Burr asked the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 20 August 1981:
(I) Did he write to members of the House of Representatives and senators asking that they provide training opportunities for Aboriginals in their electoral offices under the National Employment Strategy for Aboriginals.
(2) If so. will he also give approval for members and senators to accept final year students for training as part of their work experience program.
Mr N. A. Brown-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes.
(2) Under the guidelines for the Commonwealth Work Experience Program members and senators may accept final year students for work experience.
Statutory Authorities under the Minister for Education
(Question No. 2852)
Mr Les Johnson asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 26 August 1981:
(I)' Further to the Review of Commonwealth Functions which called for Ministers to scrutinise all authorities within their portfolios (Hansard, 30 April 1981, page 1850) which statutory authorities within the Minister's portfolio are to be (a) terminated, (b) continued and (c) reviewed in depth.
(2) If the scrutiny referred to in part (I) has not been completed, when will it be finalised and the results reported to Parliament.
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
I refer to the answer to question 2839 given by the Acting Prime Minister (Hansard. 22 September 1981), which commented on general action being taken by Ministers to examine statutory authorities within their portfolios.
Included among the educational decisions taken in the context of RCF was that requiring the Curriculum Development Centre (CDC) to be abolished unless the States agreed to contribute 50 per cent of the total operating costs. As it is now clear that the States are not prepared to meet the request, plans have been made to wind down the operation of the CDC during 1981-82.
Also as a result of RCF, the Office of the Commonwealth Teaching Service Commissioner has been abolished, as has the non-statutory Education Research and Development Committee. The structure of the ACT Schools Authority is being reviewed.
Statutory Authorities under the Minister for Housing and Construction
(Question No. 2863)
Mr Les Johnson asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 26 August 1981:
(I) Further to the Review of Commonwealth Functions which called for Ministers to scrutinise all authorities within their portfolios (Hansard, 30 April 1981, page 1850) which statutory authorities with' 1 the Minister's portfolio are to be (a) terminated, (b) continued and (c) reviewed in depth.

(2) If the scrutiny referred to in part (I) has not been completed, when will it be finalised and the results reported to Parliament.
Mr McVeigh-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) and (2) I refer the honourable member to the answer provided by the Prime Minister to question No. 2839 (Hansard, 22 September 1981, pages 1647 and 1648).

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3121

Redevelopment of Brisbane Airport: Effect on Fisheries
. (Question No. 2943)
Mr Humphreys asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on -27 August 1981:
(I) What is the location of any fish or prawn trawling, breeding and/or feeding grounds which will be lost or adversely affected as a result of dredging or pumping of sand from Moreton Bay, Queensland, in association with the redevelopment of Brisbane's International Airport.
(2) Have any investigations been carried out to ascertain whether new trawling and fishing grounds can be opened up to compensate for those lost.
Mr McVeigh-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) The likely effects of Airport construction on both the Middle Banks in Moreton Bay and the existing Serpentine Creek system were examined by the Brisbane Airport Environment Study Committee between 1972 and 1979. The work of this Committee formed the basis of the Environmental Impact Statement prepared in 1979 and on which public comment was invited and considered. Further studies have continued since 1'979 and are continuing at the present time.
The study showed that the Middle Banks were generally devoid of marine vegetation and supported very little fish life. The presence of fish in the Banks area tends to be transitory and it is not expected that dredging will result in more than a passing interference in fish occurrence. Full recovery of bottom dwelling sealife is also expected within 12-18 months of termination of dredging.
A total loss of fish and prawn habitat will occur in the sections of Serpentine Creek that are to be reclaimed. Studies have shown, however, that the Creek is not an important nursery area for bream or whiting although studies on other species have been inconclusive. The new flood canal may prove to have potential for fish breeding and feeding grounds as observations to date indicate that it has attraction for fish.
Removal of the mangrove areas in Serpentine Creek will reduce the amount of suitable habitat available in the Moreton Bay region for post larvae and juvenile prawns which migrate to estuarine areas after hatching in oceanic waters. However, relative to the total estuarine areas available, this loss is likely to be insignificant and the Moreton Bay prawn crops are likely to be affected only to a small extent.
The reclamation of Serpentine Creek and diversion of flows to the flood canal may change the distribution of the bottom dwelling sealife in Bramble Bay, but the effects are expected to be minor compared with those of a natural event such as a major flood.
The reclamation works on Boggy Creek in the Brisbane River are unlikely to have any more effects upon the ecology of the area than do the regular dredging of the shipping channels or the flood flows in the Brisbane River.
(2) This is a matter for the Queensland State Government and the Queensland Department of Primary Industries has advised that no new trawling and fishing grounds are available to be opened up.
Curriculum Development Centre
(Question No. 2978)
Mrs Kelly asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 8 September 1981:

(I) Is it a fact that the States have always heavily supported the Curriculum Development Centre, in particular by continuing to meet the salaries of State personnel involved in its various programs.

(2) Does the Centre's English Language Development

Project currently involve the the active participation in its de-

velopment work of some 200-250 English language curricu-

lum consultants and teachers in all States and Territories in

Australia.

.

(3) Did he demand that the States be asked to put up a significant share of the Centre's running costs; ifso, why, when it
is apparent that they already support it substantially in kind.

(4) Does the Government propose to continue the national
Language Development Project which is at present a project of the Curriculum Development Centres.

(5) Was the developmental phase II funded directly by
Cabinet approval for 1978-79 and 1979-80; if so, what sum was involved.

(6) Were these funding decisions indicative of the significance attached by the Government to the development of
literacy in Australia.

(7) Has the Government's policy of support for the development of literacy in Australia changed; if so, in what way.

(8) Is the National Language Development Project at present in the middle of a materials development phase and
are curriculum materials for use in Australian schools being
developed by each State team; if so, is it anticipated that they wi11 be ready for publication by the end of 1982.

(9) Will he honour the grants offered by the Curriculum
DevelopmenrCentre to the States for continuing work in the Language Development Project.

(10) Will the remaining $52,000, which is essential for continued developmental work, be paid, if so, when.

(II) Does he expect that development work begun by an
extensive and growing network of teachers in the Australian
Capital Territory, currently supported by the Language Development Project team working at the Curriculum Development Centre, will continue; if so, by what means will this work be promoted in the event of the closure of the Centre.

Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(I) The States meet the salaries of task force personnel located in States and Territories for those Curriculum Development Centre projects which the States regard as significant
to their own needs.

(2) Yes. The Government, through grants to the CDC, has supported each Language Development Project Task Force
to the extent of $15,000 each year.

(3) The Government sought contribution from the States of 50 per cent of the Centre's total operating costs. Existing
forms of support from the States and Territories were noted.

(4) The Government has provided an amount of $210,000
in the 1981-82 appropriation of the Centre for continuation of the development phase of the national Language Development Project. Funds are also available within the Centre's 1981-82 publishing budget for publication of any outcomes finalised during the year.

(5) Phase II of the project was funded as a result of normal budgeting processes. Actual development expenditure in the
two years was as follows:

1978-79 $207,200; 1979-80 $115,200.

In 1980-81 expenditure was $216,200. Funding of the projects has been on an anllual basis.

3122 REPRE~ENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Answers to Questions

(6) and (7) The broad lines of Government's policy of support For the development of literacy in Australia have not changed. The Language Development Project was Funded with the strong recommendation of the CDC Council.
(8) Yes; it is expected that materials will become ready For publication progressively during the first halF of 1982.
(9) Grants For the period up to December 1981 will be paid to States and Territories under Sections 7 and 8 of the Curriculum Development Centre Act.
(10) Funds are available in the current budget for additional grants to States and Territories in the period January-June 1982 provided that requests meet the test of essentiality.
(II) Development work in the Australian Capital Territory will continue during the 1981-82 financial year. The Future of the Centre and of the Language Development Project are under consideration by the Government.
Urea Formaldehyde Foam Insulation
(Question No. 3001)
Mr Holding asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 9 September 1981:
(I) Further to his answer to part (2) of question No. 499 (Hansard. 2 April 1981, page 1337), has his Department now compiled all available inFormation on urea Formaldehyde Foam '(UF) insulation and has the evaluation and publication of policy directives and information documents now taken place; iF not, why not.
(2) In view of concern which has been expressed by consumer organisations, such as the Australian Consumers Association, and the general public, will he now publicly release those documents, in order to ensure that the community is well inFormed about the possible hazards of UF insulation; if not, why not.
Mr McVeigh-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) The Department of Housing and Construction has evaluated available inFormation on urea Formaldehyde Foam (UF) insulation and prepared a Technical InFormation Document which will be issued to staff shortly.
The Document inForms Departmental staff of the health aspects of UF insulation and provides interim guidelines For the saFe and appropiate use of the material in Commonwealth projects.
Further directives may be issued after a Full evaluation has been conducted by health and regulatory authorities.
(2) Single copies of the Department's Technical Information Document will be made available to the public upon written request. In line with Government policy, multiple copies will be available at a modest charge to cover production and administrative costs.
Tenosynoyitis: Department of Communications
(Question No. 3013)
Mr Les McMahon asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 9 September 1981 :
(1) Have any cases of Tenosynovitis been reported to date, in the Department or Statutory Authorities under the Minister's jurisdiction.
(2) If so, will the Minj~ter state (a) how many cases have been reported (b) in wha, types of work the affected persons were engaged (c) of the cases reported how many were in re-

spect of (i) Female and (ii) male employees and (d) what age brackets appear to be the most affected in the Department and each Statutory Authority.
(3) Will the Minister provide similar information in respect of carpal tunnel.
Mr Sinclair-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
Administrative responsibility in my portfolio is spread through hundreds of offices throughout Australia, under the direction of the various Statutory Authorities and the Department. To Fully answer the questions asked by Mr McMahon would prove extremely time consuming and would place enormous additional workload on administration throughout the portFolio, particularly for cases other than those related to compensation matters.
A sample 12 months period has thereFore been surveyed throughout the portFolio and combined details have been obtained For compensible Tenosynovitis and carpal tunnel. It has not been possible to seperate these into individual ailments in all cases:
(a) In the period May 1980 to April 1981 41 cases have been recorded For compensible injury.
(b) Affected people were From a broad range of employment groups which include, Clerical/Administrative, Keyboard, Technical and Trades staff. The majority of claims arise From the Clerical and Keyboard groups.
(c) OF the reported cases 21 arefemale and 20 are male.
(d) The claims are being made From all age groups with the majority Falling into the 30-45 age group.

Tenosynovitis: Department of Administrative Services
(Question No. 3028)
Mr Les McMahon asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 9 September 1981:
(I) Have any cases of tenosynovitis been reported to date, in the Department or statutory authorities under the Minister's jurisdiction.
(2) IF so, will the Minister state (a) how many cases have been reported (b) in what types of work the affected persons were engaged (c) of the cases reported how many were in respect of (i) Female (ii) male employees and (d) what age brackets appear to be the most affected, in the Department and each Statutory Authority.
(3) Will the Minister provide similar inFormation in respect of carpal tunnel syndrome.
Mr Newman-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
Because of the administrative costs involved the extraction of data was limited to current records. Consequently the figures shown below are in respect of the period 1978 to 1981 of staff presently employed in the Department of Administrative Services, the Australian Electoral Office, the Australain Federal Police and the Commonwealth Accommodation and Catering Service Ltd; the Following inFormation is provided in respect of specific questions:
(I) Yes.
(2)-
(a) 21 cases-13 in the Department of Administrative Services; I in the Australian Electoral Office; 4 in the Commonwealth Accommodation and Catering Service and 3 in the Australian Federal Police.
(b) Keyboard duties (7); printing trades (6); catering occupations (4); stores staff (2); and labouring-type duties (2).
(c) 17 Females; 4 males.
(d) There is no clear pattern.
(3) Only one case has been reported. The employee concerned was a Female typist, aged 28, in the Department of Administrative Services.
Entry Visas to Australia
(Question No. 3074)
Mr Robert Brown asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 10 September 1981:
(I) How many (a) individuals and (b) delegations from the (i) Democratic People's Republic of Korea and (ii) USSR have been refused entry to Australia since January 1980.
(2) What were the names of those denied entry and what was the proposed purpose of their visit to Australia.
(3) What were the reasons for the refusal of entry visas.

Mr Macphee-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) From January 1980 to the end of September 1981 visas for temporary entry to Australia were refused as Follows:

Individuals Delegations

Democratic People's Republic of

Korea

nil

2

USSR

10

16

(2) and (3) Those applying for visitor visas and persons or organisations that might be sponsoring a visit have an expectation that details of their applications would not be made public. For this and other reasons I am not prepared to provide the names, purposes of visits and reasons for refusal sought by the honourable member.
Refusal of a visitor visa application is only made after careful consideration of all the factors involved and in the interests of the Australian community.
Applications for visas For Democratic People's Republic of Korea delegations have been considered in the context of our overall relationship with the Democratic People's Republic of Korea. In this regard the central Factor remains that diplomatic relations have been interrupted For some years. The Government has made it clear to the Democratic People's Republic of Korea the circumstances in which it will consider restoring relations. Meanwhile, proposals for official delegations from the Democratic People's Republic of Korea seeking to visit Australia are considered case by case.
Applications from USSR nationals are, of course, currently considered in the context of the current Government restrictions on contacts with the Soviet Union which were imposed following the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. In this respect I rely on the advice of the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

School Curricula
(Question No. 3095)
Mrs Darling asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 15 September 1981:
Further to the Prime Minister's reply to my question No; 617 (Hansard, 2 April 1981, page 1329) when will the current review of curricula be completed.
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
In my Guidelines Statement to the Parliament on 4 June 1981, I referred to the review of education and training opportunities for young people, which had been announced on 16 January 1981 and to which the Prime Minister referred in his answer to question No. 617. The review was considered by the Government in the context of deciding on guidelines for the Education Commissions for 1982 programs.
The Commonwealth is concerned to see accelerated development of appropriate transition courses in secondary schools with emphasis on basic changes in curricula relevant particularly to the needs of low achievers.
Such developments can be implemented only through action by State authorities, but the Commonwealth will be looking to their implementation as one of the outcomes of its funding of transition programs in the States. In addition most States have assured the Commonwealth that they are significantly increasing their own expenditures on transition education. The continuing process of curriculum adaptation to meet the needs of young people in making the transition from

3124 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Answers to Questions

school to working life is proceeding in a context of joint StateCommonwealth funding and dialogue concerning directions and objectives.
