Taxes and Other Charges Imposed by State and Territorial Governments
(Question No. 3224)
Mr Robert Brown asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1981:

Will he provide a complete list of all additional or special taxes, freights, fees, royalties or other charges which can be identified as having been imposed by State and Territorial Governments to obtain extra revenue benefit from resource developments and to benefit from the vacuum created by the Commonwealth Government's Failure to introduce an appropriately structured and equitable resource rent tax which is

Answers to Questions

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3125

profit related, showing in each case (a) the State or Territory which has imposed it, (b) the nature of the charge and the basis on which it is imposed and assessed including whether it is profit related or otherwise, (c) the estimated annual revenue derived by the State or Territory from the item, (d) the declared purpose of imposing the special charge and (e) whether any of the revenue derived from the charge is specially earmarked for any particular purpose.
Mr Howard-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

It is, of course, impossible for me to know the motives of the States for imposing additional or special taxes, freights, fees, royalties or other charges on resource developments. The presumption however would be that they have imposed such charges for the purpose of raising additional revenues and directly capturing for the benefit of State residents some of the benefits of mining within the State's jurisdiction.
Royalties and other charges of which I am aware that have been introduced by the States since July 1978 are set out below, together with total royalty collections for each State and the Northern Territory in 1979-80.

Electoral: Ballot Boxes and Voting Screens
(Question No. 3259)
Mr Hayden asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:
(1) Did the annual report for 1980-81 of the Australian Electoral Office report that difficulties emerged during the testing and proving of the design of new ballot boxes and voting screens.
(2) If so, what were the difficulties.
(3) Who was the successful tenderer and what was the cost of the successful tender.
Mr Newman-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes.
(2) The contract requires the use of polypropylene to produce plastic moulded ballot boxes and voting screens. The plastic sections of the voting screens are to be mounted on aluminium extrusions.
Ballot Boxes. The use of polypropylene for production of ballot boxes requires a most complex mould and preparation of the tooling took longer than was originally expected by the contractor. The basic ballot box form has been established since September 1980. First off mouldings, as expected, were not in complete accord with the design drawing: some distorsion of the moulding existed and appropriate tooling modifications were recommended to overcome this.
Fine tuning of the tool had been underway for some time, with little success, until July 1981 when a chemical analysis of

the raw moulding material revealed that it had been contaminated by a non-compatible thermoplastic at the source of
supply.

It seems that manyof the problems experienced during initial moulding trials may have been attributable to that con-
taminated material.

Following replacement of the faulty material by the supplier tool testing has been recommenced. On the basis of the tests so far undertaken some minor modifications to the ballot box design may be necessary to ensure compliance with the Australian Electoral Office's stacking specification. Some fine tuning of the moulded hinges also may be necessary.

I am informed that, at this stage, the Australian Electoral Office's technical advisers believe a satisfactory product is close to being achieved.

Voting Screens. The main difficulty here also was the much longer time involved than originally estimated by the contractor for preparation of the complex tooling to undertake the
necessary moulding. Tooling for the first panels will be tria lied
shortly and the remainder by 4 December 1981.

A secondary difficulty arose when the aluminium extrusions delivered by a sub-contractor were not in accordance with specifications and required some further machining. This work is proceeding and early completion is expected.

(3) (a) Successful Tenderer: DMG Tools Pty Ltd

(b) Tendered Cost:
Ballot boxes Voting screens

$ 110,402.64 455,465.42

565,868.06

3126 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Answers to Questions

It should be noted that the tendered price 'included amounts of $90,000 and $137,000 for the initial production of the tooling required for moulding of the ballot boxes and voting screens respectively. These are a once only cost. The tooling will remain the property of the Commonwealth and will be available for production of subsequent requirements of both items at a unit cost considerably below that of the labour intensive equipment currently in use.
Even including the cost of tooling the unit price of the items produced under this contract will be considerably less than the present unit cost of the items currently used.
Apart from the cost advantage of the new designs the new ballot box design will have the advantage of being able to be nested for transport and storage considerably reducing these costs. The voting screens also will be much lighter which also will reduce freight costs and facilitate handling.
Coal
(Question No, 3293)
Mr Hayden asked the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:
(I) What is the projected annual export of (a) coking coal, and (b) non-coking coal from (i) New South Wales and (ii) Queensland for each of the years (A) 1985, (B) 1990, (C) 1995 and (D) 2000.

Pensions: Taxation
(Question No. 3299)
Dr Klugman asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 14 October 1981:
(I) Is it a fact that some taxable pensions paid to war veterans are made on a 12 weekly basis and that therefore, in some financial years, there are five payments.
(2) If so, does this lead to an extra tax liability in some cases.
(3) Will he take steps to permit these recipients to average their pensions on a 52 week per year basis for taxation purposes.
Mr Howard-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
( I) Pensions payable to war veterans are made, at the option of recipients, either fortnightly by cheque or at twelve weekly intervals by direct credit to a nominated bank account or similar facility. Under the twelve weekly method, five pay, ments are made to war veterans in some financial years.
On 14 October 1981, in answer to Question No. 2689 (Hansard, page 2049), the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans; Affairs advised that consideration has been given to introducing fortnightly payments direct to accounts at banks, building societies and credit unions. The m'agnitude of the financial implications in making such a change prevented this action being taken during 1981-82.
(2) The receipt of five pension payments in a financial year can have the effect of placing a recipient beyond the tax threshold.

(3) It is a basic principle of taxation law that income in the form of salary, wages or pension is derived only at the time of its receipt and it would represent a significant departure from this rule to permit the exclusion from assessable income of a particular year of amounts that had, in fact, been derived as income.
Immigration: Indo-Chinese Refugees
(Question No. 3300)
Dr Klugman asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 14 October 1981:
(I) Is it proposed to publish a 12 page booklet to dispel the many myths surrounding Indo-Chinese refugees.
(2) If so, is the booklet a combined project of his Department, the Fairfield City Council and the Milperra College of Advanced Education.
(3) Will his Department accept responsibility for the cost of production and distribution of the booklet in view of the importance of correct information being widely disseminated especially following the sensationalist series of articles in the National Times.
Mr Macphee-The answer to the honourable gentleman's question is as follows:
(I) and (2) The Fairfield City Council, through its Refugee Liaison Committee on which my Department is represented, is producing a booklet aimed at reducing misinformation and increasing understanding about Indo-Chinese refugees who have settled in comparatively large numbers in the area. My Department is assisting with the text of the booklet and other community bodies, including the Milperra College of Advanced Education, local educational authorities and a Vietnamese newspaper, are also co-operating in its production and distribution.
(3) This initiative in Fairfield demonstrates a fundamental concern on the part of a significant element of the Australian community to combat the false information and prejudiced views that are sometimes current about refugees. It puts into perspective the intolerant and racist utterances of a few extremists which I condemned in my remarks to the House on 22 October. I have agreed that my Department share with Fairfield City Council the costs of publishing and circulating the booklet
Aboriginal Community Housing Projects
(Question No. 3304)
Mr Campbell asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 14 October 1981:
(I) Do construction staff.of his Department in Western Australia work on Aboriginal community housing projects for eight week periods and then spend two weeks in Perth.
(2) Is it more common in the Northern Territory for the community itself to administer its own housing project funds and generally employ a housing manager who lives and works in the community on a full time basis.
(3) In the Northern Territory does his Department give services to housing programs such as technical advisers and work evaluations free of charge.
(4) In Western Australian communities does his Department charge, on average, about 11 per cent of the communities' housing budgets for the services of his Department.

3128 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Answers to Questions

(5) What is the comparative cost of an employee being based in Perth and spending eight weeks at a time in a community compared with the cost of having a resident housing manager in the community.
(6) Does his Department recruit housing managers for the Aboriginal housing programs in Western Australia directly from the Department or does it take advantage of the Aboriginal employment section of the Commonwealth Employment Service.
Mr McVeigh~The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes, in those instances where housing projects are of more than approximately three months duration and are located in remote areas where there are no appropriate facilities for construction staff.
(2) Yes. Some larger communities employ a full-time housing manager. Other communities employ a community adviser, part of whose' duties relate to housing, and in other instances a Mission or Council administers housing funds on behalf of communities.
(3) Fees are charged for design and construction services. Fees are not charged for feasibility studies, technical advice, programming assistance or estimates provided for the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission or for similar advisory support provided at the request of communities.
(4) No. Fees vary according to services provided and are based on minimum commercial scales less rebate for repetitive work. A typical fee for procurement, supervision and construction consultancy is 6.8 per cent. Direct project charges are levied at cost.
(5) The Department does not employ resident community housing managers and comparative figures are not available.
(6) The Department does not recruit or employ housing managers for Aboriginal communities or Aboriginal housing programs. When skilled on-site foremen are needed they are either provided from the Department's workforce or recruited locally.
Aboriginal Housing Programs
(Question No. 3305)
Mr Campbell asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 14 October 1981:
(I) In areas where Aboriginal housing programs are administered by his Department, is the Department committed to providing training for Aboriginal employees.
(2) If so, has it made an estimation of the added cost involved per housing unit for this training.
(3) For each Aboriginal community housing project in the Kimberley region of Western Australia, what is the number of (a) housing project employees for whom the community is receiving a NEATS subsidy and (b) Aboriginal employees working on each project.
Mr McVeigh-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) The Department does not administer Aboriginal housing programs. It provides technical advice and estimates to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission, and advice and consultancy services to Aboriginal communities. The service provided is directed to promotion of self-sufficiency. The Department is currently training 45 Aboriginals on its own programs under the National Employment Strategy for Aboriginals.

(2) No. See above.
(3) (a) No figures are available.
(b) Aboriginal employees are engaged and paid by Aboriginal communities. The Department does not have records of numbers engaged.
Community Youth Support Scheme
(Question No. 3331)
Mr Beazley asked the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 15 October 1981:
(I) When will the new guidelines for the Community Youth Support Scheme (CYSS) be finalised.
(2) Will local CYSS Committees and project officers have the opportunity to put their views on draft guidelines before final guidelines are implemented.
(3) Will the two conferences in Brisbane during November 1981, one for project officers and the other for project officers and local CYSS committees, be the only opportunities for these people to make suggestions regarding the new guidelines; if so, will funds be provided to allow adequate representation from all States.
Mr N. A. Brown-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) It is anticipated that the new guidelines will be finalised in time to be operative from I March 1982.
(2) No, but before the draft guidelines are prepared, committees and project officers have the opportunity to present their views on those matters that should be contained in the guidelines.
(3) Apart from contributing to conferences at the national level, project officers and local CYSS committees have the opportunity to participate directly in the consultations being conducted by the Task Force throughout Australia. CYSS projects have been authorised to spend up to $250 of their current grants to enable their participation in the consultation process.
Rhodesia Medal
(Question No. 3344)
Dr Blewett asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 15 October 1981:
Further to the prompt answer to my question No. 3253 (Hansard, 13 October 1981, page 1958) was the nation formerly called Southern Rhodesia officially known as Zimbabwe-Rhodesia during the period in Which Commonwealth Monitoring Forces served there; if so, is it quite inappropriate to award Australians who served in that force during that period a medal known as the Rhodesia Medal.
Mr Newman-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
The official name of Zimbabwe before it gained its independence was Southern Rhodesia though the term 'ZimbabweRhodesia' was fairly widely used.
Tertiary Fees Loans Scheme
(Question No. 3370)
Mr Humphreys asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 20 October 1981:
(I) How many universities have agreed to administer a Tertiary Fees Loans Scheme.

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3129

(2) Will he provide details of the administrative arrangements involved in adopting this scheme, including the anticipated rate of interest on the loans.
(3) Will the Government be supplementing tertiary recurrent funding to pay the costs associated with staffing such a scheme.
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I), (2) and (3) Commonwealth officers have had useful discussions with representatives of the Australian Bankers' Association and the Commonwealth Bank on the details of the proposed loan scheme for tertiary students. There are some aspects which have yt:t to be settled, but as soon as it is possible the full details of the scheme will be announced.
Tertiary institutions will be approached on the administration of the loans when the form and scope of the scheme has been decided.
Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme Means Test
(Question No. 3429)
Dr Blewett asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 27 October 1981:
(I) With regard to the Commonwealth Government Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme (TEAS) for, ordinary students, what are the criteria (a) by which the Government establishes the nominated maximum level of adjusted family income below which ordinary students can obtain the maximum rate of living allowance and (b) for establishing the nominated reduction rate of $2.50 for every $10 of income, where the adjusted family income exceeds $10,312.
(2) With regard to the Commonwealth Government TEAS for independent students, (a) why is the means test applied to student's income for the previous financial year, (b) why is the means test not applied to an applicant's available income at the time of commencement of studies, (c) what is the reason for the difference between proportional reductions in allowance applied to an ordinary student's family income and to independent students spouse's income, (d) how many students who applied for TEAS allowance were refused the allowance on the basis of means test provisions since the introduction of the means test and (e) how many students receiving a TEAS allowance withdrew as a result of financial difficulties.
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) As regards 'ordinary' students under the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme (TEAS)-
(a) The level of adjusted family income at which maximum TEAS benefits are provided at the 'at-home' and 'away-from-home' rates (which is known as Marginal Adjusted Family Income or MAFI) is reviewed annually in the Budget context. The Government considers movements in average weekly earnings as well as its overall commitment in finding for student assistance programs generally.
(b) The principle of a gradually tapered means test is long standing; whilst administratively more complex it avoids the obvious inequities arising for exafTlple from a system based on income banding or from an all-ornothing system. The abatement rate of $2.50 in allowance for every $10 by which the adjusted family income exceeds the MAFI has applied since 1977 and permits support to students over a relatively wide range of parental incomes.

(2) As regards students granted independent status under TEAS-
(a) and (b) The means test on the student's income is in fact applied to income during the year of study and not, as the question suggests, to income for the previous financial year. It would not be realistic to means test the student's own income on the basis of the preceding year when in some cases his or her income will be of a very different order during the year of study; on the other hand, parental income is means tested on the basis of the preceding year, since that year's income is verifiable and can reasonably be assumed to be ongoing at a broadly comparable level.
(c) The abatement rate applied to the income of the independent' student's spouse, by which the allowance is reduced at the rate of $1 for every $2 by which the adjusted spouse income exceeds the MAFI, provides a less gradual taper than does' the abatement rate on family income in the case of the 'ordinary' student. The respective abatement rates take account of assumptions about the income of the family unit and the demands assumed to be placed upon it in the case of an 'ordinary' student; account is also taken of the range of other benefits or concess'ions available to the different types of TEAS beneficiary.
(d) Information is not readily available on the numbers of students, since the introduction of the TEAS means test in 1974, whose applications for TEAS allowances were refused on the basis of the means test provisions; and
(e) Similarly, information is not available on the number of students who were in receipt of a TEAS allowance and subsequently withdrew, whose withdrawal was as a result of financial difficulties. However, J refer the honourable member to the 1979 Survey of Full-time Tertiary Student Finances (Volume 2) which was tabled on 14 October 1981, which in Chapter 3 (page 31) discusses the reasons why students discontinue full-time studies. It should be noted that the sample involved in the survey, which related to universities and colleges of advanced education only, was concerned with full-time students generally, and that of the respondents, 41 per cent were in receipt of TEAS.
Tax Deductions: Donations to the RSPCA
(Question No. 3466)
Dr Theophanous asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:
(I) Is it a fact that donations to the RSPCA are not tax deductible.
(2) If so, will he take steps to have the classification of the RSPCA changed so that donations to it can be made tax deductible.
(3) If he will not take steps to change the classification of the RSPCA, what is the reason.
Mr Howard-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Under the present gift provisions of the income tax law, donations made to the RSPCA are not deductible for income tax purposes. They may be deductible, however, under the general deduction provisions of the tax law, where it can be shown to the satisfaction of the Commissioner of Taxation that an appropriate nexus exists between the making of the gift and the earning of assessable income by the donor.
(2) and (3) The Government receives numerous requests each year for amendment to the gift provisions of the income tax law so that gifts to particular organisations ,may be

3130 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Answers to Questions

allowed as deductions. Most of these requests relate to organisations or funds which, like the RSPCA, have objectives of obvious merit.
Since allowance of all such requests would have serious implications for the taxation revenue, and since it would be neither fair nor appropriate to consider particular requests in isolation, it has long been the practice to bring together all requests for new or altered .taxation concessions for consideration at Budget time. It is then possible to assess the relative merits of the requests against the general budgetary situation and such scope as there may be for granting concessions. The question of including the RSPCA in the gift provisions of the income tax law will again be considered in the context of the 1982 Budget.
Institute of Multicultural Affairs
(Question No. 3572)
Mr Young asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:
(I) Is it a fact that the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs is leading an inquiry into the implementation of the Galbally Report; if so, what is the precise purpose of this inquiry.
(2) Is it also a fact that the Institute was funded following the recommendations of the Galbally Report.
(3) Is Mr Frank Galbally the Chairman of the Institute of Multicultural Affairs.
(4) Can he say whether the Director of the Institute of Multicultural Affairs, prior to his present position, was a member of the Prime Minister's staff.
Mr Macphee-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes. The terms of reference require the Institute to
assess the effectiveness of the implementation of the Review of Post-Arrival Services and Programs for Migrants (the Galbally Report)
determine whet her the overall objectives are being achieved
determine whether the Report's objectives and recommendations remain valid and
recommend whether the objectives and recommendations should be pursued in the future and what changes (if any) should be made.
(2) Yes.
(3) Yes.
(4) Yes.
Recognition of Business Qualifications
(Question No, 3578)
Mr Young asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:
(I) What projects are there to recognise the qualifications of overseas-trained (a) professionals, (b) semi-professionals, (c) tradesmen and (d) others.
(2) How many overseas-trained persons referred to in part (I) arrived in Australia in each year since 1978, and how many had their qualifications converted or recognised in Australia.
(3) What was the country of origin of the persons whose qualifications (a) have and (b) have not been recognised in each year since 1978.

(4) How many of those admitted since 1978 continued in their profession after (a) I, (b) 2 and (c) 3 years residence in Australia.
(5) What mechanisms are there to ensure that persons admitted to Australia will be employed in jobs in which they claim expertise or qualification.
(6) Is he able to state what is the position of (a) State governments and (b) trade unions in respect of the recognition of qualifications.
(7) How many full-time staff has the Committee on Professional Qualifications.
(8) How many persons had their qualifications (a) recognised or (b) rejected in each year by the Committee since its constitution, what was their country of origin and what was the profession.
Mr Macphee-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) The Committee on Overseas Professional Qualifications was established in 1969 to assist in the recognition of professional qualifications obtained overseas. In 1978 its terms of reference were expanded to include sub-professional, technical and general academic qualifications.
The Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act, passed in 1946, provides for the recognition of certain types of trade qualifications: it is administered by the Department of Industrial Relations.
No provisions have been made at the national level for the recognition of non-TRRA trade qualifications.
In addition, I recently announced, following consultation with my State and Territorial counterparts, that a wide ranging review of the problerns faced by migrants and refugees in obtaining recognition of their qualifications would be undertaken. The review will commence shortly.
(2) Statistics are not maintained on this subject.
(3) Statistics are not maintained on this subject.
(4) Statistics are not maintained on this subject.
(5) Procedures for the recognition of qualifications and the provision of labour market information are under constant review so as to ensure that there is adequate information and advice available to overseas posts on the acceptability of overseas qualifications, and the demand for them in Australia. However, no mechanisms exist to follow-up people once they have arrived in Australia.
(6) Advice normally given to me by State Governments and trade unions is that overseas qualifications are accepted when the decision-making body is confident that the individual concerned has reached the standard of professional, semiprofessional or trade competence required of people who obtain their qualifications in Australia. No doubt this question will be studied in detail by the review body already referred to.
(7) The Committee on Overseas Professional Qualifications has 21 full time positions in its secretariat, provided by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs: 18 of these positions are currently occupied.
(8) Statistics are not maintained on this subject.
Australian Council on PopUlation and Ethnic Affairs
(Question No. 3591)
Mr Young asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

Answers to Questions

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3131

(I) On what basis were the members of the Australian Council on Population and Ethnic Affairs chosen.
(2) How many of the members can claim that they actually represent the ethnic community's view in their advice to him.
(3) On what basis does his Department make its recommendations of persons to be appointed to various committees.
(4) Does his Department have an undue influence on a committee considering that it provides the secretarial services and therefore the back-up and research materials for a committee.
Mr Macphee-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Members of the Australian Council on Population and Ethnic Affairs are appointed in their own right as individuals whose particular expertise and qualifications reflect the terms of reference and range of activities of the Council.
Membership of the Council rellects a wide range of community interests, including ethnic groups, service organisations, trade unions, industry and commerce. Several members are academics in disciplines closely related to the socio-economic aspects of population growth and the settlement of migrants and refugees. In addition the Opposition Spokesman on Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, and the Chairman of the Government Members Committee on Immigration and Ethnic Affairs are invited to attend Council Meetings as Parliamentary observers.
(2) Although members are not chosen specifically to represent the ethnic community some nine members, that is half the Council membership, are either actively involved in ethnic affairs or are able to express an ethnic community viewpoint. A list of the current membership of the Council is below.
(3) I presume that the honourable member is referring to membership of the Task Forces through which the Council pursues specific objectives determined by the Councilor myself. Current Task Forces deal with the Migration Program, Population, Ethnic Affairs Policy, Citizenship and Refugees.
Membership of the Task Forces is determined by the Full Council, on the basis of the particular expertise or interest of members in the matters to be considered by each Task Force.
(4) The Council is particularly mindful of the need to provide me with independent advice and is neither unduly influenced by nor bound to accept material provided by my Department in formulating this advice. This is something I value greatly.
The secretariat, research and other information services provided to the Council by my Department form part of the resources drawn upon by the Council in formulating its advice to me. Other elements in this process are considerations with migrants and other community groups and exchanges with relevant advisory bodies and Government organisations.

Australia Post Courier Service
(Question No. 3582)
Mr Young asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:
(I) Did his Department allocate $30,000 for the Australia Post courier service in 1980-81.
(2) Has $30,000 been allocated for Australia Post express charges in 1981-82.
(3) If so, what way does that represent a 43 per cent increase, as indicated in his Department's estimates of expenditure explanatory notes.
Mr Macphee-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) In 1980-81 the Department used the services of Australia Post Courier and private organisations covered by Commonwealth Contracts for the delivery of parcels and other freight. In accordance with Finance Directions expenditure on private organisations was chargeable to item 360.2.08 Freight and Cartage while expenditure for Australia Post Courier was chargeable to item 360.2.03 Postage, Telegrams and Telephone services which included $30,000 for that purpose.
(2) The Department of Finance has directed that costs for Australia Post Express which replaced Australia Post Courier will be a charge against item 360.2.08 in 1981-82 and an amount of $30,000 has been provided in that vote.
(3) The amount provided in item 360.2.08 for 1981-82 is $116,000 which represents an increase of 43.2 per cent over the 1980-81 expenditure in that item. As stated in the Department's explanatory notes $30,000 of that amount is a transfer from 360.2.03. If this is excluded the increased provision for freight is $4,976 or approximately six per cent.

Immigration: Timorese
(Question No. 3584)
Mr Young asked for the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:
Further to his answer to my question No. 2444 ( Hansard, 20 August 1981, page 662), (a) how many Timorese were on the agreed list, (b) of this number how many have been reunited with their families in Australia and (c) how many of those on the agreed list who have arrived in Australia are full blooded Timorese.
Mr Macphee-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(a) A total of 625 persons were on the list of East Timorese whose entry to Australia was agreed between the Australian and Indonesian Governments in 1978.
(b) By 31 October 1981, 350 of these had arrived.
(c) Statistics of the ethnicity of migrants are not collected.
Australian Federal Police
Mr Newman-On 29 October 1981 (Hansard, page 2671), Mr Mildren asked the Acting Minister for Administrative Services the following question without notice:

I refer the Acting Minister for Administrative Services to the Minister's responsibility to the Australian Federal Police. I ask: In what circumstances does the Minister relinquish to other Ministers his responsibility to the Federal Police? Did he formally relinquish this responsibility to the Minister for Primary Industry in the Federal Police investigation into the Australian Dairy Corporation and Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd? In this instance, have the Australian Federal Police reported only to the Minister for Primary Industry and not to the Minister for Administrative Services? Is it a regular practice that Ministers other than the Minister for Administrative Services are responsible for the conduct of police inquiries into activities for which those Ministers themselves are ultimately responsible, or was special exemption made for National Country Party Ministers?
The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
By administrative arrangements ordered by the Governor General in Council I administer the Australian Federal Police Act 1979, except for certain limited sections administered by my colleagues, the Ministers for Industrial Relations and Capital Territory. I do not relinquish this responsibility, except to an Acting Minister when ordered by the Governor General in Council.
Sir Robert Mark in his Report to the Minister for Administrative Services on the Organisation of Police Resources in the Commonwealth area and other related matters, stated that the AFP should be and be seen to be operationally independent from political influence and yet be and seen to be administratively accountable to the Governmemt.
This principle of administrative accountability yet operational independence is embodied in the Australian Federal Police Act which delineates the relationship between the Commissioner of the AFP and the Minister given the portfolio responsibility for the AFP, inter alia, as follows:
'13. (I) Subject to this Act, the Commissioner has the general administration of, and the control of the operations of, the Australian Federal Police.
(2) The Minister may, after obtaining and considering the advice of the Commissioner and of the Secretary (of the Department of Administrative Services), give written directions to the Commissioner with respect to the general policy to be pursued in relation to the performance of the functions of the Australian Federal Police.
(6) The Commissioner shall furnish to the Minister such reports as the Minister requests relating to the administration and the performance of the functions of the Australian Federal Police.'
These legislative arrangements support the underlying responsibility of the police to enforce the law and be accountable for their actions to the courts.
Consistent with these arrangements, in relation to the particular police inquiry referred to by the honourable member, a brief was forwarded to the Crown Solicitor for advice as to whether prosecution action should be taken and the results of the inquiry were provided to the complainant-in this case the Department of Primary Industry-and to me for information.
Trade Practices Act
(Question No. 727)
Mr Hurford asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 5 March 1981:
(I) Has his attention been drawn to the criticisms contained in the Trade Practices Consultative Committee's Report of the effectiveness of the monopolisation provisions of the Trade Practices Act.

Answers to Questions

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3133

(2) [s he concerned by the criticisms; if not, why not.
(3) [f he is concerned, will he ensure at the very minimum that the Government will act to implement without further delay the recommendations of the Committee concerning section 46 of the Act.
(4) Was the report referred to in part (I) received by the Government in December 1979; if so, why has he and the Government so far failed to act on this and other recommendations contained in that report on the relationship between the Trade Practices Act and small business.
Mr Moore-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I), (2) and (3)-The Trade Practices Consultative Committee recommended an amendment to section 46 of the Trade Practices Act which is considered would change, and extend, the basis of application of that section. The Government has decided not to adopt that recommendation. After very careful examination of the proposal, the Government was not satisfied that its adoption would benefit small business. Further, it considered that the proposal could lead to uncertainty and thereby inhibit quite legitimate and proper competition. The Government will of course, continue to monitor the operation of section 46.
(4) Yes; the report raised a number of complex issues for consideration and after very careful examination the Government has decided, in additional to the matter referred to above, on the following course:
The Government will not implement the Committee's recommendation that section 49 be repealed. The Government considers that the section has an important role in regulating anti-competitive price discrimination and is of particular benefit to small business.
The Trade Practices Act will be amended to provide protection from intimidation to persons providing information to the Trade Practices Commission.
The Trade Practices Commission has already taken action to enhance its information program and this action is supported by the Government.
The Government will not be increasing the amount of legal aid being made available to assist small business take private actions under Part [V of the Act. The Government is satisfied that funds currently made available are adequate.
Before any action is taken on the Committee's proposal to introduce franchise legislation, the Government requires further information on franchising and franchising practices. The Department of Business and Consumer Affairs will conduct further studies into franchising.
A seperate announcement will be made on whether lower courts are to have jurisdiction in matters under the Trade Practices Act.
Dispensing Pharmacy at Melba, Australian Capital Territory
(Question No. 758)
Mr Hodges asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 11 March 1981:

Development of Banana Plantation in Western Samoa
(Question No. 1643)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 9 April 1981 :

3134 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Answers to Questions

(I) Did the Prime Minister of Western Samoa state that costs of development of a banana plantation in Western Samoa were solely the responsibility of the Australian Government.
(2) What sum has been expended by Australia on this project to date.
(3) What monitoring and accounting of expenditure is and has been made by the Australian Government.
(4) What income has been derived from the plantation.
(5) What advisory fees have been paid in respect of the project and to whom.
Mr Street-The honourable member's question was referred to the Western Samoa Government for information and advice before preparation of a reply. The honourable member will no doubt be aware that a public service strike commenced in Western Samoa on 6 April 1981 and continued for approximately twelve weeks. The Western Samoan authorities have consequently only recently provided the information requested.
The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) The Western Samoa Government has advised that the Prime Minister did not make this statement.
(2) For 1979-80 and 1980-81 some $493,000 of the Development Import Grant allocation has been utilised by Western Samoa to purchase goods and services in Australia to assist with development of a banana plantation.
(3) Under the guidelines for Development Import Grants, competitive tenders are called in Australia by the recipient government or its appointed agent. Copies are sent to the Australian Development Assistance Bureau. The letting of contracts is the responsibility of the recipient government which is required to follow similar guidelines to those for Australian Government procurement. Payment is made to the Reserve Bank by the Bureau and is released for payment of claims on evidence that the goods and services have been supplied in accordance with the conditions laid down in the Memorandum of Understanding.
(4) The Western Samoa Government advises that from January 1980 to July 1981 net sales were WS $175, III. .
(5) An amount of $79,708 was paid by the Western Samoa Government for consultancy services of a banana plantation manager and quality control officer. This payment was part of the total DIGs amount spent by Western Samoa over two consecutive years.
Cocos Island Quarantine Station
(Question No. 1700)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Health, upon notice; on 9 April 1981 :
(I) Have charges been determined for stock passing through the Cocos Island quarantine station when it is completed; if so, what will be the charges; if not, when is it likely the charges will be made pUblic.
(2) Will he upgrade the figures given in answer to Question No. 543 (Hansard, 2 May 1978, page 1671) which showed estimates of the annual operating costs and receipts of the Cocos Island quarantine station.
(3) Will he also upgrade the estimate given in answer to Question No. 544 (Hansard, 2 May 1978, page 1671) of the costs to an importer of bringing adult cattle from Europe

through the Cocos Island quarantine station excluding the value of the animal and transport costs.
Mr MacKellar-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes, quarantine charges have been determined for cattle being imported into Australia through the Cocos Islands Animal Quarantine Station. The quarantine fee that has been set is calculated to recover the operational costs of the Station for the period of quarantine the cattle are required to serve. In the case of cattle from North America/Canada the quarantine fee has been set at $11.50 per day per head of cattle. As these animals are required to serve a minimum quarantine period of 90 days a total fee of $1,035 per head of cattle will be payable. Fees are subject to review annually.
Information concerning these charges has been circularised to all cattle breed societies, prospective importers and interested parties. Fees for other species of livestock will be determined as the need arises.
(2) Set out below is an updated table showing estimates of expenditure and receipts. The 1980-81 figures have been provided in the same format as figures previously set out in the response to Question No. 543 of 8 March 1978.

1980-81

It should be noted that the 1980-81 projected figures were based on three shipments of approximately 90 cattle per consignment over the first 12 months, two from the USA/Canada and one from Western Europe.
(3) The present estimate of costs to an importer to bring adult cattle from Europe through the Cocos Islands Station excluding the value of the animal and transport costs would be $3,500-$4,000. This estimate includes the quarantine fee of $1,725 (i.e. 150 days at $11.50 per day) and an estimated cost of $2,000 for testing and on-farm isolation in Europe.

Answers to Questions

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3135

European cattle have longer quarantine periods and consequently higher quarantine charges than do North American/ Canadian cattle mentioned in answer to question (I).
Quarantine Inspection of Imported Goods
(Question No. 1702)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:
Have systematic additional random inspections to assess the effectiveness and efficiency of quarantine inspection of imported goods been carried out as recommended in the report entitled 'Review of Australian Quarantine Arrangements' prepared by the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet in 1976; ifso, what were the results of inspections.
Mr Mackellar-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
My Department has advised that the recommendation referred to was not taken up because it became apparent, after careful consideration, that quarantine screening and other procedures for imported goods did not lend themselves to the systematic, randomly based evaluation techniques proposed.
As indicated in the recommendation referred to, the quarantine arrangements applying to goods imported into Australia are self regulating to an extent. Quarantine procedures for particular goods from different countries are determined in the light of assessments of the pest and disease risks which these goods present. If any matters of quarantine significance are located during routine or random inspections which are not already catered for, appropriate corrective measures are taken immediately to meet any perceived risk. These measures may involve mandatory treatments, new or increased levels of inspection for particular goods, or a shift in the emphasis of quarantine screening arrangements. Where inspections indicate, for example, inaccuracies in documentation, goods of similar origin are subject to particular attention in the future.
This approach ensures that quarantine procedures are in effect, subject to continuous review and as far as practicable, kept up to date with quarantine needs.
Registration of Chiropractors
(Question No. 1710)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:
(I) Are qualified chiropractors required to be registered in the Australian Capital Territory; if so, under what Ordinance.
(2) Are qualified chiropractors eligible to vote or contest elections for any of the Boards referred to in the 'Health Professions Board (Elections) Ordinance 1980'; if not, why not.
(3) Will he arrange for registration in the Australian Captial Territory of chiropractors possessing qualifications similar to those now recognised for registration purposes in Western Australia.
Mr MacKellar-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) No.
(2) No. A health professional is only qualified to contest and vote in an election conducted in respect of a Board covering his or her profession. Because there is no board covering chiropractic in the Australian Capital Territory, there are no related elections in which chiropractors may participate.
(3) An Ordinance for the purpose of registering chiropractors and osteopaths in the Australian Capital Territory is expected to be introduced later this year. Under this proposed

legislation a chiropractor will be entitled to apply for registration if-

he is a fit and proper person to be registered as a chiropractor,

he has an adequate knowledge of the English language, and

(a) he holds a qualification in chiropractic granted by an

institution in a State or Territory after a course of

study and training that is recognised by the registration

-authority in that State or Territory; or

(b) he holds a qualification in chiropractic-

(i) that is granted by an institution in a place outside

Australia and that would entitle him to be regis-

tered in that place under a law of that place pro-

viding for the registration of chiropractors; and

(ii) that is a qualification declared by the Minister, on

the recommendation of the Board, by notice

published in the Gazelle, to be an acceptable

qualification; or

(c) (i) he lodges an application within six months after

the date of commencement of the Ordinance;

(ii) he has within the period of five years immediately

preceding the date on which he lodges his appli-

cation with the Board, practised chiropractic in

the Territory for a period of, or periods totalling,

not less than 12 months; and

.

(iii) he has passed to the satisfaction of the Board an

examination conducted by or on behalf of the

Board in accordance with a determination made,

on the recommendation of the Board, by the Min-

ister and published by notice in the Gazelle.

Animal Diseases
(Question No. 1726)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 April1981:
(I) Is Australia and its territories currently free of (a) scrapie, (b) anthrax, (c) Newcastle, (d) rabies, (e) blue tongue and (f) foot and mouth diseases.
(2) If not, what incidents or outbreaks of each disease have been reported during the last three years, and what was the source of the infection in each case.
(3) If Australia is free of each disease, when was the last infection of each in Australia or its territories reported.
Mr MacKellar-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Australia is free from scrapie, rabies and foot and mouth disease. However anthrax, and avirulent strains of Newcastle disease virus and bluetongue virus have been reported here.
(2) The following diseases or disease agents have been reported in Australia during the past three years.
Newcastle disease-An avirulent Newcastle disease virus was first isolated in 1965 and is still present in Australian birds. This virus does not cause clinical disease. The source of the virus is not known.
Bluetongue-Several isolations of viruses which, by definition, fall within the bluetongue group have been made in Australia. None has been demonstrated to cause clinical disease. The sources of these viruses are unknown but from serological evidence it appears that some have been in Australia for many years.
Anthrax-Anthrax is believed to have made its first appearance in New South Wales about 1847. It is currently confined to isolated areas of New South Wales and Victoria.
(3) The following diseases have been reported or suspected in Australia in the past but have not been reported within the past three years.
Scrapie-Scrapie was diagnosed in 1952 in a small flock of Suffolk sheep imported from the United Kingdom twelve months earlier. The sheep and their progeny and all in-contact sheep were slaughtered and the area left unstocked for twelve months. It has not recurred in Australia.
Rabies-In Hobart in February 1867 a boy died 29 days after being bitten on the lip by a dog. Opinions expressed at the time indicated that several cases of a disease resembling rabies had occurred in dogs, and at least one pig, in the area.The affected animals were destroyed and a clean up of stray dogs was carried out by the local Municipal Council. Reports published at the time leave little doubt that the disease was rabies.
In 1883 a health officer in New South Wales reported several instances in which dogs presented the symptoms of rabies. No human case was reported and no later reports were made.
Foot and mouth disease-The only certain occurrence of foot and mouth disease in Australia was an outbreak in'Victoria in 1872 following the importation of eight bulls from

England. The diagnosis was confirmed by several veterinary surgeons. The outbreak was confined to two properties and was successfully eradicated by slaughter.
Trade Practices Act
(Question No. 1950)
Mr Hurford asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:
(I) Further to the report of the Trade Practices Consultative Committee on the operation of the Trade Practices Act in relation to primary production in Australia, is it a fact that the Consultative Committee's case against the Banana Growers Federation was adjourned following a statutory direction to the Commission by the then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs on IS September 1978.
(2) If so, was the reason given at the time for the seeking of the adjournment that the Government needed time to consider the report of the Consultative Committee.
(3) Was the Consultative Committee's report presented to the then Minister in May 1979.
(4) If so, what action has the Government taken on the report.
(5) Will the Government act on the report; if not, why not.
(6) Will the Government compensate any party who has suffered financial loss from the Government's delay in considering the report or the resultant continued adjournment of the Banana growers case.
(7) To what instances did the Trade Practices Commission refer at Paragraph 4.4.6 of its annual report for 1979-80 when it stated that other primary industry cases are being held up until the Government takes a decision on the Committee's report.
Mr Moore-The answer to thehcinourable member's question is as follows: .
(I) The Trade Practices Commission's case against the Banana Growers' Federation was generally stood over after the then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs gave a direction on 15 Septem])er 1978.
(2) Yes.
(3) Yes.
(4) and (5) As I announced on IS November 1981, the Government has decided to adopt guidelines for use in determining whether or not to grant exemptions under paragraph 172(2) (a) of the Trade Practices Act. The principal features of the guidelines are that-
Exemption is to be limited to sections 45, 458 (both dealing with agreements) and 47 (exclusive dealing) (other than section 47 (6), (7), (8)(c) and (9)(d.
Exemptions are to operate for a maximum of five years, but will be capable of renewal, where appropriate, following further examination.
Exemptions must be necessary for promoting stability in the production or marketing of primary products or for purposes connected with export marketing.
An exempted scheme must be capable of achieving these purposes and involve the least reduction in competition necessary to achieve those objectives.
Other than in unforseen or exceptional circumstances, the Government will not consider any request for exemption where proceedings under the Act have been commenced in respect of conduct sought to be exempted. There will however be a period of grace. The Government will consider requests

Answers to Questions

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3137

for exemption already made, or made within the next three months.
The Government will now proceed to examine all applications for exemption, including the request from the Banana Growers' Federation. The direction to the Trade Practices Commission to have proceedings in the Federal Court against the Federation stood over will be continued, to enable the application for exemption to be determined.
(6) No.
(7) The Trade Practices Commission makes it a practice to not pUblicise the names of companies or industry organizations against whom allegations or complaints are made, .because the Commission is not in a position to know whether the allegations are well founded until its investigations are complete. The references in paragraph 4.4.6 of the Commission's annual report for 1979-80 were to two other primary industry cases in respect of which the Commission had deferred its investigations pending the Government's decision on the Committee's report.
South Africa: Use offacilities at North West Cape
(Question No. 2073)
Mr Robert Brown asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:
(I) Has his attention been drawn to a newspaper article in the Sydney Morning Hearald of 24 April 1981 entitled 'Why South Africa could be plugged into North West Cape'.
(2) Can Australian authorities identify coded messages sent through the communications channels as originating in a particular country.
(3) If so, what third country users (a) use or (b) have used the Cape facilities.
(4) Can he give an assurance that South Africa has never used facilities at the Cape.
Mr KiIlen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes.
(2) No, unless an Australian authority is part of the message address.
(3) .(a) and (b) The only third countries to have used the station's 'facilities have been the United Kingdom, New Zealand, Italy and the Netherlands. This use has been arranged when Naval ships of those countries have been operating in the Indian Ocean area.
There are no records of any third country messages being relayed through North West Cape as part of US message traffic. Although this possibility is improbable, it cannot be completely ruled out, but in any case South Africa has not had common user access to the Allied defence communications system since 1972.
(4) See answer to part (3).
Use of North West Cape Facilities
(Question No. 2195)
Mr Morrison asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 May 1981:
(I) Which countries, apart from Australia and the United States of America, have had use of the North West Cape facilities under Article IV of the Agreement as interpreted in the agreed minutes.
(2) What were the periods of use by each country.

(3) Does the United States advise the Australian authorities of the identity of third country governments whose communications are accepted into the United States channels for transmission through the North West Cape facilities.
Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) 'and (2) The facilities at North West Cape have been made available for three ships of the Royal Navy (in 1975, 1977 and 1979), two of the Royal New Zealand Navy (in 1976 and 1980), one of the Italian Navy (1979) and four of the Royal Dutch Navy (1979).
There are no records of any third country messages being relayed through North West Cape as part of US. message traffic. Although this possibility is improbable, it cannot be completely ruled out.
(3) No. Such messages would be regarded as United States communications.

(4) What is the anticipated (a) extra cost or (b) saving resulting from the termination of the MANDATA System.

I refer the honourable member to the answer to Question No. 2209 which he asked of the Prime Minister and provide the following additional information in relation to my Department.
(I) Yes.
(a) (i) Nil.
(ii) $9,200.
(iii) $100.
(iv) Nil.
(v) $36,900. Includes cost of relocation of equipment, overtime, stationery and travel expenses associated with training and implementation.
(b) $46,200.
(2) No.
(3) It is expected that there will be some staff savings with the introduction of the computerised alternative being developed (See 4 below). The level of staff savings cannot be identified until the precise nature and operation of the new system are finalised.
(4) (a) $55,000 during 1981-82 for the development and operation by ADAPS Limited, of an interim computerised alternative. $40,000 during 1981-82 for the development by external consultants, of a long-term computerised alternative

Answers to Questions

Pesticides: Use in Australian Agriculture
(Question No. 2729)
Mr Holding asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:
(I) Has his attention been drawn to the statement that label directions safeguard the user, consumer, general public and environment by specifying the possible hazards associated with incorrect usage contained on page iii of the Report entitled 'Pesticides Used in Vietnam Hostilities and their Use in Australian Agriculture: A Comparative Study' if so, for what reason is possible irritation of the skin and eyes the only hazard listed on the labels of both Farmco D-80 Selective 2,4-D Weedkiller, produced by Chemical Industries, Kwinana, and Estercide 80 2,4-D herbicide, produced by Nufarm Chemicals Pty Ltd, when the same report listed the symptoms, described in scientific and medical literature, as being associated with 2,4-D as being (a) ex:cessive fatigue, (b) epigastric pains, (c) anorex:ia, (d) upper respiratory tract symptoms, (e) impaired taste sensitivity, (f) liver disease, (g) peripheral neuropathy and (h) contact dermatitis.
(2) [s he able to say whether the symptoms and conditions listed on page 6 of the report referred to in part (I) as being tox:ic effects of TCOD (diox:in) in man are all contained on labels of any product containing 2,4,5-T sold in Australia; if not, why not.
Mr MacKellar-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes. Although State regulatory authorities carry responsibility for labelling of pesticides they closely follow the recommendations of the National Health and Medical Research Council's Uniform Poisons Standard. The herbicide 2,4-D is included in schedule 5 of that standard as a substance having a very low tox:icity. In this regard label warnings of possible skin and eye irritation are consistent with effects encountered in long ex:perience with the use of this material in cases where adequate care in usage has not been ex:ercised. The possibility of the additional adverse health symptoms from incorrect usage of 2,4-D, detailed in the report entitled 'Pesticides Used in Vietnam Hostilities and Their Use in Australian Agriculture: A Comparative Study', is ex:tremely remote and could be ex:pected to follow only massive ex:posure such as accidental or deliberate ingestion.
(2) Products containing 2,4,5-T sold in Australia are not labelled with tox:ic effects allegedly attributable to TCDD in man. The results of ex:tensive scientific investigation carried out to date do not indicate the likelihood of any such effects occurring in man through normal usage of substances incorporating 2,4,5-T.
Pensioners' Non-interest Bearing Accounts
(Question No. 2891)
Mrs Darling asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 27 August 1981:
(I) Has the Department of Social Security prepared an estimate of the amount of savings of pensioners held in noninterest bearing accounts in banks and other financial institutions as a direct result of the existence of means tests on pensions.
(2) [s this placement of their savings by pensioners regarded by the Department as a fraudulent attempt to deprive themselves of ex:tra income for the purpose of obtaining full or higher rates of pension or fringe benefits; if so, does the Department intend taking recovery action against all pensioners with savings in non-interest bearing savings accounts.

(3) Is it a fact that in some cases pensioners are depriving themselves of thousands of dollars of interest and other extra income in order to qualify for fringe benefits within the means test.
(4) Is the Minister able to say whether this action has resulted in an enormous bonus to financial institutions in which pensioners have invested their savings interest free.
(5) [s it a fact that the pension means test has not been increased for eight years; if so, is this largely the cause of pensioners placing interest free deposits with financial institutions.
(6) What would the pension means test be if it had been increased in line with consumer price index increases during the last eight years.
Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(I) The payment of pensions in Australia is subject to an income test, not a means test. The means test, which took account of the value of assets owned as well as certain forms of income received, ceased to be applied on 25 November 1976.
The Department of Social Security has not made any estimate of the amount of savings held by pensioners in noninterest bearing forms.
(2) No. The income test is a mechanism designed to ensure that welfare funds are directed to those in greatest financial need. However, the income test is being circumvented by a proportion of people who are forgoing the receipt of income available th~ough the normal and reasonable investment of their funds. In this way welfare funds are being misdirected to certain people who are not in need of assistance.
As pointed out in my second reading speech on the Social Services Amendment Bill 1981 people will be able to retain reasonable amounts in non-interest bearing accounts without being affected in any way by the proposed amendments to the Social Services Act. As a minimum these amounts will be not less than $2000 for a single person or $3000. for a married couple.
(3) Some pensioners do forgo considerable amounts of income.
(4) To the ex:tent that financial institutions are able to borrow funds free of charge, their profit margins would indeed be increased.
(5) Permissible income limits were last increased as from October 1972; however, since that date the upper limit of income which a pensioner may have before he ceases to be eligible for some pension has increased from $60 to $159.40 a week in the case of a single pensioner, and from $103.50 to $266.90 a week for a pensioner couple.
While it is evident that there is a growing incidence of pensioners artificially rearranging their affairs in order to qualify for pensions, to increase existing entitlements or to qualify for fringe benefits, it is not possible to attribute this to any single cause.
(6) If the present income limits were increased by the movement in the consumer price index: (CPI) from the September quarter 1972 to the June quarter 1981, they would become (rounded to the nearest five cents)-
(a) $51.45 a week for a single person;
(b) $44.40 a week for a married person.

Answers to Questions

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3141

Hospital Bed Days: Alcohol-related Illness
(Question No. 3004)
Dr Blewett asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 September 1981:
(I) What is the estimated number of hospital bed days and the cost of this hospitalisation due to alcohol-related illness and injury and as a proportion of total bed days and costs.
(2) Are there any other estimated health costs to the country of alcohol-related illness and injury, for example, days lost through sickness.
(3) Are there any other related figures available on this problem, for example, prison admissions, etc.
Mr MacKellar-The honourable member will be aware that State health authorities do not routinely collect data on alcohol-related illness and injuries in morbidity data. However, in an effort to assist the honourable member as fully as possible, I have been advised that the following estimates are believed to be indicative:
(I) A. T. Williams, F. Harding Burns, and S. Morey, in their paper, 'Prevelance of Alcoholism in a Sydney Teaching Hospital', Medical Journal of Australia, 1978,2,608-611, and C. M. Peterson's 'Inpatient population and alcohol abuse', St Vincents Hospital Sydney, 1977-78, unpublished, suggested that in the order of 10 per cent of acute hospital beds may be filled with persons suffering from alcohol-related illnesses. Based on information available from public psychiatric hospitals, about 15 per cent or so of beds, not occupied by mentally retarded patients, appear to be used by people with a diagnosis of alcoholism or alcoholic psychosis. This estimate does not allow for those who are additionally treated by special institutions for people with alcohol-related problems or private institutions.
Extrapolation of these figures would indicate that between 2 million and 3 million public hospital bed days per annum could be involved in caring for people with alcohol-related problems. This would indicate an annual cost in the order of $220 to $300 million in public acute hospitals for 1977-78.
(2) There are no reliable estimates of the cost to the community of working days lost through alcohol-related sickness or injury. The NH & MRC estimated that, in 1972, the loss of potential earnings through premature deaths associated with alcohol was approximately $120 million per annum and the cost of alcohol-related traffic accidents was about $500 million annually (in 1972 terms).
L. Halchenko (Costs of Alcoholism in Industry in Australia, 1974-75, AFADD) estimated that, in 1975, alcohol related absenteeism cost industry $46 million each year.
(3) No studies have been made to enable an accurate estimate of the cost of alcohol-related crime to the community to be calculated. Evidence available from E. Oits, The Relationship between Alcohol and Violent Crime', Roneoed Material Chief Secretary's Office, Victorian Government; B. Roslund and C. Larson, 'Crimes of Violence and Alcohol Abuse in Sweden', International Journal of Addictions, 14, 8, 1103-1115, 1979; and N. Parker, 'Murderers'; a personal series', Medical Journal of Australia, 1,36-39,1979, suggests at least half, and possibly 75 per cent, of all violent crime is associated with alcohol use.
L. H. Drew, in 'Personal Responsibility and Alcohol Problems', Nursing Times, September 1976, estimated that, in 1972-73, alcohol related crime cost $120 million in a year direct outlay through the judicial and penitentiary system.

each Statutory Authority.

(c) 15 females and 2 males.

as follows:

Department of Health . . . . . .

Health Insurance Commission

Australian-based Coinpanies in the Philippines
(Question No. 3069)
Mr Howe asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 10 August 1981:
(I) Has his attention been drawn to reports of the shooting, on 5 July 1981 at the military prison camp Tolentino, Balango, Bataan, The Philippines, of 3 Union organisers, Emiliano Paguio, Antonio Santa Ana and Vivencio Santos who were under arrest after being charged with spurious offences of subversion and boycotting the presidential elections in that country.
(2) Has his attention also been drawn to the reports that the charges of subversion reiate to work by these Union organisers, designed merely to improve intolerable working conditions in factories owned and operated by Australian companies, in particular Denzil Don, a subsidiary of Dunlop (Aust) which is administered from Melbourne, Ford Philippines Stamping Plant which is also administered directly from the Ford Asia-Pacific office in Melbourne and Southern Star Billiards, an Australian-owned company.
(3) If so, will he express his concern to the Philippine Government about this matter.

3142 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Answers to Questions

(4) Should Australian-based companies operate in an area such as The Philippines where this treatment is allegedly meted out to Union officials.
Mr. Street-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes. Extensive enquiries by our Embassy in Manilla, through a number of different sources, about these allegations which you and others have passed to me have so far only been able to confirm the apparent disappearance of the three people-Jemiliana Paguio, Antonio Sta Ana and Vivencio Santos.
(2) Officers of our Embassy in Manilla, who recently visited the Bataan Export Processing Zone reported that the companies with Australian ownership or connections have not themselves specifically been the targets of action by workers or unions with which Paguio and Sta Ana are said to have been associated. As far as the Embassy officers could ascertain, these companies met Philippine labour code and wage requirements and they were told that the companies enjoy a reputation for fair dealing. Our Embassy understands that Vivencio Santos was arrested for alleged offences in connection with the boycott of the Presidential election of 16 June. He is understood not to have had any association with either unions at the Bataan Export Processing Zone or Australian companies in the Philippines.
(3) The Philippine Government is already aware of the Australian Government's views on human rights matters. Successive Australian Governments have placed clearly on record Australia's support for the principles set out in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.
(4) The location of Australia-based private companies is a matter for the companies.
Child Care Services: Means Test
(Question No, 3097)
Mrs Darling asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 15 September 1981:
(I) Will a means test apply on the provision of child care services; if so, what will the means test consist of.
(2) Were members of parliament invited to make submissions to the Minister or the Department of Social Security in respect of child care; if so, did any Member of Parliament make a submission.
(3) If submissions were made by Members of Parliament what was the nature of each of the submissions.
(4) Is it normal practice for the Department of Social Security to conduct reviews of its policy based on reviews undertaken by Government backbench Members of Parliament.
Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(I) All child care services funded.by the Commonwealth Government are currently required to apply a sliding scale of

fees to ensure that those in the greatest financial need receive the greatest benefit from government subsidies to such services. My department is currently examining the feasibility of introducing a common income test for all subsidised child care services, both centre-based and family-based. I have undertaken that consultations will occur with organisations in this process.
(2) to (4) I have instituted a number of reviews of Department of Social Security programs, involving the Social Welfare Policy Secretariat, officers of my department and parliamentary colleagues. These are entirely internal and are part of the continuing process of policy review undertaken by the Government within the Department.
The recently completed examination of the Children's Services Program is one such exercise. The recommendations made by the review group are internal working documents which will be subject to consideration by the Government.
Submissions were not invited from members of parliament.

Agent Orange: Information from Ex-Serviceman
(Question No, 3104)

Dr Cass asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 15 September 1981:
When seeking information from ex-servicemen and their families as part of the study into the effects of Agent Orange, is privacy between husband and wife protected; if not, how can the information elicited be accepted as accurate.

Mr MacKellar-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

Yes. The recently enacted Epidemiological Studies (Confidentiality) Act 1981 covers the husband and wife situation.
