Medical Fund Rates
(Question No, 3184)
Dr Blewett asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 22 September 1981:
(1) Did registered private health funds lose over $190m in the full year following the Government's 1976 health insurance changes.
(2) [fso, was it unrealistically low medical fund rates which mainly contributed to this loss.
(3) [s it anticipated that similar losses will occur following the latest health changes, due to the unrealistically low rate increase he has approved, particularly in New South Wales.
(4) When does he estimate the next round of rate increases will occur.
Mr MacKellar-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) The health insurance arrangements were revised with effect from I October 1976. For the twelve months ended 30 June 1978 registered medical benefits organisations and registered hospital benefits organisations incurred operating deficits of $175.2m and $15.lm, respectively, resulting in a combined operating deficit of $190.3m. However, after taking non-operating income into account, medical benefits organisations recorded a total deficit of $164.4m and hospital benefits organisations made a total surplus of $Il.lm, resulting in a combined total deficit of $153:3m.
(2) With the benefit of hindsight, it is clear that the contribution rates charged by the medical funds from I October 1976 were generally inadequate to meet total commitments. The operating deficits coming from the built up reserves of the health insurance organisations were of course used for the benefit of contributors through the lower contribution rates paid. It should be pointed out, however, that at the time the I October 1976 rates were set there was a considerable degree of uncertainty about the future claims utilisation by contributors, due to the lack of up-to-date and relevant data. (Health funds were not involved in the payment of basic medical benefits between July 1975 and September I 976, inclusive.)
It was generally considered that the best available data on which to base new contribution rates were those available in respect of the period up to 30 June 1975, when most Australians were insured privately. However, these data proved to be unreliable as the claims utilisation rate was significantly higher in 1977-78 than in 1974-75. This could well have been due to the Medibank Standard medical benefits being paid from I July 1975 to 30 September 1976 without the need for medical insurance, thus generating a heavy demand for services by consumers and extensive increases by providers.
(3) Unlike the situation in 1976, the contribution rates effective from I September 1981 were based on recent and reliable data. These provided a sound basis for forecasts of the outcomes of the rates. Whilst there is always some uncertainty

attached to proposals based on assumptions about future trends, [am optimistic that the contribution rates now in force in New South Wales will be variable for the various funds at current levels of charges and benefits. However the New South Wales Government has recently announced its decision to increase public hospital charges by 20 per cent from I January 1981. This means, for example, that the inpatient accommodation charge per day will rise by $16 from $80 to $96 per day. If the basic hospital benefits are to partly or wholly cover the increased charges then clearly there must be an increase in contribution rates.
(4) It is not expected that across-the-board increases in contribution rates will be necessary until the next general increases in either hospital charges or Schedule medical fees. It may be necessary to review hospital contribution rates in States which decide to increase public hospital charges in the same way as New South Wales before the next general increase in charges. Allowance was made for increases in Schedule medical fees in November 1981 when the contribution rates from I September 1981 were set. I should point out that the financial experience of the respective health insurance organisations often varies considerably. Where it is necessary to ensure that continuing viability of a fund, an organisation may at any time apply for approval to increase contribution rates.
Nowra Region Flight Manoeuvres
(Question No. 3187)
Mr Scholes asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 22 September 1981:
(I) Has his attention been drawn to compliants from Nowra residents concerning Hight manoeuvres in airspace over the residential areas in the Nowra region.
(2) Has there been any inquiry into operations in airspace over residential areas following these complaints.
(3) If so, have these inquiries shown any breach of current operational airspace regulations, or the need for a review of current operational airspace areas or regulations.
Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes.
(2) Yes.
(3) No. However, the validity of these regulations is under question by a landowner in the Nowra district who has also initiated legal proceedings against the Commonwealth. Inquiries are also being made on his behalf by the Deputy Commonwealth Ombudsman.
Family Medicine Program
(Question No. 3193)
Mrs Darling asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 22 September 1981:

Answers to Questions

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3145

. (I) Did his Department receive representations from the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners for an increase in real terms for the allocation in 1981-82 for the Family Medicine Program.
(2) Did he announce in the 1981-82 Budget that no increase in any form would be made to the allocation to the Family Medicine Program.
(3) Is it a fact that fewer medical practitioners are prepared to take trainees under the program because of the shortfall between the Government's reimbursement through the Family Medicine Program and the general practitioner's payment to the trainee.
(4) Does the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners state that a cut in real terms to the Program's allocation will result in more untrained or inadequately trained doctors being let loose on the community.
(5) Has the College pointed out that a cut of this kind is false economy because the cuts would produce untrained doctors who would waste expensive resources such as hospital care, specialist, investigations and therapeutic items.
(6) Will he give consideration to increasing the allocation to the Family Medicine Program; if not, why not.
Mr Howard-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Ministers have received representations by the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners seeking a review of the 1981-82 allocation for the Family Medicine Program.
(2) The Government decided that the 1981-82 grant for the Family Medicine Program should be set at the same level as the 1980-81 basic grant of $5.025m. The Government has also decided to institute an independent review of policy issues surrounding the post-graduate vocational training activities undertaken by the Family Medicine Program. After giving consideration to the outcome of that review, the Government will decide what, if any, future actions are warranted on its part in relation to post-graduate vocational training of general practitioners.
(3) It has been suggested by the College that this is the situation. There may, however, be other considerations and a better understanding of the matter will be possible when the findings of the independent review are available.
(4) and (5) These claims have been made by the College and will be considered in the proposed review.
(6) See (2) above.
Brisbane Airport: Air Traffic Control
(Question No. 3197)
Mrs Darling asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 22 September 1981:
(I) Can he say whether the closure of the Brisbane Airport due to air traffic control problems has halted a $30m resort development in the Whitsunday area, Queensland.
(2) If so, can he also say whether the mainland resort developers have halted the project until they receive clarification of the effects on other areas in Queensland caused by the closure of the Brisbane Airport.
(3) What will be the effect on other Queensland airports as a result of the Brisbane Airport temporary closure.
(4) What action has he taken to immediately resolve the situation caused by a shortage of air traffic controllers.
Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(1) No-indeed there is no total closure of Brisbane Airport but there is a limited closure from 9 pm to midnight daily which has had minimal effect on scheduled services to and from Brisbane Airport.
(2) Not applicable.
(3) There are no jet airline operations scheduled to depart to or from Brisbane or any of the Queensland coastal airports later than 9 pm and these are therefore unaffected by the 9 pm closure of Brisbane's airport.
(4) Action was initiated in 1979 to recruit air traffic control trainees to the maximum capacity of the training college. Between 110 and 120 trainees have been recruited each year since 1979. Because the training course takes three years for the bulk of these trainees, the benefit from this recruitment action will not be felt until late 1981 jearly 1982. It is anticipated that there will be an improving situation from this time onwards. On the specific problem at Brisbane arising from the acute shortage of controllers in Queensland, my Department has now transferred 17 permanent and seven temporary controllers to Queensland. These transferees, once trained, will release other controllers for training in the terminal area positions and so enable the airport to resume normal operations. My Department anticipates that this training will be completed early next year.
Hospitals: Acquisition by German Hospital Chain
(Question No. 3222)
Dr Blewett asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 23 September 19,81:
(I) Is he aware of any large German hospital chain which is interested in acquiring a hospital in Australia as reported in the Australian Financial Review of 18 September 1981, page 19.
(2) If so, what is the name of the chain.
Mr MacKellar-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) and (2) I am aware of the report in the Australian Financial Review of 18 September 1981 concerning this matter and my Department sought advice from the Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) as to whether an approach had been made to the Board in respect of it. I am informed that there has been no approach to the FIRB but the Board's enquiries of the German-Australian Chamber of Industry and Commerce have indicated that the advertisement was placed in the Australian Financial Review as a means of determining what potential might exist for investment in Australia by a German company, experienced in the operation of hospitals, in advance of a visit to Australia by an executive of that company. The name of the company was not disclosed to the FIRB, but it was indicated that the company was aware that any such proposal would come within the scope of the Government's foreign investment policy requirements.
I should add that in the event that any proposal for acquisition of a private hospital in Australia by this or any other overseas company is put forward it will be subject to detailed examination by the FIRB in consultation with my Department and the health authorities of the relevant State. Further, no proposal would be approved unless it offered worthwhile benefits in the efficient provision of hospital services, complied with all Federal and State health requirements and provided scope for substantial Australian participation in the equity of the venture.

3146 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Answers to Questions

Department of Defence: Severance Pay Entitlements
(Question No. 3270)
Mr Scholesasked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:
(I) Does his Department withhold proportion of severance pay entitlements at the time of discharge
(2) If so, what is the purpose of withholding these funds and for what period are they retained by his Department.
(3) Is interest paid on funds of former service personnel withheld for his Department's convenience.
(4) Does any legal authority exist for the retention of moneys properly belonging to the former servicemen.
(5) If the withholding of moneys is not covered by statutory authority, what redress is available to service personnel.
Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Certain entitlements such as pay-in-lieu of recreation leave and furlough do not become due until after the member is discharged. However, on the day of discharge, members are advanced 80 per cent of their pay-in-lieu of leave entitlement and normally, payment of their pay-in-lieu of furlough entitlement less $200 is effected within three or four days.
(2) The Defence Force Pay systems whilst allowing for payment and some calculation of entitlements at unit level, are largely centralised and computer based. Variations to members entitlements are processed through the Defence Force Pay Accounting Centre in Melbourne which is also charged with final reconciliation of members accounts. Experience over many years has shown that errors do occur in calculations and can only be identified when all of the members records are brought together and reconciled. These records include details of leave entitlements. and amounts recoverable from the member which can be incurred up to and on the day of discharge. The current practice was standardized in August 1979 and was generally an improvement on previous procedures. Ex-members normally receive the balance of their pay in lieu of leave and furlough entitlements within three to four weeks of discharge.
(3) No.
(4) Advice from the Crown Solicitor's Office indicates the need for the Department to reconcile the accounts of retiring members and pay moneys due to them on retirement or as soon as possible thereafter. Reconciliation which is the basis of the current procedures, is necessary to ensure the correct 'and proper use of public funds.
(5) Redress through the Civil Courts is available to ex-members. However, an examination of current procedures is in progress with the aim of reducing the time taken to reconcile the pay accounts.
Rates of Workers' Compensation
(Question No. 3273)
Mr Scholes asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:
(I) What rates of workers' compensation apply under the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act.
(2) What are the comparative rates in each State, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory.

Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(I) The'Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971 provides a comprehensive range of benefits payable in respect of work-connected injury or disease. The rates or amounts of the major benefits payable from I September 1981 are as set out below:
(i) Totallncapacity For the first 26 weeks of total incapacity for work, an injured employee receives weekly compensation payments at the rate equivalent to his full sick pay rate. During further periods of incapacity, the rate payable is the lesser of the employee's average weekly earnings or $114.00 a week plus $29.85 a week for a dependent spouse and $14.20 a week for each dependent child.
(ii) Partial Incapacity Where an employee is partially incapacitated, the rate of weekly compensation payable is calculated according to ability to earn. Generally, the payment is an amount equal to the difference between the employee's average weekly earnings before the injury (as adjusted) and the weekly amount he is currently able to earn, subject to a maximum rate of $114.00 a week.
(iii) Loss of Limb or Faculty Where an employee loses, or loses the use of, a part of the body or a faculty and he is not likely to become totally unfit for work, he may receive lump sum compensation. The maximum payment for anyone loss is $35,500. Actual amounts payable in respect of specific losses are shown in sections 39-42 of the Act.
(iv) Death of an Employee A dependant of a deceased employee may qualify for a lump sum payment. The basic death benefit of $35,500 is payable where there is a dependant wholly dependent on the deceased employee. A person partially dependent may receive up to $35,500. An additional weekly payment of $14.20 is payable in respect of each dependent child.
(2) Comparative rates and amounts of compensation payable under State or Territorial workers compensation codes are set out below.
New South Wales (effective from 1 October 1981).
(i) Totallncapacity For the first 26 weeks of total incapacity an employee receives compensation at the weekly rate of wages provided by his award or an award covering the nature of his work. If no award can be applied, an amount of $201.29 is payable.
Thereafter: Employee-$115,60 a week.
a Spouse-$26.50 a week.
Each child-$13.20 week.
(ii) Partial Incapacity The difference between the employee's probable earnings but for the injury and the average weekly amount he is able to earn, to a maximum of $115.60 a week.
(iii) Loss of Limb or Faculty Lump sum payment, payable on a similar basis to payments under the Commonwealth Act, with a maximum amount payable of $31,000.
(iv) Death Maximum lump sum to dependants-$45,200. Additional Child's Benefit-$22.60 a week.
Victoria (effective from 1 July 1981).

Answers to Questions

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3147

(i) Total Incapacity Adult Employee-$ 130.00 a week. Minor (under 21 )-$96.00 a week. Spouse-$37.00 a week. Each child-$12.00 a week.
These payments are subject to a maximum weekly limit of$ I93.00 (adult) and $167.00 (minor).
(ii) Partial incapacity Such weekly amount as bears the same relationship to total incapacity rate as actual loss of earnings bears to average weekly earnings before injury.
(iii) Loss of Limb or Faculty Lump sum payment, payable on a similar basis to payments under the Commonwealth Act, with a maximum amount payable of $23,260.
(iv) Death Maximum lump sum to dependants-$41,093.
An additional lump sum is payable in respect of each dependent child. The actual amount varies according to the child's age at the date of the worker's death. The maximum additional benefit is $10,023 for a child under one year of age.
Queensland (effective from I I May 198 I).
(i) Total Incapacity For the first 26 weeks of total incapacity an employee receives weekly compensation at the rate of wages provided by his award or agreement. If no award appropriate, an amount of $215.50 is payable.
Thereafter, the Queensland Basic Wage is payable-
Employee-$97. 10 a week. Spouse-$24.30 a week (25 per cent of Basic Wage). Each Child-$9.70 a week (10 per cent of Basic Wage).
(ii) Partial Incapacity Weekly payment calculated on a similar basis to Victoria.

(iv) Death Maximum lump sum to dependants-$34,020. Additional lump sum child's benefit-$2,520.
South Australia (effective from 1 January 1974).
(i) Total Incapacity For any period of total incapacity, an employee receives compensation at the rate of his average weekly earnings over the previous 12 months (or his period of employment if less than 12 months) including overtime and allowances. Such payments are subject to a total limit of $25,000 in respect of anyone incident.
(ii) Partial Incapacity A weekly amount not exceeding the difference between the employee's average weekly earnings before injury and the average weekly amount he is able to earn after injury and bearing such relation to the amount of that difference as under the circumstances of the case appears proper. Such payments are subject to a total limit of $18,000 in respect of anyone incident.
(iii) Loss of Limb or Faculty Lump sum payment, payable on a similar basis to payments under the Commonwealth Act with a maximum amount payable of $25,000.

(iv) Death Maximum lump sum to dependants-$25,OOO. Additional lump sum child's benefit-$500.
Western Australia (effective from I July 1981).
(i) Totallncapacity For any period of total incapacity, an employee receives compensation at the rate of his weekly earnings at the time of injury excluding overtime and allowances. Such payments are subject to a total limit of $58,885 in respect of anyone incident.
(ii) Partial Incapacity A weekly amount not to exceed the difference between the employee's weekly earnings before the injury and the weekly amount he is able to earn after injury.
(iii) Loss of Limb or Faculty Lump sum payment, payable on a similar basis to payments under the Commonwealth Act, with a maximum amount payable of $58,885.
(iv) Death Maximum lump sum to dependants~$50,052.25. Additional Child's Benefit-$7.50 a week.
Tasmania (effective from I January 1981).
(i) Total Incapacity For any period of total incapacity, an employee receives compensation at the rate of his average weekly
a earnings over previous 12 months including overtime
and allowances. Such payments are subject to total limit of $41,634 in respect of anyone incident.
(ii) Partial Incapacity A weekly amount calculated on the difference between the amount payable for total incapacity and the amount an employee is able to earn after injury.
(iii) Loss of Limb or Faculty Lump sum payment, payable on a similar basis to payments under the Commonwealth Act, with a maximum amount payable of $41,634.
(iv) Death Maximum lump sum to dependants-$41,634. Additional lump sum Child's Benefit-$I,026.
Australian Capital Territory (effective from I October 1981 ).
(i) Total Incapacity For the first 26 weeks of total incapacity, an employee receives compensation at the equivalent of this full sick pay rate or his normal weekly earnings whichever is greater. Thereafter.
Employee-$116.82 a w.eek (or weekly earnings if less than $116.82). Spouse-$30.74 a week. Each Child-$14.34 a week.

Review of Commonwealth Functions: Effect on Commissioner for Employees' Compensation
(Question No. 3286)
Mrs Darling asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:
(I) Is it a fact that delays of up to six months are being experienced by the Office of the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation in the processing of claims for compensation.
(2) In what way has this office been affected by the recommendations of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions.
(3) Is it a fact that the recommendations of the Committee of Review have caused or contributed to the delay; if not, what other factors have caused the delay.
Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(I) The Commissioner for Employees' Compensation has informed me that no statistics are kept regarding the specific length of time each individual case takes to be processed in the Office of the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation (OCEC). However, in the light of complaints about delays received from various sources, e.g., members of the Parlia, ment, the Commonwealth Ombudsman, the Commissioner acknowledges that it is a fact that, despite attempts to improve the situation, delays of up to six months have occurred in the determination of claims under the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971 ('the Compensation Act'). Measures adopted to alleviate the situation included:
increasing the number of delegates outside OCEC and widening the scope of the delegations;
the introduction of revised procedures in OCEC, together with the working of considerable overtime; and
the provision, this year, of some additional staff and an increase of 5 in staff ceiling.
(2) In the context of the Review of Commonwealth Functions the Government decided that, in the interests of efficiency, effectiveness and rationalisation in relation to the administration of the Compensation Act and OCEC operations, two ,measures should be introduced. These decisions and their effects are:

(a) the introduction, with effect from I July 1981, of a new appeal forum, namely, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, in lieu of the review procedures previously operating. Some increase in the work load associated with the review of determinations has resulted and the provision of additional staff resources in this area of OCEC is under consideration; and
(b) the other decision was that the operations of OCEC be expanded in the Australian Capital Territory and extended to the States to take over work currently performed on OCEC's behalf by Commonwealth Departments and Authorities. Implementation of this decision is in the preliminary stages with work being carried out on the evaluation of systems and resources required. This in itself has not led to any disruption to the claims processing work in OCEC.
(3) No. The processing of claims has not been adversely affected. It is expected that, when implemented, the revised system of administration of the Compensation Act will minimise delays. The Commissioner has reported his views on the factors causing delays in his Annual Report for 1980-81.
Theft of Munitions or Bombs from Army Depots
(Question No. 3290)
Mr West asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:
What Army depots in Australia have had munitions or bombs stolen from them since I January 1976.
Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
Army records show that in the period I January 1976 to 16 October 1981 there has been a total of thirty-one (31) separate incidents at twenty-five (25) depots involving the theft of weapons or ammunition from Army units in Australia. Complete recovery was effective in twelve (12) of these thefts.
Electricity Generating Capacities
(Question No. 3296)
Mr Hayden asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:
(I) What was the actual electricity generating capacity in each state and Territory if 1980 and what is the projected generating capacity for (a) 1985, (b) 1990, (c) 1995 and (d) 2000.
(2) What was the actual electricity demand in each State and Territory in 1980 aljd what is the estimated demand in (a) 1985, (b) 1990, (c) 1995 and (d) 2000 for (i) all consumers, (ii) industry, (iii) residential consumers, (iv) commerce and (v) other consumers.
Mr Anthony-The Minister for National Development and Energy, Senator Carrick, has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(I) Table I shows actual capacity for 1980 and details of State plans of public authority electricity generating capacity for 1985 and 1990, consistent with information given in Table A4.1 in the Department of National Development and Energy publication 'Forecasts of Energy Demand and SupplyPrimary and Secondary Fuels Australia: 1980-81 to 1989-90'.
It should, however, be recognised that it is normal practice for State electricity authorities to keep under continual review the timing and content of their investment and plant retirement programs in the light of changes in forecasts of demand.

Answers to Questions

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3149

These changes are in turn dependent on factors which include changing estimates of future income levels and relative prices, industrial development, and demand for the exports of certain electricity intensive industries notably aluminium smelters.
Electricity demand forecasts for the coming decade and beyond are particularly sensitive to the third factor. Supply arrangements to aluminium smelters typically involve long term contracts which, even after finalisation, may still allow varying degrees of Hexibility in timing and take or pay arrangements.
Since the table was prepared, there have been reports of deferrals of several aluminium smelter projects, notably in Queensland and Western Australia. As a result, there could be deferral or attenuation of some planned power station projects.
The State Electricity Commission of Victoria has recently announced the deferral of units of the Loy Yang A power station, the second and third units by six months and the fourth unit by nearly a year.
For such reasons, projections of planned installed capacity, particularly extending as far as 1995 and 2000, may be subject to considerable uncertainty and as a general rule are not published by the authorities. Exceptions have been noted in the initial submission of the State Electricity Commission of Victoria to the State Parliamentary Public Works Committee Inquiry on the proposed Driffield project (8 April 1981 ,p. 31) and publications of the Tasmanian Hydroelectric Commission and Tasmanian Directorate of Energy relating to future electricity supply options in that State.
(2) Data on electricity demand are included in the Department of National Development and Energy publication referred to in (I). Forecasts to 1990 are at pp. 122-131, and historical data are at pp. 163-169. The end-use classification presented in Table (2) is a summary of this information.

Military Aid to Indonesia

(Question No. 3319)

Mr Fry asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 14 October 1981:

(I) What military aid, in monetary terms, has been given by Australia to Indonesia since December 1975.

(2) What type and quantity of equipment has been given to Indonesia during the same period.

(3) Once such equipment has been given, does the Australian Government retain any control over how it is to be
used.

(4) Is he able to say whether any of this equipment has been used in hostilities; iFso, when and where.

(5) How many Indonesian officers are trained annually in Australian military establishments.

(6) What type oFtraining are they given.

Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(I) Total expenditure on DeFence Cooperation with Indonesia For the period I July 1976 to 30 June 1981 was
$48.770m.

(2) Principal equipments provided to Indonesia under the
DeFence Cooperation Program since December 1975 comprise:

Ten Nomad aircraft (two provided earlier in December 1975).
Six sixteen metre patrol boats. Twelve ex-Army Sioux helicopters.
250 Land Rovers. 261 PRC77 field radios (1975-76), together with radio test, repair and maintenance equipment. Ten fully equipped mobile vehicle repair workshops.

Further elements of equipment have been provided in re-
spect of DeFence Cooperation Program assistance to Indonesia in the following fields: survey and mapping, research and development, English language training and oxy-
gen drying equipment.

(3) The only restriction placed on the use of military equip-
ment provided under the Defence Cooperation Program to
foreign countries, including Indonesia, relates to sale or disposal to a third country without the prior consent of the Australian Government.

(4) No.

(5) The number of Indonesian servicemen who undertake various Forms of training in Australia and study visits to
Australia since 1975 has averaged over eighty each year. The
niajority of these were officers and senior NCOs. Total training figures are as Follows:

1976

81

1977

47

1978

81

1978-79

89'

1979-80

81

1980-81

70

"Note: Statistics converted to financial year basis From 1978-79.

(6) The main types of training provided For Indonesian Servicemen are:

Underwater medical techniques, Marine survey and hydrography training, Training in naval instruction tehniques, Army Staff College course, Military cartography and map production training, Training in the command of air defence artillery, Basic training in Armoured Corps equipment and orgsanisation, Training in inFantry combat instructors, Training of flying instructors, Air Force supply systems training, Training in packaging and loading air freight, and Flying saFety officer training.

'Towards an Australian Family Policy' Conference
(Question No. 3328)
Mr McLean asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 15 October 1981:
(I) Has an official report yet been received from the conFerence held in May 1980 to discuss the issue Towards An Australian Family Policy'.
(2) If a report has been Completed, has it been circulated.
(3) If a report has not been completed and circulated, what is the reason.
Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(1) No.
(2) and (3) The May 1980 ConFerence: 'Towards An Australian Family Policy' was sponsored by the Australian Council of Social WelFare Ministers. Membership of the Council comprises all State and Territory WelFare Ministers the Commonwealth Minister For Social Security and WelFare Ministers from New Zealand and Papua New Guinea. Responsiblity For production of a Report From the ConFerence rests with the New South Wales Department of Youth and Community Services. I understand the Report is nOw available.

Answers to Questions

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3151

Brisbane Airport: Retention of Flight Path Information
(Question No. 3355)
Mrs Darling asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 20 October 1981:
(I) Will he instruct the Brisbane Airport authorities to retain information concerning flight paths at that airport for a longer period than the present holding period of 30 days.
(2) Would retention of this information over a period of several years enable Departmental personnel, as well as the public, to compare and contrast air traffic patterns over the Brisbane metropolitan area.
(3) What is the reason for holding this information no longer than 30 days.
Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) No. The retention of flight strip records for a period of 30 days is sufficient for routine statistical and investigational purposes. The retention of these records for a period in excess of 30 days is arranged from time to time to assist in special studies.
(2) Yes, but to store and extract the information would require very large resources which would not be commensurate with the benefit gained. The new radar display to be ordered by my Department will permit automatic storage and analysis of data over long periods.
(3) The standard contained in an Annex to the Convention of International Civil Aviation requires such records to be held for a minimum of 30 days. Up to approximately 1978, these records were maintained by my Department for a period of 90 days. This period was reduced to 30 days after a twelve month trial, bearing in mind that special holding arrangements are made for special studies.
Improved Practices to Reduce Salinity
(Question No. 3378)
Mr Lloyd asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 21 October 1981:
(I) Who are the officials mentioned in the Prime Minister's Press statement of 16 October 1981 who will review the extent to which irrigators were adopting improved practices to reduce salinity and the possible need for additional incentives to hasten the adoption of new practices.
(2) When will the first meeting take place, what will be the terms of reference, and when is the committee expected to report to the Government.
Mr Anthony-The Minister for National Development and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(I) Messrs T. E. Michell, Department of National Development and Energy; S. Pels, New South Wales Water Resources Commission; E. Corbin, New South Wales Department of Agriculture; A. H. Clegg, Victorian State Rivers and Water Supply Commission; J. Mullaly, Victorian Department of Agriculture; R. C. McKnight, South Australian Engineering and Water Supply Department and G. Thomas, South Australian Department of Agriculture.
(2) The Committee will meet on 9 December to determine a work plan to meet the following terms of reference:

review the appropriateness 'of current land use for irrigation in the Murray Valley
review existing irrigation and drainage practices and the rate of adoption of improved practices
determine constraints to the adoption of improved practices and the impact of recent taxation concessions 011 adoption of improved practices
assess the need and justification for possible additional incentives for farmers to adopt improved practices.
It is hoped to have the study completed by the end of March 1982.
Storage Charges on Overdue Containers
(Question No. 3380)
Mr Milton asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 21 October 1981:
(I) What sum did Australia Post pay for storage on overdue containers (sea mail) during the last 12 months.
(2) How many containers were overdue.
(3) What is the reason For the average delay of 7 to 14 days in the collection of containers.
Mr Sinclair-The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:
(I) The sum paid by Australia Post during the 12 months November 1980 to October 1981, for the storage of containers of overseas surface mail prior to collection, is not yet available. During 1980-81, however, an amount of $133,252 was paid.
(2) During 1980-81, 853 containers were overdue.
(3) Delays in collecting containers have resulted mainly from industrial disputes/stoppages within the maritime and transport industries and, to a lesser extent, industrial difficulties within Australia Post. In addition, the simultaneous arrival of large shipments of containers, particularly from the United States of America and the United Kingdom, has contributed to some delays.
Qantas: Carriage of Sporting Teams in Australia
(Question No. 3387)
Mr Campbell asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 21 October 1981:
Will he permit Qantas to carry in and out of Perth, Western Australia sporting teams competing in recognised interstate championships or competitions.
Mr Hunt-The answer to' the honourable member's question is as follows:
There have been a number of recent developments affect' ing the availability of Qantas transcontinental capacity. A rearrangement of Qantas' schedules has meant that the number of Qantas flights terminating in Perth has increased, thus reducing to a large extent the amount of capacity available on Qantas services between Sydney and Perth.
On 28 September, I announced that Qantas had been given approval to introduce through fares between Perth and United States of America. From I November when these lower fares became effective it is expected that the stimulus to demand resulting from the lower fares will further reduce the number of empty Qantas seats across Australia. Moreover, Qantas now offers its Qantas/TWA round the world fare at the same rate from all Australian ports with unlimited stopover rights within Australia provided the basic conditions of travel are met. This is also expected to generate additional traffic across Australia.

3152 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Answers to Questions

When the impact of these initiatives and seasonal variations in demand are taken into account, it is quite possible that unutilised Qantas capacity across Australia would be minimal.

Many other projects funded under the Community Health Program (for example, community health centres and community nursing services) have also undertaken activities related to drug addiction and alcoholism as part of the general community health services provided by them. It is impracticable to identify Commonwealth expenditure on these activities by such other projects.
Ethnic Television
(Question No. 3402)
Mr Humphreys asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 22 October 1981:
(I) Is it a fact that Channel 0/28 has loaned 6 programs to the Migrant Resource Centres for screening around Australia.
(2) If so, is it intended that these screenings will form the basis for assessing public reaction to experimental ethnic television programs .which have already been shown in Sydney and Melbourne.
Mr Sinclair-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes.
(2) I am advised that a brief questionnaire has been devised to assess audience reaction after each showing of selected Channel 0/28 programs at Migrant Resource Centres around Australia. The responses will be forwarded to the Central Office of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and the results provided to the Special Broadcasting Service.
DSCC Terminals at Joint Defence Space Res~arch Facility, Pine Gap, Northern Territory
(Question No. 3418)
Mr Holding asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 27 October 1981:
(I) Did he say in answer to Question No. 3596 (Hansard, 3 May 1979, page 1892) that, inter alia, the radomes at Pine

Gap, Northern Territory, were installed in 1968, 1968, 1969, 1969, 1971 and 1977.
(2) Did he also say in answer to question No. 492 (Hansard 20 October 1981, pages 2248-9) that, inter alia, 2 DSCS terminals, designated SCT-35 and SCT-8, were installed at the Joint Defence Space Research Facility, Pine Gap, Northern Territory, in 1973 and 1980.
(3) Is there any conflict between these 2 answers; if so, what is the reason for, and the details of, this conflict.
(4) What antennae system at Pine Gap was used for satellite communication before the installation of the 2 DSCS antennae, what was the formal designation of this antennae system, and what was the satellite communication system with which it operated.
Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes.
(2) Yes.
(3) No. The apparent inconsistency arises because a satellite terminal used for research that was installed in 1969 was later dismantled and replaced by the SCT-35 communications terminal in 1973.
(4) Prior to 1973, surface communications links were used between the facility and the United States. For reasons of security I will not provide details of other satellite communications equipment at the facility.
Growth in Defence Outlay
(Question No. 3420)
Mr Morrison asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice; on 27 October 1981:
(I) Did the Defence Report 1981 state that the 1980-81 Budget provided for an outlay of $3,541 m representing an increase of 7% in real terms over 1979-80.
(2) Did he, in response to a question raised in Estimates Committee A, advise that the real growth in defence outlay in 1980-81 over 1979-80 was 5.6%.
(3) In view of these apparently conflicting statements what was the actual growth in real terms in 1980-81 over 1979-80.
(4) What steps will be taken to rectify the record in either or both of the sources referred to in parts (I) and (2).
Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes.
(2) Yes.
(3) There is no conflict. As I told Parliament on 20 October 1981, while the 1980-81 Budget provided for real growth of about 7 per cent, a number of factors including deferral of the decision on the new tactical fighter resulted in a somewhat lower growth of 5.6 per cent actually being achieved.
Uranium Information Centre Ltd
(Question No. 3428)
Dr Blewett asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 27 October 1981:
(I) What sum is spent by the Government on support for the Uranium Information Centre Limited via (a) direct subsidy and (b) advice information or any support from any Government Department.

Answers to Questions

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3153

(2) If there is money spent on the Centre, does the Government make any stipulation as to how it will be spent.
(3) Does the Government provide any support for publi non-nuclear energy agency information services; if so, for what agencies and what is the nature of the support.
Mr Anthony-The Minister for National Development and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(I) and (2) Nil.
(3) There is no non-Governmental agency providing information on non-nuclear energy matters to the public in receipt of Government support. In conjunction with the States, however, the Department of National Development and Energy participates in and contributes to the National Energy Conservation Program and the National Industrial Energy Management Scheme which, inter alia, provide information to the public and industry on energy matters.

(4) What sum was spent for each individual in respect of each visit abroad for (a) travel, (b) accommodation, (c) other associated and incidental expenditure and (d) total expenditure.
Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(I) to (4) Neither I nor any member of my staff has officially travelled abroad since I January 1981.
Brisbane Airport: Control Tower
(Question No. 3500)
Mr Morris asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:
(I) What is the proposed height of the new control tower to be constructed under the Brisbane Airport Redevelopment Scheme.

DCSC Terminal, Nurrungar, South Australia
(Question No. 3454)
Dr Blewett asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 28 October:
Further to his answer to Question No. 492 (Hansard, 20 October 1981, pages 2248-9), what is the formal designation of the (a) Defence Satellite Communications System (DSCS) terminal at the Joint Defence Space Communications Station (JDSCS) at Nurrungar, South Australia and the date of its installation and (b) ground station at Salisbury, South Australia operated by the Advanced Engineering Laboratory of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation and used to communicate with the DSCS I satellite 93-26 and the date of the installation of this terminal.
Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(a) AN/MSC-46, installed in 1974.

(2) Is it a fact, as reported, that a ground radar system will have to be installed to enable air traffic controllers operating from the new control tower to determine location of aircraft on the ground when fog occurs at the airport.
(3) Is it also a fact that, under the conditions of operation during periods of fog at the new control tower, aircraft will not be visible to air traffic controllers in the control tower because of the height of the tower and the intervening fog.
Mr Hunt-The answers to the honourable member's question are as follows:
(I) The proposed height of the new control tower to be constructed under the Brisbane Airport Redevelopment Scheme is still subject to a final decision.
(2) No. Location of aircraft on the ground when fog occurs is determined by procedural (that is, non radar) control methods.
(3) No. Visibility of aircraft in fog from various heights of control tower depends on the visibility profile of the fog.

(b) The ground station at Salisbury does not have an official nomenclature. It was designed and developed at the Advanced Engineering Laboratory and is known as the Advanced Engineering Laboratory Satellite Communications Experimental Facility. It was first used experimentally in August 1974.

Australian Shipping Commission: Loan Repayments
(Question No. 3503)
Mr Morris asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

Overseas Travel by Ministers or Ministerial Staff
(Question No. 3479)
Mr Morris asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 29 October 1981 :
(I) On what occasions has the Minister or members of the Minister's staff travelled abroad since I January 1981 to the date of preparation of the answer to this question.
(2) What places and organisations were visited during the travel abroad and on what dates did the Minister depart from. Australia and arrive and depart at each of the places visited during travel abroad, and on what date did the Minister and associated staff return to Australia.
(3) What were the names and classifications of persons associated with the Minister's travel abroad referred to in parts (I) and (2) ..

(I )In relation to the repayment of loans amounting to $30m by the Australian Shipping Commission in 1981-82 being interest bearing borrrowings from previous Budgets, why was this course of action necessary and what will be the' financial impact on the Australian Shipping Commission of the early repayment.
(2) What will be the financial impact upon the Australian Shipping Commission of the early repayment of the loans referred to in Item 7 (b) on page 4 of the Estimates of Receipts and Expenditure explanatory notes for his Department 1981-82 and, in particular, what are the specific amounts of interest charges involved and will he indicate whether the action being taken will result in interest charges of the Commission being higher or lower in 1981-82 had this course of action not been followed.
Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) and (2) Following consideration of ANL's Corporate Plan earlier this year, the Government agreed to allow ANL

3154 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Answers to Questions

to develop commercial refinancing packages to restructure its long term debt portfolio. The $30m repayment of Budget Advances in 1981-82 will result from the first of these refinancings.
As the refinancing arrangements will not be finalised until towards the end of the current fiscal year they are not expected to have a financial impact on the Commission in 1981-82.
Australian Shipping Commission: Darwin Service Subsidy
(Question No. 3514)
Mr Morris asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:
With reference to the subsidy paid to the Australian Shipping Commission for the operation of the east-coast Darwin shipping service, what specific information is he able to provide on the alternative proposals being considered for the provision of an alternate shipping service to Darwin by the Australian Shipping Commission and the Northern Territory Government or proposed to be considered by the Australian Shipping Commission and the Northern Territory Government.
Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
The Australian National Line (AI"L) is currently investigating, in conjunction with Northern Territory interests, alternative proposals for the continuation of shipping services between the East Coast and Darwin. It would be inappropriate to make interim comments on these proposals before the studies are completed.
Australian Shipping Register
(Question No. 3521)
Mr Morris asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:
(I) How many vessels have been registered on the newly established Australian Shipping Register since its commencement.
(2) How many vessels are eligible for registration on the Australian Register and what is the anticipated number of vessels that will be registered by the end of 1981-82.
Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) As the honourable member will be aware I announced on 6 November that the Government is aiming to bring the Australian Register of Ships into operation on Australia Day 1982.
(2) My Department does not have details of the total number of vessels that will be eligible for registration on the Australian Register as the eligible vessels include all pleasure craft owned or operated in Australia and capable of navigating the high seas. However, it is anticipated that 5,200 vessels will be registered by the end of 1981-82.
Adult Migrant and Refugee Education Courses
(Question No. 3573)
Mr Young asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:
In relation to the Adult Migrant and Refugee Education courses what provision has been made for (a) certificates at

the completion of the courses, (b) permanent teachers in all States, (c) curriculum materials specifically designed for adults as distinct from children's books and stories and (d) English language classes for the increased number of immigrants.
Mr Macphee-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(a) Most courses available in the Adult Migrant Education Program are provided through State Adult Migrant Education Services or their equivalents in the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory. Those services in New South Wales, Victoria, Western Australia, Tasmania, Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory issue certificates to migrants who complete courses. The State Adult Migrant Education Services in Queensland and South Australia have not yet decided to issue certificates.
(b) Teachers in the Adult Migrant Education Services are employed by the State or Territory Education authorities. In New South Wales there are some 120 permanent teachers, in Queensland 12; South Australia II; Northern Territory 6 and the Australian Capital Territory 15. There are no permanent teachers in the Victorian Adult Migrant Education Services and the Officer-in-charge is the only permanent professional officer if the Western Australia Adult Migrant Education Service. Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia employ some full-time temporary teachers and in New South Wales about 200 hourly paid staff work on a full-time or nearly full time basis. All States and each of the Territories employ staff who are paid on an hourly basis.
(c) Curriculum material has been designed specifically for the Adult Migrant Education Program under the guidance of the Joint Commonwealth/States Committee on professional aspects of the Adult Migrant Education Program. The production of t;.ducational material in support of that curriculum development is continuing at Commonwealth, State and local levels under the guidance of the National Materials Steering Committee. Funds have been provided to States to support that development.
(d) The Government has substantially increased the level of funding for the Adult Migrant Education Program in Australia. Operational funding has increased from $8.8m in 1976-77 to $31.3m in 1981-82. Other funds have been made available through the appropriations to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and the Department of Administrative Services for the provision of classrooms and associated facilities to accommodate the expanded program.
Immigration: Joint Commonwealth-State Research Program
(Question No. 3574)
Mr Young asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:
(I) Was $30,000 allocated for the Joint Commonwealth State Research program in 1980-81 and the same sum allocated for 1981-82.
(2) On what was this sum spent during 1980-81 and on what will it be spent in 1981-82.
(3) Which States (a) have and (b) will participate in these projects.
Mr Macphee-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes. In 1980-81 and 1981-82 $30,000 was allocated by the Commonwealth and $30,000 in total by the States (with

Answers to Questions

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3155

the contribution of each State calculated on a per head of population basis) to the Joint Commonwealth-State research program.
(2) During 1980-81 and 1981-82 the funds have been spent on a longitudinal survey of settlers in the general eligibility category. Further projects in this program are currently being discussed with the States.
(3) All States have participated and have indicated that they will continue to participate in the research program.
Australian Population and Migration Research Trust Account
(Question No. 3575)
Mr Young asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:
What is the Australian Population and Migration Research Trust Account and who are the trustees.
Mr Macphee-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
The Australian Population and Migration Research Trust Account holds the funds contributed by the Commonwealth and the States for the Joint Comm'onwealth-State Research Program. The trustees are officers nominated from each State

Immigration and/or Ethnic Affairs Ministry and the Commonwealth Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs: Computer Arrangements
(Question No. 3577)
Mr Young asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:
(I) Why does his Department have to absorb the overhead costs in computer equipment.

3156 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Answers to Questions

(2) [s there a 150 per cent increase in maintenance and equipment costs and a $203,500 increase in the purchase of computer time in 1981-82, ifso, why.
(3) Are other departments opting out of the present computer arrangements with the Department of the Capital Territory, ifso, why.
Mr Macphee-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) [n accordance with the procedures laid down by the Department of Finance, the total costs of running the Department of the Capital Territory computer installation are apportioned between user departments on the basis of their proportional usage. Accordingly, where the number of users is reduced, the remaining users must absorb that proportion of fixed costs apportioned to the former users.
(2) Maintenance costs for ADP equipment are expected to increase by approximately 150 per cent because to date the department has met maintenance costs only for a small number of remote terminals and a mini-computer installation. [n 1981-82 the department will be liable for additional maintenance costs for increased numbers of remote terminals and maintenance costs for recently purchased computer hardware.
Expenditure on computer time is expected to increase significantly because the Department of the Capital Territory has introduced a revised charging structure based on the procedures outlined in (I) above and based on actual rather than notional usage. The new charging structure will result in an effective increase in the rate paid by the Department of [mmigration and Ethnic Affairs for its computer time and accordingly an increased provision has been made.
(3) The other departments are moving from the Department of the Capital Territory equipment to their own equipment.
Department ofImmigration and Ethnic -i\ffairs: Reductions in Staff
(Question No. 3579)
Mr Young asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 29 October 1981 :
(I) Are the only areas in his Department which will not suffer staff cuts (a) the Executive, (b) Central Office and (c) the Population Branches.
(2) Have all other branches had staff cuts ranging from I to 52 persons.
(3) [n 1981-82 will there be (a) a potential 1.2. million applicants for Australian citizenship, (b) new regulations introduced regarding travel between Australia and New Zealand and (c) an increased number of applicants both in Australia and overseas for permanent, temporary and tourist visas.
(4) [f so, on what basis were these cuts recommended, and what is the rationale behind them at a time of increased immigration intake.
Mr Macphee-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) No. For further details see Table A below.
(2) No. See Table A.
(3) (a) Yes; (b) Yes. New requirements have already been implemented; (c) Yes.
(4) 1981-82 staff ceiling allocations were set in the context of decisions emanating from the Review of Commonwealth

Functions resulting in a reduction of 74 in the Department's staff ceiling.
The internal distribution of the total staff ceiling is determined in accordance with assessed priorities and is subject to regular reassessment to take account of workload distribution, changing priorities and other exigencies. Ceiling figures are formally allocated to Divisions and regions. Whether within these categories particular Branches are allocated a ceiling is an internal management matter.

Telephone Interpreter Service
(Question No. 3580)
Mr Young asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 29 October 1981.
(1) Has the telephone interpreter service experienced a considerable growth pressure in the last 2 years.
(2) Was a staff cut in this area recommended to the members of the Committee on the Review of Commonwealth Functions; if so, on what basis.
(3) What is the rationale behind the charges to be introduced in certain interpreting and translating services.
(4) How will the automatic switching devices operate between say Umbakumba, Northern Territory and Sydney.
(5) How will the charges for telephone interpreting be collected.
(6) Could private enterprise better manage the telephone interpreting service than the present Government.
Mr Macphee-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

Answers to Questions

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3157

(I) Yes. The total number of calls has increased from 168,205 in 1979-80 to 214,089 in 1980-81.
(2) and (3) The principal purpose of the changes made to the Telephone Interpreter Service was to improve its efficiency by taking advantage of the available telecommunications technology and, where appropriate, utilising the wide range of interpreting skiils available in the community in the larger population centres.
The imposition of charges for certain services was expected to encourage individual Government Departments and other bodies to develop their own interpreting and translating capacities. It is hoped that in due course both the public and private sectors will come to realise that the ability to communicate in languages other than English is essential to providing an effective service to clients or customers and to the conduct of management/labour rehitions.
(4) The Department is assessing and considering the use of Telecom's INWATS system. This will mean that a client in a remote location will be connected automatically to a TIS centre for the cost to the client of a local call.
In respect of the Northern Territory, all calls to TIS Darwin are presently connected automatically to Perth outside the normal hours of operation of the Darwin centre at a cost to the client of the charge for the link from the location to Darwin. It is expected that arrangement will continue.
(5) No charges have been introduced or are planned for telephone interpreters.
(6) The possibility of another agency or private operator managing the Telephone Interpreter Service has not been examined.
Transport Planning and Research: Funding
(Question No. 3589)
Mr Morris asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:
(I) What is the percentage monetary change and real change in Government expenditure on transport planning and research planned for 1981-82 compared to expenditure in 1980-81.
(2) What are the Government's reasons for the changes in expenditure.
(3) If a reduction in expenditure is planned, does this represent reduced Government concern with transport planning and research.
Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) In 1980-81, $6.25m was provided by way of grants to the States for land transport planning and research. This program has been discontinued as from 30 June 1981. However, the Commonwealth is providing $2.42m in 1981-82 as direct assistance to the Australian Road Research Board (ARRB) and the Australian Railway Research and Development Organisation (ARRDO) in lieu of Commonwealth assistance previously provided through the States under the transport planning and research grants. Commonwealth grants to ARRB and ARRDO in 1981-82 are in total 61 per cent less in money terms than the amount provided in grants to States for transport planning and research in .1980-81. There is no specific index for measuring changes in transport planning and research expenditure in real terms.
(2) and (3) The Government is confining its assistance for transport planning and research to programs which are of national significance.

Stevedoring Industry: Industrial Disputes
(Question No. 3591)
Mr Morris asked the Minister for Industrial Relations upon notice, on 29 October 1981:
(I) What percentage of man-hours lost in the stevedoring industry, for the years 1975-76 to 1980-81, were caused by (a) employer-employee disputes, (b) demarcation disputes and (c) other causes.
(2) Is it a fact that the Waterside Workers' Federation of Australia is the only union which is party to the existing waterfront disputes settlement procedures.
(3) What union, other than the WWF have members working in the stevedoring industry.
(4) What percentage of man-hours lost in the stevedoring industry, for the years 1975-76 to 1980-81, were caused by each of the unions represented in the industry.
(5) What (a) advantages and (b) disadvantages exist in extending present waterfront disputes settlement procedures to the other unions represented on the waterfront.
(6) What (a) advantages and (b) disadvantages exist in a policy of industry unionism on the waterfront.
(7) Does the Government support such a policy; if so, what measures is it taking in this regard.
Mr Viner-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) The Australian Bureau of Statistics publishes a quarterly analysis of industrial disputes according to duration, cause, method of settlement, analysis by number of workers involved and analysis by total working days lost. The statistics of causes of industrial disputes are classified under the following headings: wages, hours or work, leave, pensions, compensation provisions, managerial policy, physical working conditions, trade unionism and other.
. There is no separate breakdown by employer-employee nor demarcation classification. However managerial policy is defined as disputes concerning the managerial policy of employers and this classification would embrace employeremployee disputes.
Similarly there is no separate classification of demarcation disputes but inter-union and intra union disputes are included under the classification of trade unionism along with employment of non-unionists, sympathy stoppages in support of employees in !lI1other industry, recognition of union activities, etc.
The. ABS statistics in respect of industrial disputes in stevedoring services reveal the following details for 'managerial policy' and 'trade unionism' disputes for the years 1975-76 to 1980-81:

Managerial Trade policy unionism Other

1975-76
1976-77 1977-78 1978-79
1979-80 1980-81 (-9 months to
30.3.81)

percent 12.8 20.5 52.2 45.0 59.7
30.1

percent percent 4.8 82.4 14.6 64.9 1.3 46.5 13.0 42.0 0.5 39.8
7.7 62.2

- most recent ABS statistics.
(2) The Waterside Workers' Award contains, at clause 28, a detailed dispute settlement procedure. A feature of that procedure involves the operation of a Port Conciliator Service

3158 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Answers to Questions

whereby, if agreement does not arise between the employers and the Federation, the parties may exercise a right to involve a Port Conciliator to reconcile the matlers in dispute. For this purpose, the Port Conciliator may make a recommendation or, where the parties mutually agree, arbitrate on the matler. The operation of the Port Conciliator service is monitored by a Deputy President of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The establishment of the Port Conciliator service was entered into by the AEWL and the WWF at the time of the rationalisation of the industry in 1977.
A number of awards covering the unions involved in waterfront activities contain disputes settlement procedures ego the Australian Foreman Stevedores Association, the Federated Clerks Union and the Federated Storemen and Packers Union. In addition some other unions have written into the awards to which they are parties specific grievance procedures and/or provision for the appointment of Boards of Reference to resolve disputes.
(3) Unions, other than the WWF, with members employed in the stevedoring industry include:
Australian Stevedoring Supervisors Association (ASSA). Federated Clerks Union (FCU). Australian Foremen Stevedores Association (AFSA). Australian Shipping Officers Association (ASOA). Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association (FEDFA). Federated Storeman and Packers Union (FSPU). Transport Workers Union (TWU). Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union (AMWSU). Federated Iron workers Association (FIA). Electrical Trade Union (ETU). Federated Miscellaneous Workers Union (FMWU). Australian Workers Union (AWU). Australasian Society of Engineers (ASE). Building Workers Industrial Union (BWIU).
(4) Since December 1977, the Department of Transport has published monthly reports of manhours lost by operational employees of stevedoring companies due to industrial disputes. The DOT statistics are compiled from returns submitted by the Association of Employers of Waterside Labour and by stevedoring companies. They measure manhours lost by operations employees of stevedoring companies directly or indirectly involved in disputes. The statistics do not reveal time lost in the industry occasioned by industrial action by union members not employed by stevedoring companies.
(5) The Government supports the adoptions of disputes settlement procedures by recognises that it is for the parties directly involved to determine what is most appropriate for particular areas. I am aware that stevedoring employers are at present exploring ways to improve the various dispute settlement procedures operting under awards and agreements in the industry. Any extension to other areas of the precise arrangements involving waterfront employers and the WWF is a matter for the parties concerned and judgment as to the advantages or disadvantages of such a course must necessarily rest with them.
(6) The advantage of an industry-based union on the waterfront include a likely diminution in interunion disputes, the possibility of a more orderly system of negotiation and greater ease and more effective consultation. There are no obvious disadvantages associated with an industry-based union for the waterfront.
(7) It is the policy of the Government to encourage the formation of industry-based unions. I note also that the ACTU supports the establishment of industry-based unions. In consultation with industry, employer and union interests, the Government is actively encouraging acceptance of this policy

and it will continue to examine legislative measures to ensure consistency with its policy objective.
United Nations Convention on the Carriage of Goods by Sea
(Question No. 3592)
Mr Morris asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:
(I) What advantages and disadvantages are there to Australian exporters acceding to the UN. Convention on the Carriage of Goods by Sea, 1978, generally known as the Hamburg Rules, rather than the present Hague-Visby Rules.
(2) What are the principal provisions of the (a) Hamburg Rules and (b) Hague-Visby Rules.
Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) and (2) For the purposes of seeking Australian industry views on the UN. Convention on the Carriage of Goods by Sea, the so-called Hamburg Rules, my Department has prepared a background paper which includes a comparison of the Hague-Visby Rules and the Hamburg Rules.
A copy of that paper was incorporated in the Annual Report of the Australian Shippers' Council (pages 57-63) which I tabled on 29 October J981.
Trade Practices Act: Controls on Freight Rates
(Question No. 3593)
Mr Morris asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:
What progress has been made in discussions and Government action to amend Part X of the Trade Practices Act, relating to strengthening Australian control over freight rates on its liner exports.
Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
The Government's proposals for amendments to Part X of the Trade Practices Act were primarily aimed at increasing its capacity to protect Australian shippers' interests. In response to my invitation to industry to comment on the proposed amendments I have received extensive industry submissions from, and held discussions with, both shippers and shipowners.
As part of this consultative process, I have recently been advised by the principals of both sectors of the industry that they are satisfied appropriate commercial arrangements can be concluded under the existing legislating framework. The future of the proposed amendments is being assessed in the light of the comments received.
Returned Services League Hall, Bacchus Marsh, Victoria
(Question No. 3600)
Dr Theophanous asked the Minister, for Defence, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:
(I) Has it been drawn to his attention that the 2nd Battalion, Royal Victorian Regiment, D Company, has been parading in the RSL hall at Bacchus Marsh, Victoria for a period of approximately 8 weeks.
(2) Uso, is he able to say whether the RSL charges $20 per week for use of the hall by this Army Reserve Unit.
(3) Did the unit resume use of the hall on the understanding that costs would be met by the Government.

Answers to Questions

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3159

(4) Is it a fact that the men of this Unit have had to pay for the hall from their private mess fund.
(5) Is a lease for the hall currenlly being negotiated between his Department and the Department of Administrative Services; if so, why are the negotiations so protracted when the matter appears a simple one and the cost involved so small.
(6) Can he reassure the members of the 2nd Battalion, Royal Victorian Regiment D Company, that the lease will be finalised speedily and aII money personally expended reimbursed.
Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) D Company 2nd Battalion, the Royal Victorian Regiment(2 RVR) has been parading at the RSL hall, Bacchus Marsh since 4 June 1980 except for the period 8 July 1981-19 August 1981. The unit arranged for use of the RSL hall without reference to either my Department or the Department of Administrative Services.
(2) and (3) The unit resumed occupancy of the hall in a private arrangement with the RSL whereby the unit would continue to parade upon a weekly payment of $20 in anticipation of a formal agreement being concluded between the Department of Administrative Services and the RSL. The RSL has proposed an annual rent of $1,820.
(4) Yes. The $20 weekly payment has been made from the Other Ranks mess fund.
(5) Leasing arrangements are near completion. Difficulties arose in the unit's occupation of the RSL premises which was arra"nged in an irregular manner outside Service channels and procedures. Subsequent administrative delays contributed to the formal leasing arrangement being deferred until the 1981-82 financial year.
(6) Both my Department and the Department of Administrative Services are endeavouring to regularise this situation as speedily as possible. Although payments to the RSL by unit members is a private arrangement, I understand that the RSL will re-imburse the members upon receipt of lease payments from the Commonwealth.
Chilean Regime
(Question No. 3603)
Dr Theophanous asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:
(I) Has his attention been drawn to the recent statement by the Deputy Prime Minister in which he described the Children regime as one that has the respect of the people (Hansard, 20 October 1981, page 2184).
(2) If so, does this statement reflect the official Government attitude.
(3) Does the Government support this regime which numerous international reports have described as one of the most reactionary and oppressive regimes in the world.
(4) How does the Government reconcile the Deputy Prime Minister's statement wit.h the Human Rights Reports which condemn the Chilean regime, as evidenced by the 1980 Amnesty International Report which said that there was a marked deterioration in the human rights situation, and there were many arbitrary detentions, allegations of torture and harassment of trade unionists, members of youth organisations, human rights activists, members of church organisations, political opponents and the poor.
Mr Street-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes.

(2) and (3) Australia recognises the Government of Chile and conducts normal diplomatic and trade relations with that country.
(4) The Government has expressed to successive Chilean Governments and in international forums its concern at human rights violations in Chile.
Refugees: Financial Assistance
(Question No. 3604)
Mr Young asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:
(I) Is a 46 per cent reduction in expenditure proposed for 1981-82 to voluntary agencies for the Refugee Resettlement Assistance Loan.
(2) If so, what is the reason for these cuts.
(3) Who are the members of the Committee for Allocation of Loan Funds to Refugees from Indo-China.
Mr Macphee-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) and (2) No. The $200,000 appropriation for the refugee loan scheme in 1981-82 brings to $1,213,000 the amount provided by the Government to a revolving fund, from which interest free loans are made available to refugees and into which repayments return. The annual appropriation is therefore added to earlier Commonwealth funding which began with an amount of $200,000 in 1978-79. It is expected that loans made during 1981-82 will, in total, be of a similar order to those made in 1980-81.
(3) The Board of Directors of CALFRIC Ltd c_omprises representatives of the following agencies: .
AUSTCARE Australian Council of Churches Australian Council of Social Services Indo-China Refugee Association St Vincent de Paul Society Salvation Army, and Smith Family
CALFRIC Ltd releases funds through the voluntary agencies participating in the loan scheme around Australia.
CSIRO: Building Research Division
(Question No. 3610)
Mr Jacobi asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:
(I) Is it a fact that the activities of the Building Research Division of CSIRO have been cut by 30 per cent in the past five years.
(2) What were thestaff levels and financial allocation of this Division for each of the last five years.
(3) Are the publications, information and consulting services of this division highly regard~d by local government bodies and the building industry, and do they make an important contribution to the maintenance of high standards for public safety and well-being in the industry.
(4) Is it a fact that an internal review ofCSIRO activities is currently assessing, or will shortly assess, the activities of this Division.
(5) If so, will he take steps to ensure that the work of this Division is not further curtailed.
(6) If he will not undertake to do this, can he give an assurance that the division will retain at least its current standing withinCSIRO.

3160 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Answers to Questions

Mr Thomson-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) No. Part (2) below gives staff levels and financial allocations for the Division of Building Research for the past five years. Since 30 June 1981, approximately 45 staff of the Division have been transferred to another Division of CSIRO. This does not, however, represent a decrease of CSIRO's efforts in support of the building industry. Transfer of the staff, and the forthcoming formation of a new Division of

Cellulose Research will in fact sharpen the focus of CSIRO's research in wood science, including research for the building industry. The overall staff decrease in the Division since 30 June 1977, including transfer of these 45 staff, is less than 20 per cent, although the Division's capacity to employ has decreased as shown in part (2) below.
(2) The staff levels and financial allocations of the Division of Building Research in the last five years is set out in the table below.
