(3) Yes.
(4) The CSIRO Division of Building Research is to be reviewed later this month. Such divisional reviews are conducted as circumstances dictate, and the CSIRO Executive has decided that it is apportune now to review this Division. While the Review Committee appointed by the Executive consists of an industrialist part-time member of the Executive and two CSIRO Institute Directors, external consultation, in particular with the Building Research and Development Advisory Committee, will be an important facet of the review.
(5) and (6) The determination of research priorities, consequential resource allocation and internal organizational arrangments are statutory responsibilities of the Executive of CSIRO.
Naturalisation Service: Ballarat
(Question No. 3629)
Mr Mildren asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:
(I) Is the service previously supplied by his Department in which naturalisation interviews were conducted at the Ballarat Office, Victoria, of the Commonwealth Employment Service still being provided at that office.
(2) If not, is it a fact that applicants for naturalisation from Ballarat and district are now required to travel to Melbourne for these interviews.
(3) If the service in Ballarat has been terminated is this a result of reductions in his Department.
(4) Will he ensure that this service will continue to be provided for the people of Ballarat.
Mr Macphee-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) No. The Commonwealth Employment Service of the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs previously made available its staff for citizenship interviewing purposes at its Office in Ballarat. This service has now been withdrawn.
(2) Applicants for citizenship from Ballarat and district are now required to travel to either Geelong or Melbourne for interview.

(3) No.
(4) The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in conjuction with the Public Service Board is currently undertaking a joint review of citizenship procedures, including the interviewing of applicants for citizenship from outside the metropolitan areas. The report of the review is expected in the near future and I expect that n<;w procedures developed will meet the needs of applicants from Ballarat and other nonmetropolitan locations.
Community Agencies: Grants-in-aid Scheme
(Question No. 3632)
Mr Young asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic A"ffairs, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:
(I) Has his attention been drawn to the dire financial situation that community agencies funded through the Grants-inAid scheme find themselves in as a result of various awards such as the recently gazetted charitable institutions professional staff social workers award.
(2) Will the Government change the funding arrangement of the Grants-in-Aid scheme from a subsidy grant to a total grant covering award rates in States and Territories where they are applicable.
(3) Has his attention also been drawn to the fact that the smaller ethnic communities which have few resources, such as the Armenians, Finns, Afghans, Koreans, Pacific Islanders and Romanians, receive no funding as these groups are not covered by existing departmental services, either at State or Commonwealth levels.
Mr Macphee-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) I am aware of the implications of the various awards under which Grant-in-Aid workers are employed and of the financial pressures that agencies are experiencing as a result of recent salary increases.
(2) The Galbally Report formulation for the Grant-in-Aid scheme specifies that funding provided under the scheme is designed to subsidise the employment of social welfare workers through community agencies. It was not intended that grants should meet all the costs incurred by organisations

Answers to Questions

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3161

in employing workers. An important feature of Grants-in-Aid is the stimulus given to sponsoring agencies to develop the appropriate resources to attract and maintain grants. Self-help was one of the key principles contained in the Galbally Rec port. The wish of communities to contribute to welfare service delivery, both financially and through their skills and manpower, should not be underestimated.
(3) It is the policy of the Government to help small emerging ethnic groups who may find it difficult to seek and manage Grants-in-Aid. For this reason, a number of grants have been made to generalist social welfare agencies such as the Red Cross, St Vincent de Paul, Care Force and a variety of church organisations to provide services to such groups.
There are over 100 different ethnic groups in our multicultural society, and the locations and concentrations of these groups vary. While it has been possible to fund some small ethnic communities directly, it is not possible to cater for all nationalities in all areas through the provision of specific workers.
The Grant-in-Aid scheme is only one component of a total welfare strategy for addressing the needs of migrant communities. The migrant services units and the Telephone Interpreter Service within the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs play and important role, as do State and community welfare agencies.
Migrants: Information Needs
(Question No. 3633)
Mr Young asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:
Is he able to say what steps have been taken by Commonwealth Departments following the recommendations of the Scott Survey for the information needs of migrants; if so, will he provide detai Is.
Mr MacPhee-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
When tabling the summary of findings on 28 August 1980, I noted that the Survey of Information Needs of Migrants had produced findings and data of relevance to information delivery at all levels in the Australian community. Accordingly, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs distributed some 1000 copies of the full report and 1200 copies of the summary of findings to a wide range of Commonwealth, State, community and private organisations with responsibilities which included delivery of services to the migrant communities.
A further 1000 copies of the full report and nearly 400 copies of the summary findings have been purchased through the Australian Government Publishing Service bookshops.
The major changes in information delivery within the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs following the survey have been:
(i) revision and simplification of information material produced for prospective migrants overseas.
(ii) introduction of group counselling for prospective migrants.
(iii) the production of specialised audio-visual material for migrant counselling overseas.
(iv) the use of Bilingual officers to explain, through ethnic radio stations, changes to policy and to provide information on available services.
A special task force of the Ethnic Liaison Officer Scheme has examined the report to identify its implications for Commonwealth agencies. Since the completion of the report,

changes in the Commonwealth Government agencies' approaches to information delivery have included:
(i) greater use of multilingual publications about facilities, services and obligations.
(ii) greater emphasis on ethnic media for Government advertising.
(iii) greater attention to relaying Ministerial and Departmental announcements to the ethnic press.
Migrant Resource Centres
(Question No. 3635)
Mr Young asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:
(1) Has his attention been drawn to the fact that without appropriate funding for migrant resource centres, hostility could be created at the local level since agencies and communities will have to compete with each other for scarce voluntary and financial resources.
(2) Will he take steps to have additional funds appropriated for migrant resource centres.
Mr Macphee-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) and (2) Funding of migrant resource centres is designed to cover basic operating costs such as core staff salaries, rental, and essential equipment. The intention is that these basics should serve as a starting point for the development of community support programs which mayor may not involve funds from sources outside the migrant resource centre program. Far from competing with other agencies for funds, migrant resource centres co-operate with agencies and individuals in the community in working to meet local community needs. The 1981-82 appropriation for migrant resource centres provides an average of $55,000 for each standard centre. That compares with the $50,000 p.a. allowed for in the Galbally Review Report: Migrant Services and Programs.

War Service Pensions
(Question No. 3645)
Mr Beazley asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:
In view of the recent High Court decision in favour of Nancy Law, will he now allow war service pensions to be paid to ex-servicemen, who claim to have served in war zones, but whose claims are rejected on the grounds that inadequacies in military records do not permit the verification of their claims.
Mr Thomson-The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
I assume the question relates to eligibility for service pension of ex-servicemen who claim to have served in a theatre of war. If this is so, the matters mentioned are for determination by Repatriation Boards and the Repatriation Commission and not by the Minister. If the honourable member wishes to bring to my notice specific claims where he feels that the law has not been applied properly. I shall refer them to the Repatriation Commission for urgent examination.

Munitions Filling Factory, St Marys, New South Wales
(Question No. 3708)
Mr Free asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

When may I expect to receive replies to my letters of 28 July, 4 and 6 August and 8 October 1981 and my telegram of 23 October 1981 concerning the elimination of the cash mode of payment to Commonwealth employees at the Munitions Filling Factory, St Marys, New South Wales.
Mr Howard-The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
The delay in replying to the honourable member was occasioned by the inter-related processes involved in implementing the decision to eliminate the payment of salaries to Commonwealth employees in cash.
A number of employee organisations, representing a variety of employment categories at widely spread locations, had requested me to exercise the power of exemption contained in the legislation. A detailed examination of each request was necessary to ensure an equitable and consistent application of the Government's decision. I can inform the honourable member that a reply to his letters is now being prepared and should be received within the next few days.

Department of Aboriginal Affairs: Kununurra Area Office
(Question No. 3742)
Mr Campbell asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:
(I) Further to the Minister's answer to question No. 3180 (Hansard, IS October 1981, pages 2163-4) will the Minister provide a detailed description of the 12 positions now attached to the Kununurra area office, Western Australia, and an indication of salary ranges that apply to these particular positions.
(2) How many motor vehicles will be allocated to the Kununurra area office of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.
Mr Viner-The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(I) In my response to question No. 3180 I made it clear that there are nine approved positions attached to my Department's Kununurra office. Details of the nine approved positions are:

Answers to Questions

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3163

Area Officer, Clerk Class 8, $22693/23609. Duties: administer, control and co-ordinate the operation of the Area Office and represent the Department on all mallers relating to Aboriginal affairs within the East Kimberley Arr.a.
Senior Project Officer, Clerk Class 7, $20542/21772. Duties: deputise for the Area Officer as required; assist the Area Officer with the formulation of development plans for the advancement of Aboriginal communities and with the control of field operations within the area (two positions).
Project Officer, Clerk Class 5, $16874/18246. Duties: in consultation with Aboriginal communities, assess and recommend projects for inclusion in functional expenditure programs for which the Department is directly responsible (two positions).
Administrative Clerk, Class 4, $15044/16415. Duties: provide administrative support to the Area Officer in the preparation and submission of the Area program; maintain systems for recording programming and project control documentation (one position).
Field Officer, Clerical Assistant Grade 6, $14186/14917. Duties: establish personal contact and maintain communications and consultation with Aboriginal communities and organisations to identify needs and aspirations and ensure a two-way How of information between Aboriginals and the Department (one position).
Assistant Field Officer, Clerical Assistant Grade 4, $12233/12737. Duties: maintain communications between Aboriginal communities and the Department as directed to facilitate development processes (one position).
Typist Grade I, $5102/10828. Duties: carry out typing, reception and general office duties (one position).
(2) There are five vehicles allocated to the Kununurra office. One of these is in Perth and will be transferred to Kununurra when the second Senior Project Officer position is filled.
Power Generation
Mr Thomson-On 27 October 1981 (Hansard, page 2460) Mr Barry Jones asked a question of the Prime Minister concerning the generation of power by hydrogen fusion induced by laser excitation. I advised that I would take the question on notice.
The Australian Research Grants Scheme of my Department has supported Professor Hora of the University of New South Wales to carry out basic theoretical research in this field. He is examining the interaction of lasers with plasmas and has received a total of $109,271 for his research over the past five years.
Fusion research falls within the responsibility of my colleague, the Minister for National Development and Energy, whose Department has provided the following statement:
The Government is aware of experiments being carried out in the USA on inertial confinement fusion methods which include laser induced fusion. The complexity of both these and magnetic confinement systems which include tokamaks is such that they are still in the phase of proving technical feasibility. It is evident, however, that both will be complex systems, physically large and with large power output per unit.

Commercially viable systems will necessarily require development over a long-span of years, making it difficult at this time to predict what ot her energy sources they might replace.
The Government is supporting some research in Australia on both the inertial and the magnetic confinement methods for producing nuclear fusion. In addition, Australian membership of the International Fusion Research Council provides the opportunity to keep up to date with overseas developments.

Answers to Questions

4 (a) Maximum penalties that could have been imposedHealth Insurance Act 1973Section 129: Penalty $10,000 or imprisonment for 5 years National Health Act 1953Section 88: Penalty $200 or imprisonment for 6 months Section 103: Penalty $200 or imprisonment for 6 months Section 134: Penalty $200 or imprisonment for 6 months Crimes Act 1914Section 19B: Where a person fails to observe the conditions of his recognizance (good behaviour bond), the court may convict him of and sentence him for the offence with which he was originally charged. Section 29A: Imprisonment for 5 years Section 29B: Imprisonment for 2 years Section 67B: Imprisonment for 10 years
(4) (b) While I appreciate the need to provide as far as possible information sought by honourable members, I do not consider it would be appropriate in this instance for there to be the extensive redeployment of resources away from other functions that would be necessary in order to provide the information requested.
Information for the preparation of this reply was made available by my colleague, the Minister for Health, from records held within that Department.
MANDATA System: Department of Social Security
(Question No. 2221)
Mr Les Johnson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 12 May 1981:
(I) Has the MANDATA System been introduced in the Department of Social Security and Government instrumentalities under the Minister's control; ifso, what was the:
(a) cost of (i) the equipment, (ii) installation, (iii) site preparation, (iv) acquiring or renting sites and (v) other additional factors associated with the introduction of the system and
(b) total cosi of introducing the system.
(2) Were any reductions in the staff of personneljestablishment units achieved as a result of introducing this system; ifso, what:
(a) reductions in staff and (b) cost savings were achieved in each year since its
introduction.
(3) What staff:
(a) saving or (b) increase is expected with the termination of the
MANDATA System.
(4) What is the anticipated:
(a) extra cost or (b) saving resulting from the termination of the MAN-
DATA System.
Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(I) Yes, in the Department of Social Security in the Australian Capital Territory, New South Wales and Victoria.

(a) and (b) The cost of the purchase and installation of the central computer was outlined in the answer provided to Parliamentary Question 2209 by the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister.
The total direct cost to the Department of Social Security of introducing MANDATA was approximately $42,000, comprising $3,000 for the preparation of sites for remote visual display units and $39,000 in salaries for staff involved in the planning for data ,pickUp, the actual data pickup and file purification.
(2) No.
(3) The decision to terminate MANDATA is not expected to have any impact on the Department's staffing.
(4) The Department of Social Security is replacing MANDATA with its own personnel information system. This system is not expected to cost staff resources and has been made possible by the Department's recent move to improved computing facilities. Because of network improvements and the on-line nature of the personnel information system, it has been necessary to purchase some new items of equipment. The cost of this equipment is expected to be in the vicinity of $100,000. Not all of the items purchased are for the ex<;iusive use of the new personnel information system.
Invalid Pension
(Question No. 2490)
Dr Klugman asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 5 June 1901:
(I) Do applications for an invalid pension now take an average of 10 weeks to process,
(2) Is the delay even greater when a medical report from a specialist is required.
(3) If so, is the Minister able to say whether this is due to delays experienced within the Department of Health.
Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(I) On average, over all States, applications for the invalid pension take about seven weeks to process.
(2) The average processing time of those applications requiring a specialist report is longer. This is due largely to the length of time it takes to secure specialist appointments, However, new claims requiring specialist examination are infrequent; and where delays are experienced, other forms of income support are available.
(3) When all necessary information is available there is little delay in the Department of Health providing a report to the Department of Social Security, When further information is required from general practitioners, hospitals or specialists there are delays in obtaining the necessary information on which to make a report. Such delays are outside the control of the Department of Health.

Teacher Education
(Question No. 2746)
Mr Milton asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:
(I) Have any major inquiries into teacher education recommended the provision of four years pre-service preparation for primary school teachers as an educational priority; if so, which ones, and when was each published.

(2) Is such a course an educational priority of the Commonwealth Government.
(3) Has the Commonwealth Government provided any funding for four year pre-service preparation of primary teachers in the Australian Capital Territory.
(4) What is the current provision of funding for these courses to the States.
(5) What is the formula for the transfer of costs between the States and the Commonwealth for these programs.
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) A major Commonwealth inquiry, the Natioanallnquiry into Teacher Education (NITE), presented its Report in August 1980. The Committee was generally agreed that four years' training was a target to be achieved during the 1980's for all teachers. Some members of the Committee, while not opposing a fOllr-year preparation, were of the opinion that the final year should be undertaken in association with in-service training.
Prior to the establishment of NlTE, a policy of four-year training existed in Tasmania. During 1979 and 1980, inquiries were conducted in the other States which canvassed various aspects of teacher education, including the question of a minimum period of pre-service preparation. Four of these inquiries supported a four-year period of initial training; the conclusion of the fifth (WA) was that any mandatory extension of the present three year course was not warranted.
(2) Following receipt of the NlTE Report, it was decided that as the issues raised were of significant concern to the States, there was a need for a collective discussion by Ministers for Education of the various recommendations. This discussion took place at the 43rd Meeting of the Australian Education Council in February 1981. Council did not endorse the recommendation concerning four years' initial preparation, but did support the general principle of extending the length of teacher preparation. Ministers agreed that this might include further development of a variety of approaches.
(3) Courses at the Canberra College of Advanced Educ cation, are funded by the Commonwealth Government. All under-graduate pre-service teacher education students are enrolled in the four-year Bachelor of Education course. Students may terminate their training at the end of three years when they are eligible to take out a Diploma of Teaching, a basic qualification for entry into primary teaching.
(4) and (5) the financial arrangements for the provision of funds to universities and colleges of advanced education have been agreed between the States and the Commonwealth. The arrangements for the funding of four-year pre-service courses for primary school teachers in these institutions are the same as those made for other higher education programs. The agreed arrangements provide that teacher education programs, proposed by the State and acceptable to the Commonwealth, are fully funded by the Commonwealth under States Grants legislation.
Unemployment Benefit: Means Test
(Question No. 2790)
Mrs Darling asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:
(I) Is it a fact that the Victorian State Liberal Minister for Youth, Sport and Recreation has urged the Commonwealth Government to lift the ceiling on all allowable extra earnings, that is, the means test, for those receiving unemployment benefits, and has called on the Government to increase unemployment benefits in line with consumer price index increases.

Answers to Questions

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3169

(2) If so, is he able to say whether the Victorian Minister's suggestions were made following a Victorian State Government report on youth homelessness.
(3) Has he seen the report.
(4) If so, did the report indicate that by increasing unemployment benefit and easing the means test, the social and psychological consequences of long term unemployment would be relieved, and young .people could be provided with vital work experience as well as promoting individual initiative.
(5) Will the Minister consider these proposals of his Liberal colleague in the Victorian Parliament.
Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(I) to (3) In releasing a report prepared by five Victorian Government Departments for the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare, the Victorian Minister for Youth, Sport and Recreation did urge the Commonwealth to review unemployment benefits and bring them into line with movements in the Consumer Price Index. He also recommended an easing in the income test on these benefits.
(4) The report identifies many factors as contributing to the homeless status of young people in Victoria, and states that the causes can be expected to be complex, inter-related and mutually compounding. Inadequate finance was identified as the only one of a set of contributing factors. Other factors included the state of the housing market and youth access to it, family breakdown and social problems affecting young people.
(5) Unemployment benefit rates are 'currently automatically indexed for price movements except for the single people aged 16 years to 17 years and aged 18 and over without dependants, although the latter rate was increased in November 1981 in line with the increases in indexed rates over the last year.
Factors that need to be taken into account about proposals to index all unemployment benefit rates and to further relax the income test include the extent to which they might reduce incentives to undertake full-time work or further education, or increase incentives to leave the parental home.
The Government has a continuing concern with the problems of youth homelessness, and gives careful consideration to proposals aimed at alleviating such problems that are put before it.
All proposals must be considered in the light of the Government's overall economic objectives and with regard to competing priorities in the welfare field.

(Question No. 2892)

Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

(I) As at 24 August 1981 the number of claims for disadvantaged persons health care cards received in each State was
as follows:

800 1,750 1,700

These figures relate to applications received from persons ap-
plying on the basis of low income and from recent migrants. Unemployment and special beneficiaries do not have to apply. Eligible unemployment and special beneficiaries current at I
September 1981 would have qualified for the health care card automatically.

Applications for health care cards may also be lodged retrospectively. As a result, many people who are eligible on
the basis of low income or as migrants may be expected to defer applying for the card until they seek medical treatment.

(2) Information about the number of claims approved at
the time is not readily available but the general experience has been that between 10 per cent and 15 per cent require further inquiry or rejection.

Pensioner's Non-interest Bearing Accounts
(Question No. 2893)
Mrs Darling asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 27 August 1981:
(I) Further to the Minister's Statement in relation to Pensioners' non-interest bearing accounts, and the relation to the pension means test, what is regarded by the Government as (a) a reasonable amount of money in non-interest bearing accounts, which would be exempt from the application of the means test and (b) the reasonable purposes referred to, for which pensioners may liquidate income producing assets.
(2) Will it be possible for a pensioner to sell a house which he or she has been renting out, for the purpose of using the balance remaining from the sale for an overseas trip.
(3) If so, will the pensioner be required to seek approval for such a transaction before proceeding.
(4) Will the Department's view of assessable extra income conflict in any way with that of the Australian Taxation Office

3170 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Answers to Questions

as to what constitutes income on which taxation might be payable, for example, the Taxation Office does not require payment of taxation on the amount of savings in non-interest bearing accounts because it does not regard this as income.
Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(I) When the legislation concerning these matters has been introduced further announcements will be made on the operational aspects of the new provisions. However, as indicated in my second reading speech on the Social Services Amendment Bill 1981, it will be considered reasonable for a single person to hold an amount to the order of $2,000 in a nonincome producing form. The corresponding figure for a married couple will be to the order of $3,000. Again, as was made clear in my statement on 18 August 1981, the provisions will not operate to penalise people who liquidate income producing assets for reasonable purposes such as the purchase of a home, or a car or to finance a holiday.
(2) Yes.
(3) No.
(4) Where a person maintains a large sum of money in a non-income producing form in order to qualify for a pension or fringe benefits, it is the intention of the proposed legislation to deem income to have been received for pension purposes. Such deemed income will not be treated as assessable income for .income tax purposes. The difference in treatment relates to the different functions of the social security system and the personal income tax system. The definition of income used in the assessment of pension entitlement is intended to provide a basis on which to establish a pensioner's need for income support. This can be a different matter to assessing a person's liability to pay income tax.
Drugs: Suneillance of Australia's Coastline
(Question No. 2985)
Mr Les Johnson asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 9 September 1981:
(I) Which of the specific recommendations in the report of the Australian Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs relating to the Surveillance of Australia's coastline (Book B, page 8441) (a) have been accepted, (b) have been rejected and (c) are still under consideration.
(2) What is the cost of implementing the recommendations which have been accepted.
(3) What new equipment has been purchased for surveillance purposes since January 1981.
Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
The honourable member has referred to those recommendations of the Royal Commission listed on page B441 of Book B. Page B441 in fact represents only the beginning of a list of some sixteen recommendations relating to coastal surveillance, which appear on pages B441-443. Accordingly, I have addressed my answer to all sixteen recommendations; these were more specifically identified in Book D of the report of the Royal Commission as recommendations Nos 102 to 117.
( I) (a) Recommendations 102, 104, 107, 108, 111-114 and 116 have been accepted. The following recommendations have been accepted subject to qualification.
No. 103: Accepted, insofar that the emphasis in relation to areas adjacent to major centres of population is best represented by a capacity to assist Customs and the Australian Federal Police in responding to intelligence that they receive.

No. 105: Accepted on the basis that in this instance the term Australian Coastal Surveillance Centre referred in fact to the Australian Coastal Surveillance Standing Interdepartmental Committee, which is the Commonwealth body responsible for the management of coastal surveillance. The Review of Coastal Surveillance, now in progress, will report on the Committee's role in the light of this recommendation. .
No. 106: Accepted, subject to the realisation that in the case of aircraft intrusions, a high level of successful monitoring is unlikely to be achieved given the extreme difficulty of tracking aircraft in Hight in remote areas. Other methods of obtaining intelligence on suspect aircraft activities are being examined.
No. 109: Accepted on the understanding that familiarisation and liaison visits are preferable to lengthy periods of secondment. We are currently in touch with the States and the Northern Territory on this matter.
(I) (b) None of the recommendations have been rejected outright.
(I) (c) Recommendations Nos 110, 115 and 117 are still under consideration.
(2) A number of the recommendations are related to Civil Coastal Surveillance Policy and do not give rise to direct costs. The costs of others depend either on the outcome of the Coastal Surveillance -review or the result of discussions between the Commonwealth and the States and Northern Territory.
I have been advised that the cost of implementing No. 116 is estimated to be $3.027m based on current prices.
(3) None.

(2) The number of applications received as at 4 September 1981 was:
(a) The Brisbane metropolitan area: 1,903 (b) Queensland: 3,613.
Public Service Superannuation
(Question No. 3070)
Mrs Kelly asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 10 September 1981:

Answers to Questions

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3171

(I) Do the same provisions of the Superannuation Act apply to Public Service officers over and under 60 years of age?
(2) Are officers over 60 years entitled to a lump sum payment?
(3) Are officers under 60 years entitled to a choice of either a lump sum or pension payments regardless of the number of years of service; if so, will the anomaly which discriminates against officers over 60 years be removed?
(4) Does Public Service Board circular (Ref: 81/3210) indicate that officers 60 years and over are entitled to a lump sum?
Mr Viner-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) No. The level of Government-financed pension and any contributor-financed pension payable on age retirement under the Superannuation Act 1976 depends, inter alia, on the contributor's age at retirement. Contributors below age 60 with contributory service of at least one year are entitled, on involuntary early retirement, to the option of a lump sum in lieu of a Government-financed pension; contributors over age 60 do not have this option. However, contributors who were members of thesup.erseded Provident Account under the Superannuation Act 1922 are entitled to an option of a lump sum in lieu of a Government-financed pension on voluntary or involuntary retirement after age 60 (this option was provided on a no detriment basis as benefits for Provident Account contributors were in the form of a lump sum only).
(2) All persons who cease to contribute to the scheme (except those on leave without pay) are.eligible to receive a lump sum benefit of their contributions plus interest, in addition to any Government-financed benefits payable. Government-financed benefits for contributors who are over age 60 on retirement may be in the form of a lump sum if retirement is on the ground of invalidity after a short period of service or if the contributors were members of the superseded Provident Account.
(3) Benefits for contributors retiring on the ground of invalidity before age 60 may be in the form of a lump sum if their period of service is short or they were members of the superseded Provident Account. Contributors below age 60 with contributory service of at least one year have the choice, on involuntary retirement, of taking their Governmentfinanced benefits in the form of a pension (which reduces to nil where age at retirement is below 36) or a lump sum payment.
The lump sum option on involuntary retirement below age 60 is intended to give staff who are required to retire before a normal age for retirement a greater degree of flexibility in that they might pay the amount into a superannuation schem~ of a new employer or otherwise use it to provide for their ultimate retirement from the work force. On the other hand, contributors who have attained the age 60 are regarded as having reached a normal age for retirement and their Governmentfinanced benefits on involuntary retirement after that age take the form of the primary benefit available under the scheme, that is, a pension.
Consequently, it is not considered appropriate to amend the Superannuation Act 1976 to provide the option of a lump sum in lieu of a Government-financed pension to contributors retiring involuntarily after age 60.
(4) Paragraph 20 of PSB Circular 1981/17 as originally printed implied that all superannuation contributors who are retrenched had the option of taking their full superannuation benefits as a lump sum payment. In fact this is not the case and when the error was discovered in June the circular was reprinted and the paragraph now reads:

'Superannuation contributors who are compulsorily retired as a result of an excess staff situation will be eligible to receive a normal age retirement benefit if they have attained 60 years of age. Those compulsorily retired at an earlier age have the following involuntary retirement benefit options:
(a) a standard early retirement pension based on the pension that would have been payable if the date of retirement had been the contributor's 60th birthday, reduced by 4% for each year or part of a year that retirement occurs before age 60, plus additional pension based on accumulated contributions;
(b) standard early retirement pension as described above with a lump sum of accumulated contributions in lieu of additional pension; or
(c) a lump sum equivalent to three and a half times accumulated basic contributions plus any accumulated supplementary contributions.
Note: Standard early retirement pension in (a) and (b) above cuts out at retirement ages below 36.'
Social Welfare Division, Department of Social Security
(Question No, 3071)
Mrs Kelly asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 10 September 1981:
(I) Did the Prime Minister state on 30 April 1981 in relation to the review of the Social Welfare Division of the Department of Social Security that in the wider perspective the aim of the review is to establish the conditions under which there can be increased opportunities for all and better care for those in need.
(2) If so, how will the scaling down of the Social Welfare Division (Hansard, 30 April 1981, page 1848) allow increased opportunities for all and better care for those in need.
(3) Will the functions of the Social Welfare Division be transferred; if so, to where.
(4) What evidence was given of the need to scale down the Social Welfare Division.
(5) Will this evidence be made available to the pUblic.
(6) Who is conducting the review of the Social Welfare Division.
(7) Are outside consultants being employed on the Review.
(8) What are the qualifications of these consultants in social work.
(9)What fees have been or will be paid-to the consultants.
(10) What period will be spent on the Review.
(11) How many public service officers have been working on the review and for how many hours.
(12) Have extra staff been engaged to continue delivery of social welfare services.
(13) What backlog of work existed in the Social Welfare Division as at 9 September 1981.
(14) How many requests for childcare have not been processed.
Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(I) and (2) No. The particular reference in the Prime Minister's speech of 30 April 1981, mentioned by the honourable member, did not relate specifically to a review of the Social Welfare Division of the Department of Sodal Security but

3172 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Answers to Questions

was made in the context of the aim of the Review of Commonwealth Functions generally.
(3) and (4) The review of the Social Welfare Division was conducted in the context of the decision of the Review of Commonwealth Functions that social work activity by departmental social worl<:ers and welfare officers be confined to that directly related to the delivery of Social Security benefits or Commonwealth programs and rehabilitation services.
(5) No. Conclusions are being considered by the Public Service Board and my department initially and will be considered by the Government if necessary.
(6) to (9) The Public Service Board's Office was responsible for the review in consultation with the Department of Social Security.
(10) The review commenced in mid-August and was completed by the end of September.
(II) Two officers from my department were seconded to assist the Public Service Board with the review, which was conducted over the period 10 August to 4 September 1981. Several officers from the Board were involved with various aspects of the review but in conjunction with other tasks and projects. An accurate estimate of the man-hours devoted specifically to the review is not available.
(12) While there is a close link with welfare staff, the Social Welfare Division is not directly involved in the delivery of welfare services. However, during the course of and subsequent to the concurrent review into the Department's social work activity, normal recruitment, subject of course to ceiling restraints, has continued in respect of:
(a) Social Worker positions in Rehabilitation and Work Preparation Centres;
(b) all vacant Social Worker Class 2 positions in the Department's Regional Offices;
(c) other vacant positions, e.g. Social Worker Class I and Welfare Officer, where these represent the sole 'welfare position' in a particular Regional Office.
(13) The work of the Social Welfare Division largely consists of major ongoing projects. As these projects are not always undertaken against strict timetables it is not possible to assess a tangible level of backlogs or arrears at any given time.
(14) Requests for child care are exillllined by the Office of Child Care in the Department and no disruption to processing has resulted from the review of the Social Welfare Division.
Aboriginals Employed In Australian Public Service
(Question No. 3072)
Mrs Kelly asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 10 September 1981:
(I) How many Aboriginals have been employed in the Australian Public Service in each year from 1973 to date.
(2) Is the Government committed to a policy of providing improved employment opportunities for Aboriginals in the Public Service; if so, why has there been a real decline in the number of Aboriginals employed in the Public Service.
Mr Viner-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) The number of Aboriginals employed in the Australian Public Service is assessed by a survey conducted in October of each year. Results of theSe surveys indicate that Aboriginal employment in the Australian Public Service for the years 1973 to 1980 was as follows:

(2) Yes, through implementation of the National Employment Strategy for Aboriginals (NESA). Implementation of NESA in the Public Service has so far resulted in:

provision of some 1800 vocational training opportunities for unemployed Aboriginals

the identification of some 740 positions which require a

knowledge and understanding of Aboriginals and an ability

to communicate with them

.

development of a special intake program called the Clerks (Aboriginal Services) Program

the taking of special measures to bring employment opportunities in the Public Service to the attention of Aboriginal people.

Aboriginal employment in the Public Service -has declined
since 1974 as a result of the transfer of many functions and the
associated staff from the Service in the Northern Territory to bodies such as Aboriginal Councilsand the Northern Terri-
tory Public Service. Staff of these bodies are not employed under the Public Service Act and are therefore not included in the Public Service Board annual surveys of Aboriginal staff
employed in the Public Service. While the numbers of Abor-
iginal staff transferred from Public Service Act employment in this manner is not readily available, an indication of the impact of these transfers upon total Aboriginal employment in
the Service is provided in the table below.

For example, as will be seen' from the table, in 1974 some
1488 out of a total of 1757 Aboriginal staff employed under the Public Service Act were employed in the Northern Terri-
tory. The majority of these staff were employed as exempt staff in departments such as Aboriginal Affairs, Education, Health, Housing and Construction and the then Department
of the Northern Territory. With the bulk of the functions of these departments in the Northern Territory having been subsequently transferred to the above-mentioned bodies, the
number of Aboriginal staff employed in the Service in the Territory has been reduced from 1488 in 1974 to 114 in 1980. On the other hand, the number of Aboriginal Staff employed else-
where in the Service has increased from 269 in 1974 to 510 in 1980. This latter growth can be attributed in part to implementation in the Australian Public Service of the Govern-
ment's national Employment Strategy for Aboriginals.
