Canberra Airport
(Question No. 3160)
Mr Scholes asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 17 September 1981:
(I) What is the estimated cost of upgrading Canberra Airport to anternational standards.
(2) What is the estimated recurring cost of providing international terminal facilities, customs and quarantine, at the airport.
(3) What is the projected passenger traffic from international sources.
(4) Will he make available to the Parliament detailed financial studies which justify the proposal to upgrade Canberra Airport to international standards.
Mr Hunt-The answers to the honourable. member's questions are as follows:
(I) (2) (3) and (4), The Government has not considered any proposal to upgrade Canberra Airport to cater for regular international services, nor am I aware of any such proposal from any airline to operate such a service. Therefore, I am unable to provide any detailed costs for any firm proposal.
Companies Act: Proposals for Amendments
(Question No. 3213)
Mr Jacobi asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 23 September 1981:
(I) Further to the answers which I sought to a number of matters during the debate on the Companies Bill 1981, and despite his detailed response of 26 May 1981, will he consider each of the undermentioned proposals as a basis for appropriate amendments to the Companies Act.
(2) In section 5 of the Act, Interpretation, is it a fact that, because of the Government's failure to simplify companies legislation, there are at least 6 confusingly similar but technically distinct modes of referring to the corporate entities to which the Act is in various ways applicable, namely, company, body corporate, corporation, foreign company, recognised company and recognised foreign company.
(3) Does the Government agree that exempt proprietary companies and the privileges associated with them should be abolished and all limited companies should be compelled to prepare and file audited reports; if not, why not.
(4) Under section 7 of the Act, Subsidiaries, holding companies and related corporations, will he initiate a fundamental reform of the company law, including the provision of statutory powers to the courts, to enable the lifting of the corporate veil in appropriate circumstances, including that whereby a holding and subsidiary company elfectively operates as a unit and where a private company acts as a trustee for a trading trust; if not, why not.

(5) Under section 12 of the Act, Power of Commission to require production of books, will he ensure that the powers of inspection given to the NCSC should be extended to ensure the fullest possible access of the Commission to books; if not, why not.
(6) Under section 16 of the Act, Privilege, will he ensure that any provision which enables questionable practices to be hidden. by means of legal professional privilege will be amended; if not, why not.
(7) With respect to sections 33 to 37 of the Act, does the Government agree that the Act should include a requirement for all companies to raise and maintain a prescribed minimum nominal and paid-up capital; if not, why not.
(8) With respect to sections 40 to 64 concerning names provisions, do the cumbersome provisions in respect of company names need to be rationalised, and is a good deal of the complexity attributable to the numerous related but technically distinct names applicable to the corporate entity.
(9) Has the opportunity been lost in the Act to simplify the company names procedure by enabling companies to make an available search on a national basis; if so, will he undertake to rationalise these sections as quickly as possible.
(10) Under section 67, Powers, does the Government agree that ii should have power to require disclosure of donations made by companies for political purposes; if not, why not.
(II) Under sections 94 to 109 dealing wit' prospectus provisions, is there a need for a full review of the provisions relating to fund-raising and prospectuses so as to ensure maximum disclosure and to require independent valuation of assets exchanged for sh1\re issues; if so, when will the Ministerial Council undertake such a review; if not, why not.
(12) Will he seek to amend section 117, Power to make certain payments, so that the discount allowed therein applies only to commissions paid to under-writers and the brokerage fees paid to registered sharebrokers in connection with an issue of company shares.
(13) Did the Explanatory Memorandum to the Bill, at paragraph 302, suggest that section 117 deals, in elfect, with the payment of commissions and brokerage and is based on section 58 except that it has been amended to cover all payments-cr. Fifth Interim Report of Eggleston Committee, paragraph 87; if so, did the Eggleston Committee recommend that the section should cover all payments or did it recommend that the section should make it clear that both underwriting and brokerage commissions at current commercial rates could be paid without contemplating that other payments or discounts should be permissible.
(14) Does section 117 as presently worded appear to permit a company to make a payment or provide a discount of up to 10 per cent of the issue price of the shares to any person or persons who undertakes to subscribe for, or to procure subscriptions for, the shares so that an ordinary subscriber could be given a discount of up to 10 per cent, and is it only if the company's memorandum or articles prohibit (cf. 'authorise' in section 58) the making of such a payment that it may not be made.
(15) Is it a fact that section 5 of Table A of Schedule 3 permits the company to exercise the power to pay commissions conferred by the Act, while the Act does not specifically mention commissions, and the power to pay such brokerage as is lawful.
(16) Is it also a fact that section 117 seems to permit more than one payment of up to 10 per cent of the issue price to be made in connection with the one share' issue, thus permitting an underwriter, a broker and subscriber to each receive a payment or discount equivalent to 10 per cent of this issue price, making a total payment of 30 per cent; if so, would such a result be considered scandalous.

3174 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Answers to Questions

(17) In section 125, Rights of holders of classes of shares, and in view of sub-sections 72 (I) and 73 (5) of the Act, does sub-section 125 (2) permit the alteration of a class rights clause which is contained in a company's memorandum of association, where there is no existing variation procedure or prohibition contained therein; if so, could this doubt be resolved by amending sub-section 125 (2) to read: 'Where rights are attached to shares included in a class of shares whether in the memorandum or articles of association of the company or otherwise',
(IS) Bearing in mind sub-section 72 (I) of the Act, can a class rights provision in a company memorandum be altered under sub-sections 125 (2),126 (2) or 127 (2).
(19) Does anything in these sections expressly say that the memorandum may be altered, although a variation may be added.
(20) If a company can alter a class rights clause in a memorandum, how can this be done, that is, by special or ordinary resolution.
(21) Is it a fact that the new paragraph 125 (2) (a) negates sub-section 73 (2) which indicates that a special resolution would be required (except for sub-section 73 (5, and sub-section 73 (5) should be amended to permit such alterations provided that section 125, 126 or 127 is complied.
(22) Will he give an assurance that the matters referred to in parts (17) to (21) will be clarified as quickly as possible.
(23) With respect to sections 129 and 130, Company fjnancing dealings in its shares, etc.; and Consequences of company financing dealings in its shares, etc, is a reform needed of the provisions relating to companies financing dealings in their own shares and, in particular, (a) should the exemption for financial assistance given to salaried directors in paragraphs 129 (I) (a) and 129 (I) (b) be removed and be a reference to paragraph 129 (9) (b), (b) should sub-section 129 (4) be clarified so that it is apparent which of a company's officers or employees must be aware of relevant facts for the company to be held to be aware of the same facts, and (c) should possibilities for abuse of sections 129 and 130 be further,considered; if not, why not.
(24) In section 229, Duty and liability of officers, will'he take take steps to insert a new sub-section based on section 3 of the Swedish Companies Act 1975 which deals with the protection of shareholders; if not, why not.
(25) In section 229, Duty and liability of officers, should provision be made for a higher standard of competence, care and diligence for directors and officers of companies and, in particular, should the standard of skill which is appropriate to directors and other officers be made explicitly objective.
(26) In relation to share transfers made to avoid liability for future calls, should a provision be inserted in the Act similar to section 391 of the South Australian Companies Act 1962-1979 to provide that any transfer of shares made within a period of 2 years before the commencement of the winding up of the company to any person known to the transferor to be unable to pay the liability on those shares shall not relieve the transferor of that liability.
(27) Does he still contend that a provision similar in effect to section 391 of the South Australian Companies Act was included in the April 19S0 exposure draft of the Companies Bill' at section 21SA with the only substantive difference between the 2 provisions being that, for the purposes ofsection 391, the relevant period is 2 years, whereas for clause 21SA, it was one year.
(2S) Was section 21SA deleted from subsequent drafts of the Companies Bill on the basis that it did not add anything to what is now section 360 of the Act (section 21S in the ICAC Companies Act) which provides that, subject to certain qualifications, every past and present member of a company

will be liable to contribute to the company's assets as it is being wound up.
(29) Will he undertake to reconsider the proposal to include section 391 of the South Australian Companies Act in the context of the overall review of the winding up provisions, and, in particular, those provisions dealing with the liabilities of contributories.
(30) Does he still contend that the only substantive difference between section 391 of the old South Australian Act and section 360 of the Commonwealth Act is that the relevant period is 2 years under section 391 whereas it is one year under section 360,
(31) Is the answer to part (30) well illustrated by transfers of shares in an unlimited liability company to a $2 limited liability company during the one or 2 years prior to winding up, and are shareholders in an unlimited liability company at the time the company commences to be wound up jointly and severally liable, without limit, for the debts of the company.
(32) Is it a fact that (a) it is only if those members are unable to contribute enough funds to satisfy those debts that past members may be liable under section 360 whereas under the old section 391 if the transfer was made to avoid liability on the shares the transferor remained liable, jointly and severally, (b) if section 391 had applied in Victoria when the Garrety Group of unlimited liability investment companies collapsed, the Garrettys could not have avoided personal liability for the companies' debts merely by setting up $2 companies and transferring their shares to those companies and (c) section 391 clearly served a useful purpose and should have been retained,
(33) In section 237, Provisions indemnifying officers or auditors, should 'officer' have the same meaning that it has in section 229 so that its provisions apply to privately appointed receivers andcourt appointed receivers, receivers and managers, and liquidators.
(34) Does the definition of 'officer' in sub-section 5 (I) apply to section 237 unless the contrary intention appears and is there nothing in section 237 itself to suggest a contrary intention, whereas the extended definition of 'officer' in section 229 is expressed by that section to apply only to that section; if so, will he take steps to clarify this matter as quickly as possible.
(35) With respect to section 247, Circulation of members' resolutions, etc. should individual members be able to insist on the company forwarding details of any resolution of the members at the same time as the notice of meeting is sent to all members with the expense of this being borne by the company.
(36) Should it also be possible for an individual shareholder to cause the company to circulate on his behalf a statement with respect to any business to be dealt with at the meeting with the cost of this circulation being at the shareholders' expense unless the company otherwise agrees.
(37) Does he still contend that section 247 is similar in effect to section 143 of the ICAC Companies Acts and also to clause 130 of the National Companies Bill.
(3S) If an individual member feels that the company is unreasonably preventing him from bringing the attention of members to a resolution he is proposing, may he then utilise the provisions of section 320 of the Act to seek a remedy; if so, how could directors, consistent with their duty, do less than explain in the notice of a meeting the effect of any resolutions to be proposed by members, and disclose any material interests of their own (Jenkins Committee paragraph 467).
(39) What is the justification for making the company rather than the relevant member/s pay for copies of resolutions circulated.

Answers to Questions

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3175

(40) Could this lead to individual members proposing meaningless resolutions in the knowledge that it is the company as a whole, and not themselves, which has to bear the expense of circulating such resolutions.
(41) Could the suggested problems with the proposal be readily overcome by a section which allowed the company to obtain relief from the obligation, if the procedure was being used for frivolous, vexatious or illegal purposes.
(42) Has his attention been drawn to the Swedish experience which suggests that in reality shareholders are unlikely to abuse the procedure.
(43) Has his attention also been drawn to the fact that section 7 of Chapter 9 of the Swedish Companies Act 1975 states that a shareholder is entitled to have a matter dealt with at a general meeting of shareholders provided that the board of directors has received a request there for early enough to include the matter in the notice convening the meeting so that the company bears the expense of complying with such requests; if so, will he reconsider this matter and undertake to have it re-examined by the Ministerial Council.
(44) With respect to section 261, Power of company to obtain information as to beneficial ownership of its shares, will he seek to amend the Companies Act to provide for full .disclosure to the public of the beneficial ownership of all shares in companies; if not, why not.
(45) With respect to section 270, Directors' reports, will he seek to amend section 170 to provide (a) for directors' reports to state the details of the emoluments of directors which are included in the aggregate amount of emoluments shown in the accounts and (b) that the fixed salary of directors who are also full time employees must be disclosed; if not, why not.
(46) Will he seek to amend section 277, Qualifications of auditors, so that in sub-sections 277 (2) and 277 (12) the word 'unlimited' is inserted before 'exempt proprietary company'; if not, why not.
(47) Will he undertake to omit section 279, Exempt proprietary company need not appoint auditor in certain circumstances, from the Companies Act; if not, why not.
(48) Will he seek to amend section 320, Remedy in cases of oppression or injustice, to provide adequate remedies for shareholders where the affairs of the company are being conducted in an oppressive manner, and, in particular, make provision for (a) extending the concept of oppression to single and anticipated acts unfairly prejudicial to a shareholder and (b) a body such as a 'Shareholders Tribunal' to protect the interests of minority shareholders; if not, why not.
(49) In section 320, Remedy in cases of oppression or injustice, does sub-paragraph 320 (I) (a) (ii) merely restate the provisions of paragraph 364 (I) (f) which allows a shareholder to apply for a company to be wound up, if directors of the company are acting in their own interests rather than in the interests of the company as a whole; if so, what action will he take in this matter.
(50) With respect to section 324, Liability of receiver, will he seek to have included in the Act a provision in similar terms to section 345B of the New Zealand Companies Act, which provides that a receiver or manager of the property of a company who sells any of that property shall exercise all reasonable care to obtain the best price reasonably obtainable as at time of sale, the concept being that this duty is one that is owed by the receiver to the company, and it is not to be a defence to any action or proceeding brought by the company against the receiver or manager in respect of a breach of that duty that the receiver or manager was acting as the agent of the company, or under a power of attorney given by the company, nor is the receiver or manager entitled to be indemnified or compensated by the company for any liability he may incur as a result of the breach of his duty; if not, why not.

(51) With respect to section 535, Power to grant relief, will
he seek to amend sub-section 535 (4) so that it covers all persons who come within the section 229 definition of 'officer' and, in particular, so that privately appointed receivers who
are not also managers will be able to take advantage of the provisions of section 535; if not, why not.

(52) Will he take urgent steps to have a definition of profit included in section 565, Dividends payable from profits only.

(53) Would the definition of 'profit' in clause 376 of the exposure draft have entrenched most of the current unsatisfactory common law rules relating to profits available for dividend purposes.

(54) As the point was made during the debates that no distribution of dividends should be possible unless after the distribution the company's paid-up share capital would be represented by net assets, which is the basic EEC position as evidenced by the 1980 UK. Companies Act, will he ensure that an appropriate amendment on this matter will be included when dealing with forthcoming amendments.

(55) With respect to section 245, Proxies, will he seek to
amend the Act so that a shareholder will have the right not only to appoint a proxy but also to instruct a proxy in certain
specific and important matters, such as the appointment or dismissal of a director or an auditor.

(56) Will he reconsider the implementation of the mandatory use of two-way proxies which would encourage shareholders to exercise the right particularly where the chairman of the meeting is appointed as proxy.

(57) Will he ensure that such rights are provided for in the forthcoming amendments particularly as they relate to such important matters.

(58) Will he seek to amend the section of the Act dealing
with trading trusts so that, in order to protect creditors and to assist the prevention of tax avoidance, stringent disclosure re-
quirements will be imposed upon companies acting as trustees of trading trusts, or at the very least, the provisions of Parlia-
ment IV AA in the April 1980 exposure draft of the Companies Bill be reinstated; if not, why not.

(59) In PART VI, ACCOUNTS AND AUDIT, Division 2, Accounts, will he undertake to have included in any
Companies Bill a requirement that listed companies prepare more frequent accounts; if not, why not.

(60) With respect to PART XII, WINDING UP, will he consider a complete reform of the winding up provisions in
the Act and, in particular, will he refer the whole question of
insolvency to the Australian Law Reform Commission for their examination; if not, why not.

(61) Will he give a guarantee that in any review of
company law he will undertake to consult with the National Institute of Criminology as to the appropriate amendments
needed to minimise corporation and white collar crime so rampant throughout society in Australia.

Mr MOORE-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(I) I have noted the matters raised by the honourable member in his question and will bear them in mind, to the
extent that they remain relevant, in the consideration by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities of possible
amendments to the co-operative companies and securities scheme legislation. I have set out, below, a number of comments on some of the individual matters raised.

(2) The following points should be noted so far as the use of

these terms is concerned:

.

(a) The Companies Act 1981 would be considerably longer and more complicated if it were decided to re-
place the terms referred to with descriptive references

3176 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Answers to Questions

within the body of each substantive provision indicating the circumstances in which a particular provision applied. The use of these different terms simply reflect differences in the way in which the Companies Act 1981 will apply to entitles having a different nexus with the relevant jurisdiction.
(b) The concept of a 'recognized foreign company' is new to the Companies Act only because it was thought that, consistent with the 'one place of registration' concept embodies in the scheme legislation, overseas corporations should have to register in only one of the jurisdictions covered by the scheme. The term is accordingly used to describe an overseas foreign company registered in a participating jurisdiction other than the A.C.T.
(c) A 'body corporate' is not separately defined in s. 5.11 is the terms used to encompass any corporate body however formed.
(3) This proposal would represent a major departure from existing Australian companies legislation. However, see my answer to question (I).
(4) There are a number of provisions in the Companies Act 1981 which already give recognition to the principle that in certain circumstances the 'corporate veil' should be lifted to impose personal liability on defaulting officers. An example of such a provision is s. 556 which provides that if a debt is incurred by a company when there were no reasonable grounds to expect that it could be repaid, then any defaulting officer will be guilty of an offence and jointly and severally liable with the company for the payment of the debt to the creditor.
The Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities has set up a working party to formulate proposals in relation to trading trusts for consideration by the Ministerial Council.
(5) The NCSC already has extensive powers, subject to certain safeguards, for the inspection of company books where criminal activity is suspected and represent a significant strengthening of the powers in the existing State and Territory companies legislation. However, see my answer to question (I).
(6) Section 16 of the Companies Act 1981 represents an attempt, on the one hand, to balance the policy objective that the NCSC should have adequate powers to obtain information for the purposes of exercising its functions with, on the other hand, the consideration that privileged communications between solicitor and client should be protected. The Honourable Member will be aware that section 16 has been amended by the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act 1981 to impose further disclosure requirements on legal practitioners who make a claim of legal professional privilege. These practitioners will not now be able to claim privilege in respect of:
(a) the name and address of the person on whose behalf the privilege is claimed; and
(b) the particulars required to identify the book, or the part of the book, containing the privileged communication.
(7) See my answer to question (I), When this question is considered, the following issues (among others) will need to be settled before any final decision could be made:
(a) An appropriate level for paid-up capital (The present United Kingdom Pounds Sterling is 50,000 for a public company).
(b) Whether proprietary companies should be required to have a minimum paid-up capital and what effect this would have on small business. (There is no minimum paid-up capital requirement for private companies in the UK Company Law Act 1980).

(c) The transitional provisions that are to apply to existing companies whose paid-up capital is less than the prescribed minimum.
(d) Whether the National Companies and Securities Commission should have a discretion to register companies with less than the statutory minimum capital.
(8) and (9) Division IV of Part III of the Companies Act is an attempt to deal as simply as possible with the procedures that are provided for in the Formal Agreement. See, however, my answer to question (I).
(10) II was not considered that a major new disclosure requirement of this nature was appropriate for inclusion in the initial companies legislation to be enacted under the cooperative scheme. See, however, my answer to question (I).
(II) The National Companies and Securities Commission is currently considering the fund-raising provisions of the Companies Act.
(12) to (16) I have asked my Department to undertake further work on these questions so that I can discuss the matter at an appropriate time in the Ministerial Council for
Companies and Securities. Among other things i have asked
my Department to have regard to para 87 of the fifth interim report of the Company Law Advisory Committee (Eggleston Committee) which is in the following terms:
'87 Section 58 deals with the questions of payment of brokerage or commission for subscribing or agreeing to subscribe for shares, or procuring or agreeing to procure subscriptions. Sub-sections (I), (2) and (4) refer only to commissions, and allow a commission of up to 10 per centum, subject to certain conditions. Sub-section (3) provides that nothing in the section is to affect the power of the company to pay such brokerage 'as it has hitherto been lawful for a company to pay' subject to certain requirements as to disclosure. Such a provision is obviously unsatisfactory, since it is extremely difficult to advise anyone with certainty as to what rate of brokerage was lawful in the early years of this century, when the provision was first introduced. Prior to the introduction of section 58, it was held in Metropolitan Coal Consumers Association v. Scrimgeour (1895) 2 Q.B. 604, that payment to brokers of a reasonable commission for their services in procuring SUbscriptions was lawful, and it seems that the United Kingdom equivalent to sub-section (3) was proposed by Lord Halsbury to preserve the effect of that decision. The brokerage paid in that case was in fact 2.5 per cent. The General Revision Bill proposed the repeal of sub-section (3) and the inclusion of a reference to brokerage where reference is made to commission elsewhere in the section. The form of the amendment would in our view leave room for doubt as to whether in some cases both brokerage and commission at the rate of 10 per cent each might not be allowable, and we would regard this as excessive in view of the rates of brokerage provided for in respect of share issues of which we have knowledge. In the draft in Appendix 'A' we have limited the total allowable for brokerage and commission to 10 per cent but we do not feel that the subject is one of which our views are entitled to any special weight '.
(17) to (22) The honourable member will be aware ofs. 35 to s. 37 of the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act 1981. See also my answer to question (I).
(23) See my answer to question (I).
(24) The issues raised by section 3 of the Swedish Companies act 1975 are complex and require careful consideration since that section impinges on the right of shareholders to use their voting power. II has been an implicit principle in our company law that a vote attached to a share is a property right and that a shareholder is entitled to deal with

Answers to Questions

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3177

that property right as he sees fit. There is, however, the safeguard that a shareholder may not use his voting rights to perpetrate a fraud on the minority (see e.g. s. 320 of the Companies Act).
(25) Section 229 of the Companies Act 1981 is wider than the corresponding provisions in s. 124 of the existing ICAC Companies Act.
(26) to (31) See my answer to question (I). The following differences between s. 391 of the Companies Act and clause 218A of the April 1980 exposure draft are noted:
(a) Sub-section 391 (2) only applies if the transfer was made with the purpose of avoiding or evading liability in relation to the shares in question. There was no such limitation in clause 218A.
(b) Para 218A (3) (d) contained'the new stipulation that the transfer would be void if consideration in relation to the transfer was paid to a relative of or a person associated with, the transferee.
(c) Sub-clause 218A (4) made it clear that nothing in clause 218A affected the liability of persons registered as the holder of the relevant shares at the time of the commencement of the winding up. There is no equivalent provision in s, 391.
The following additional differences between s. 391 of the South Australian Companies Act and s. 360 of the Companies Act 1981 are noted:
(a) s. 360 applies to make past members liable irrespective of the fact that the transfer of shares may have been made in good faith and for full consideration. In this sense, therefore, s. 360 is wider in scope than s. 391.
(b) s. 360 does not, with one exception, apply to past members unless existing members are unable to satisfy the company's liabilities. (Para 360 (I) (c. The applicability of s. 391 does not, however depend on this factor.
(c) The liability of past members pursuant to s. 360 for the company's debts does not apply in respect of debts contracted after they ceased to be members, (para 360 (I) (c whereas ifs. 391 applies then the liability of the transferor will continue without any restriction.
(d) s. 360 has special rules to cover the situation where the company in question has changed its status from a unlimited liability company to a limited liability company within 3 years of the commencement of the widing up.
(33) and (34) See now s. 49 of the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act 1981.
(35) to (42) Section 247 of Companies Act 1981 is similar in effect to section 143 of he ICAC Companies Acts and also to clause 130 of the National Companies Bill. See also para 467 of the Jenkis Committee Report, the terms of which are as follows:
'It appears to us that the language of section 207 (I) (a) to which reference is made above, is really little more than declaratory of the existing law as applied to the case with which the section deals. It is difficult to see how directors could consistently with their duty do less than explain the effect of the resolution to be proposed, and disclose any material interests of their own, and the effect thereon of the resolutions so far as different from their effect on the like interests of others. It may no doubt be said that if this is already the law there is no need of any statutory provision about it. There is force in this argument. On the other hand, the fact that section 207 (I) (a) makes specific provision for a particular case coupled with the fact that there is no general provision in the Act prescribing the duties of directors in relation to circulars dealing with matters to be discussed at meetings may mislead directors and other officers of a company into thinking that they need do no more than comply with the specific provisions of the Act. On the

whole, therefore, we think the inclusion in the Act of a general provision declaratory of the existing law on this matter may serve as a reminder to directors and other officers of duties of which they may not be fully aware. The provision we have in mind would require directors who issue a notice or other circular relating to a meeting of a company or of any class of its shareholders, to state with reasonable precsion the nature of the business to be transacted, giving such explanations and additional information as may be necessary, and in particular, where such information as may be necessary, and in particular, where such information is material, disclosing any interests of the directors in the proposed transactIons and the effect thereon of those transactions so far as it is different from their effect on the like interests of other members. As to the position of a member who issues circulars in his private capacity we do not think that his present position is so strong that the directors or his fellow members need to be protected against him by special legislation. '
(43) See my answer to question (1).
(44) The Eggleston Committee considered (para. II of the Second Interim Report) whether all nominee shareholders should be required to notify the company of the names of their principals. The Committee concluded that any general requirement applicable to all nominees would impose a heavy burden and would for the most part serve no useful purpose. The substantial shareholding provisions in the Companies Act (Division 4 of Part IV) have the effect of requiring full disclosure of any interests (be they beneficial or otherwise) a person or company has in a company where that interest is in more than 10 per cent of the voting shares of that company. The information given to a company in compliance with these provisions is required to be maintained on a public register (s. 143). The notification period for acquisition of, or changes in, substantial shareholdings has been reduced from 14 days to 2 days.
(45) I have directed my Department to examine these issues so that I can raise them in the Ministerial Council at an appropriate time. In so far as inspection of director's service contracts is concerned, it can be argued that this is a matter that should be regulated by the company's articles.
(46) and (47) See my answer to question (1).
(48) and (49) This Ministerial Council has asked the National Companies and Securities commission to prepare a report on the desirability of proposals that an alternative statutory remedy for shareholders should be provided to protect them against abuse of power by directors and other officers and persons. I am also considering the reforms that have been made in this area of the law by the United Kingdom Companies Act 1980 and the New Zealand Companies Amendment Act 1980.
(50) The Companies Act 1981 does not at present purport to provide a complete code of conduct regulating the behaviour of receivers. See however, my answer to question (I). In relation to the New Zealand provision itself, it should be noted that the position in New Zealand following the amendment is that although a receiver could be liable in certain circumstances for negligence, such circumstances could not relate to his decision to sell, but only to his subsequent conduct of the sale. His obligation under the section is to 'obtain the best price reasonably obtainable as at the time of sale'. The section does not state that he must exercise reasonable care in actually selecting the date of the sale.
(51) See s. 80 of the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act 1981.
(52) to (59) See my answer to question (1). The accounts of all companies are required to be prepared once every financial year (see s. 269 of the Companies Act 1981). In addition,
if a company is listed on the Stock Exchange, th,en the AASE

3178 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Answers to Questions

listing requirements on the preparation of accounts will apply. The relevant requirements are as follows:
listed companies must prepare reports on a half yearly basis.
additional requirements are placed on mining companies.
listing rules also require explanations and disclosure of information affecting a listed company or the market for its securities.
(60) See my answer to question (I).
(61) Consistently with practices it has adopted in the past, I would expect that the Ministerial Council would normally agree that any Bills containing substantive amendments to the co-operative scheme legislation will be exposed for public comment in order that all interested persons and organizations may express their views.
Porta printer
(Question No, 3267)
Mr McLean asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:
(I) Has his attention been drawn to the existence of the telephonic aid for the deaf called Portaprinter.
(2) If so, is he able to say what is the cost of this equipment.
(3) How many of these machines are in use by deaf people in each State and Territory.
(4) Have any Commonwealth Government departments and authorities installed these machines; if so, which departments and authorities.
(5) Has Telecom Australia offered, or does it intend to offer, any concessions, subsidies, or other assistance, in order to make this equipment more accessible to deaf people.
Mr Sinclair-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes. The Portaprinter is available direct from Intercept Communications Pty Ltd or through Telecom.
(2) The sale price of a Porta printer Plus is $996 to Government departments and Commercial Organisations, and $846 if sold to disabled persons and their respective institutions.
(3) Telecom understands that a total of 122 Portaprinters have been sold in Australia, of which 69 have been purchased for use by deaf people. Of the latter, there are 30 in New South Wales, 25 i.n Yictoda, nine in South Australia, four in Tasmania and one in Queensland.
(4) Telecom has purchased 21 units, the Department of Social Security three and the National Acoustic Laboratories five.
(5) No. Subsidies and assistance of this nature are considered within the overall framework of the Government's Social Security programs.
Postage Rates for Service Organisations
(Question No, 3275)
Mr Campbell asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice,.on 13 October 1981:
(I) With reference to the excellent work carried out by service organisations such as Apex, Lions and Rotary Clubs throughout Australia, has it been drawn to his attention that these organisations annually raise and contribute millions of dollars to community development and overseas aid and that thousands of dollars are spent annually by these service clubs on postage.

(2) Does he recognise that the costs of postage which is essential to these organisations as a form of communication to their members, limits the funds that would otherwise be available for worthwhile community projects.
(3) If so, will the Government consider re-c1assifying the postage rate for regular newsletters, dinner notices, et cetera, for these service organisations from category B to category A, if utilised by the service clubs in community projects.
Mr SincIair-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes.
(2) Yes.
(3) No. Eligibility requiremenfs for registration of publications are set out in the Australian Postal Commission Postal By-laws. Unless publications satisfy the special conditions prescribed in the Postal By-laws for inclusion in Category A, publications eligible for registration are classified as Category B publications.
Classification as a Category A publication is restricted to four types of organisations and registration is determined according to the dominant aims, intention or conduct of the person or organisation involved. Moreover, the dominant intention of the organisation in publishing the publication. is significant.
Category A registration is restricted to publications which are:
published by an organisation, the dominant purpose of which is the investigation or relief of particular disabilities of individual persons. Additionally, the publication must consist mainly of articles relating to that dominant purpose.
published by a religious organisation and contain articles which relate to the interests of members of that organisation. (Publications reflecting social, recreational and scholastic activities are excluded);
a 'returned serviceman's' publication; or
a 'country interest' publication.
(Note: Specially excluded from registration as Category A publications are the publications of the following types of organisations: social, recreational, motorists, employerjemployee, business (other than primary production) and professional.)
Australia Post has examined the constituent documents and activities of the Apex, Lions and Rotary organisations. Whilst it is recognised that these organisations are interested in and carry out worthwhile work in respect of the relief of disabilities of individual persons, activities of this nature do not rank as the dominant purpose and function of these organisations. Furthermore, their publications generally reflect the widerbased interests of the organisation and are concerned largely with administrative and social matters. Accordingly, the publications of Lions, Apex and Rotary are not eligible for Category A registration.
Pensioner Concession Cards
(Question No. 3285)
Mrs Darling asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:
Has any State branch of the Department of Social Security experienced delays in sending out pensioner concession cards; if so, what has been the cause of the delay.
Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

Answers to Questions

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3179

The ad hoc issue of pensioner concession cards was interrupted in Brisbane between 16 and 25 September 1981 owing to supply problems. In Sydney, staffing difficulties have delayed some card issues by up to twelve days.
Other States have experienced no delays in issuing concession cards.
South Australia and Victoria Boundary
(Question No. 3291)
Mr Jacobi asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:
(I) Has the Attorney-General's attention been drawn to the answer to Question No. 2704 given by the Minister for National Development and Energy (Hansard, 9 September 1981, page 1141), wherein the Minister indicated that the question of the exact location of part of the boundary (that is about 11.1 kms) between the States of South Australia and Victoria have never been clearly resolved nor has it been seriously challenged and that the question is one for resolution by the 2 states.
(2) If so and in view of the fact that this Il.l km distance is undefined, is it possible to reach a tentative conclusion from the judgments of Griffith C. J. in South Australia v, Victoria (1911) 12C.L.R. 667 and Stephen J. in Wardv. R. (1980) 29 A.L.R. 175 and the material they cite.
(3) Was the South Australia/New South Wales border before 1850, when Victoria was established, assumed to follow the 141 E longitude.
(4) Was the border delimited on the ground from a point near the Glenelg River on the south coast of Australia to the 36S latitude by an arrangement between New South Wales and South Australia which the High Court held in 1912 became binding upon its proclamation in 1847 and which was not subsequently varied.
(5) Was the line some 3 km west of where it should have been.
(6) When Victoria was separated from New South Wales in 1850 and its northern boundary was stated to follow the Murray River to the eastern boundary of the Colony of South Australia, is it now clear that this actual line followed the Murray bank on the south side, leaving the whole watercourse of the MurrllY in New South Wales.
(7) Was the original attempt to delimit the South Australian boundary south of the Murray intended to extend only to the Murray.
(8) Was the erroneous line then established continued to the Murray in 1850, but after Victoria was estabished.
(9) As no attempt was made to extend that line over the Murray, does it therefore follow thllt the Victorian boundary was established at the intersection of that line with the northern boundary of Victoria extending along the southern bank of the Murray.
(10) At that time anf for some time later was no attempt made to delimit the New South Wales/South Australia boundary north of the Murray; is so, does it folow that that boundary still followed the actual line of 141E longitude until the Victoria border.
(II) Was a proposal made simply to extend the actual South Australian/Victorian boundary north to the 'northern boundary of South Australia, but because it had then become apparent that the South Australian/Victorian boundary was inaccurate, the present New South Wales/South Australia boundary was delimited in 1868 following much more closely the true line of 141  E longitude.

(12) Although its line seems to have started physically on the north bank of the Murray (see Griffith C. J.'s judgment at page 696), does it seem clear that it must be taken to have extended from the actual Victorian border whatever that was (and at the time that was disputed).
(13) Does it follow that the New South Wales/South Australia border begins on the South bank of the Murray and that the whole watercourse of the Murray to the west of the border is within South Australia.
(14) In view of the fact that this portion of the boundary has not been delimited, presenting the possibility either of a legal vacuum or of jurisdictional conflict and difficulties, such as occurred in Ward's Case, what steps will be taken in an effort to resolve this problem' and to enable the question between the 2 States to be resolved in the public interest as quickly as possible.
Mr Viner-The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
It is not proposed to comment on the legal and other matters raised by the question. They are primarily the concern of the States involved.
Trade Development Centre, Melbourne
(Question No. 3311)
Mr Holding asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 14 October 1981:
(I) Did he issue a Press release on I October 1981 confirming the Government's decision to establish a Trade Development Centre in Melbourne for use by developing countries; if so, what is the expected cost of this proposal.
(2) What developing countries made representations to him requesting the development of this centre and what was the nature of those representations.
(3) Does the cost of this project represent additional funds in the overseas aid program or does it represent a reduction in the existing level of funding; if so, what particular programs will be cut or terminated.
Mr Malcolm Fraser-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes. The estimated cost for 1981-82 is $150,000.
(2) A number of informal approaches were made after successful establishment of a similar Centre in Sydney.
(3) No. Funding for the project was part of the 1981-82 aid vote.
Video Access Centres
(Question No, 3312)
Mr Holding asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 14 October 1981:
(1) When were the Video Access Centres in Carlton, Footscray and Williamstown, Vic., opened, and by whom were they opened.
(2) How many staff were employed at that time in each centre.
(3) When was each centre closed and what was the reason for the closure in each case.
(4) How many staff were employed at each centre at the time of clsure.

3180 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Answers to Questions

(5) Was any attempt made to provide alternative employment for staff with technical expertise; if so, what are the details.
Mr Wilson-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
I am informed by the Australian Film Commission that:
(I) The video centres at Carlton and Footscray were opened in the first half of 1974 by the Australian Film Institute, acting on behalf of the Film, Radio, and Television Board of the Australia Council. By August 1976 the centres had become autonomous incorporated bodies funded by grants from the Australian Film Commission. Carlton Video Centre became the Melbourne Access Video and Media Cooperative and subsequently moved to premises in Fitzroy. The Footscray centre merged with a centre in Altona into the Western Communications Co-operative and the premises .moved to Williamstown and subsequently to Newport.
(2) At the time of opening, the video centres at Carlton, Footscray and Altona each employed two full-time staff, as well as part-time paid assistants.
(3) Western Communications at Newport closed in July 1981 as a result of a decision by the Film Commission to discontinue funding to small video access centres. The centre at Fitzroy is still in operation, with support from the Film Commission.
(4) At the time of closure the Western Communications Co-operative had a staff of two full-time employees.
(5) The Commission has received advice that the two full time employees of the Western Communications Cooperative have obtained employment with a Television Station in Melbourne.
Drugs: Raids by Australian Federal Police
(Question No. 3323)
Dr Cass asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 14 October 1981:
(I) How many raids have been conducted by the Australian Federal Police in Victoria in the course of investigations of possible criminal activity in relation to drugs in each of the last 4 years.
(2) How many of these raids were carried out in the Melton, Deer Park, Laverton and Werribee areas in each year.
(3) How many (a) raids were carried out in the same areas on 31 May 1980 and I June 1980, and (b) premises were raided and on how many premises were drugs found.
(4) Were any of the raids conducted on the wrong premises due to incorrect addresses being given to the officers concern; if so, have apologies been provided to the occupants and if no apologies have been made, what is the reason.

Mr Newman-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
The Australian Federal Police has been responsible for drug invcstigations at the Federal level since 6 November 1979. Information relating to drug investigations prior to that date has been obtained from the records of the former Federal Bureau of Narcotics which then came within the portfolio of the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs.
(I) 1978222; 1979167; 1980 158; 198158 (to 30 October).
(2) 1978 Nil; 1979 2; 1980 Nil; 1981 Nil.
(3)(a) Nil; (b) Nil.
(4) No.
Education: Expenditure
(Question No. 3325)
Mr Hayden asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 15 October 1981:
(I) What sum was spent on (a) primary and (b) secondary education from funds provided by (i) the Commonwealth Government, (ii) each State government and (iii) other sources, specifying the major ones, for each year since 1970.
(2) Can he provide a breakdown of the figures sought in part (1) for (a) government, (b) catholic and (c) other private schools.
(3) What were the total enrolments for each of the categories referred to in part (2) for each of the same years.
(4) What was the expenditure per student (a) according to each source of funds and (b) in total, for each of the categories referred to in part (2) for each year.
(5) Will he provide these figures in both current expenditure and real terms.
(6) What was the retention rate for the matriculation year of secondary education for (a) males and (b) females in each of the categories referred to in part (2) for each year.
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I )-(5) Tables I to 3 provide the information sought from 1973-74 to 1979-80. These details were derived chiefly from data provided by the Commonwealth Schools Commission and comparable figures are not available prior to 1973-74, nor is it possible to produce information by State. Some information on individual State expenditure is available from other sources and is provided in the answer to Question No. 3326. Further information on the expenditure trends within the non-government sector are provided within the answer to Question No. 3327.
(6) Table 4 shows apparent retention rates from 1970 to 1980. These rates are measures of the tendencies of members of student cohorts to remain in school from the first secondary year to the final year of secondary schooling.

Education: Expenditure
(Question No. 3326)
Mr Hayden asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 15 October 1981:
(I) What was the total expenditure on education in Australia by (a) the Commonwealth Government, (b) each State government and (c) other sources, specifying the major sources, for each year since 1970.
(2) Can be provide a breakdown of the figures sought in part (I) between the major areas of (a) universities, (b) colleges of advanced education, (c) technical and further education and other technical education institutions, (d) secondary schools, (e) primary schools and (f) pre-schools.
(3) What proportion of gross domestic product was the total expenditure for each year specified.
(4) Will he provide the financial statistics requested in both current expenditure and real terms.
(5) Is he able to say what proportion of GOP expenditure was spent on education in OECD member countries for each of the same years.
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable, member's question is as follows:
(I) to (3) Tables I to 6 show expenditure in each State from 1973-74 to 1978-79 of Commonwealth specific purpose payments and expenditure from State government resources. Table 7 shows expenditure by both Commonwealth and State Governments in Australia from 1973-74 to 1978-79. Commonwealth expenditure in Table 7 includes specific purpose payments to the States, expenditure in the Territories and expenditure on programs not distributed to the States. As Commonwealth expenditure in Tables I to.6 is limited to specific purpose payments to the States, Table 7 is not a summary table. Different sources have been utilised in these tables from those used in Tables I and 2 in answer to Question No. 3325 in an endeavour to have information comparable across all sectors of education, but at the expense of'data provided for schools in Question No. 3325 not being strictly comparable with Table 7 here.
(4) The statistics requested have only been provided in current expenditure terms, as information is not readily available at this stage to convert these data to real terms.

(a) State Governments and Local Government Authorities.

Notes to Tables I to 7:

(i) 'Other higher education' is mainly expenditure on coIleges ofadvanced education, but expenditure by State Governments includes expenditure on teacher trainee allowances and

expenditure on agricultural colleges and institutions of a similar nature.

(ii) 'Vocational training' is mainly expenditure on colleges of technical and Further education.

(iii) 'Other' includes Aboriginal education, migrant and adult education and pre-school programs; disaggregated State-level expenditure on these items are not available.

(iv) See source (below) For inFormation on private sector expenditure on education.

Source: Derived from Expenditure on Education, Australia, 1978-79 ABS Cat. No. 5510.0.

InFormation for earlier years can also be obtained from this source.

(5) The following data compares public expenditure on Education as a percentage of Gross National Product in OECD member countries. Any comparisons of countries using this data should take into consideration differences between countries in such factors as national accounting practices, the structure of education and demographic patterns. The figures for Australia in this table are not directly comparable with the information on Government outlay on education in Australia as a percentage of Gross Domestic Product in Table 7.

Australian National Railways

(Question No. 3342)

Mr Morris asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 15 October 1981:

(I) What sum has the Australian National Railways Commission borrowed from (a) the domestic capital market and
(b) overseas capital markets for each year from 1976-77 to 1980-81 and what sum does it propose to borrow for 1981-82.

(2) What repayments of (a) principal and (b) interest are repayable to each of the 2 sources for each' year of 1976-77 until full repayment is completed, including proposed borow-
ings in 1981-82.

Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(I) (a) ANRC Borrowings from Domestic Capital Market: 1976-77 to 1981-82:

$m

1976-77-1979-80

1980-81

20

1981-82 . . .

26

The 1981-82 figure includes Public Loan No.4 of $I4m floated on 5 November, and private loan of $2m to make up shortfall in 1180-81 approved Loan Council borrowing program.
(b) No funds have been borrowed from overseas capital markets.
(2) Repayment of principal and payment of interest in respect Qf domestic capital market borrowings: 1976-77 to full repayment.

Financial year

Electorate Offices
(Question No. 3358)
Mr Wallis asked the minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 20 October 1981:
(1) Has the Government adopted the strong recommendation of the Remuneration Tribunal that, in electoral divisions of over 400,000 square kilometres, a second electorate office should be provided for the servicing of those large electorates.
(2) If so, when can it be anticipated that an announcement will be made regarding the details of facilities, staffing, et cetera, to be provided in those large electoral divisions.
Mr Newman-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes.
(2) I have written to the members concerned to inform them of the approved arrangements.

CHOGM-Security
(Question No. 3385)
Mr Robert Brown asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 21 October 1981:

3188 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Answers to Questions

(I) Did the Government ask Commonwealth Heads of Government to send security advisers to Melbourne prior to CHOGM so that they could assess the adequacy of security measures.
(2) If so, which countries participated and over what dates did the officers concerned visit Australia.
(3) What was the overall cost of this operation.
Mr Malcolm Fraser-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Commonwealth Member Governments were informed that if they wished to send advance security survey teams to inspect the planned security arrangements for CHOGM, as applicable to them, such visits could be made during September 1981.
(2) The Governments which availed themselves of this opportunity were Britain, Canada, Grenada, Guyana, India, Kenya, Malawi, New Zealand, Nigeria, Singapore, Sri Lanka, Tanzania and Zambia.
(3) Costs of these surveys were borne by the participating member governments.
Telecom: Country Residents
(Question No. 3388)
Mr Campbell asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 21 October 1981:
(1) Has Telecom Australia recently introduced a new telephone instrument called Gondola to Western Australia.
(2) Does this telephone instrument provide a facility whereby the telephone can remember numbers and re-dial them.
(3) Is it a fact that Gondola will not be available in the Perth metropolitan area until November 1981.
(4) Is there a further 6-months delay for non-metropolitan subscribers who wish to obtain this particular telephone; if so why.
(5) If a delay for non-metropolitan subscribers exists, does it constitute discrimination against country residents.
Mr Sinclair-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes.
(2) The Gondola has a facility known at last number redial which permits the last number dialled to be recalled at the push of a button. It does not have the facility to store and recall other numbers.
(3) The Gondola telephone was introduced in Perth and Sydney on a trial basis on I September 1981.
(4) and (5) Subject to satisfactory market trials and adequate stock levels, it is intended to launch the Gondola on an Australia-wide basis in March 1982.
Imperial Honours to Members of Parliament
(Question No. 3463)
Mr Scholes asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:
How many persons granted Imperial Honours upon his recommendations as set out in his answer to question No.' 3186 in each of the orders of Imperial awards, KCMG., K.B.E., Knight Bachelor, C.B., C.M.G., CBE., OBE., I.S.0., M.B.E., and B.E.M., were, at the time of recommendation;
(a) a member of parliament.
(b) a former member of parliament.

(c) an official of a political party (including a member of a State or National Councilor Executive member of a political party) or
(d) formerly held any of the positions set out in part (c).
Mr Malcolm Fraser-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
Recommendations and grants of honours and awards are made on the basis of contributions by members of the Australian community. Often an individual will have given invaluable service in a number o( capacities. Citations concerned with individual grants are given wide publicity. It would be inappropriate and I would not be willing to agree to the unnecessary work required to prepare what are additional artificial statistical tables sought by the honourable member.
Overseas Travel by the Minister for Education or Ministeral Staff
(Question No. 3480)
Mr Morris asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:
(1) On what occasions has the Minister or members of the Minister's staff travelled abroad since I January 1981 to the date of preparation of the answer to this question?
(2) What places and organisations were visited during the travel abroad and on what dates did the Minister depart from Australia and arrive and depart at each of the places visited during travel abroad, and on what date did the Minister and associated staff return to Australia?
(3) What were the names and classifications of persons associated with the Minister's travel abroad referred to in parts (I) and (2)?
(4) What sum was spent for each individual in respect of each visit abroad for (a) travel; (b) accommodation; (c) other associated and incidental expenditure and (d) total expenditure?
Mr FifeThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) On no occasions.
(2) Not applicable~there was no travel.
(3) Not applicable.
(4) Nil.
Missing Aircraft: Searches
(Question No. 3511)
Mr Morris asked the Minister for Transport, up on notice, on 29 October 1981:
(I) How many searches for missing aircraft have beem conducted by his Department in each of the years 1976-77 to 1980-81 and during the period I July 1981 to the date of preparation of the answer to this question.
(2) What were the dates and circumstances associated with the disappearance of the aircraft in each case and in which cases were the searches unsuccessful.
(3) What was the duration of the search for each missing aircraft before the (a) aircraft was located and (b) search was abandoned.
(4) In each of the successful searches what casualties were involved and is he able to say in what cases the delay before the aircraft was located had a bearing upon the condition of the survivors or those who may have survived if the aircraft had been located earlier.

Answers to Questions

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3189

(5) What changes have occurred in the method ofconducting searches for missing aircraft since I July 1976 and in the equipment utilised in search procedures.
Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) The information requested from 1976-77 to 1980-81 is not readily available and I am not prepared to authorise the use of scarce resources to answer all of this question. From I July 1981 there have been seven searches for missing aircraft, three of which were major searches.
(2) (a) 17.7.81-search for VH-DSA Cessna 177, Tangalooma Qld. Aircraft operating in training area. Reported by ground observer to have disappeared behind hill. No contact with aircraft. Air search conducted. Aircraft located Tangalooma Airstrip.
(b) 2.8.81-search for YH-ICC Piper PA32, Mornington Island Qld. Aircraft enroute Urapunga to Normanton. Failed to arrive at destination and nil contact. Search instigated. Aircraft located at Mornington Island.
(c) 9.8.8 I-major search for YH-MDX Cessna 210, Barrington Tops NSW. Aircraft enroute Coolangatta to Bankstown. At a position 50 N-M north of Singleton following a pilot report of instrument failure/icing and turbulence, all contact was lost. Search unsuccessful.
(d) 29.8.81-major search for YH-PON Piper PA 32, Finke N.T. Aircraft enroute from Leigh Creek to Alice Springs. Advised was unsure of position. Communications lost. Wreckage found.
(e) 22.9.81-search for YH-MYG Beech 24R. Aircraft inbound to Roma Qld. Failed to arrive. YSB signal heard. Found at first light.
(f) 22.10.81-major search for YH-CGL Piper PA 32R. Aircraft enroute from Canberra to Moorabbin. Last reported in Eildon Weir area. Search unsuccessful.
(g) II.I 1.8 I-search for YH-BYY Cessna 185. Aircraft force landed west of Pine Dam Qld due to engine problems. Aircraft diverted to area to search. Wreckage found.
(3) The duration of the searches was:
(a) 60 minutes-located (b) 58 minutes-located (c) 9 days-not located (d) I day II hours-located (e) 9 hours 38 minutes-located (f) 9 days-not located (g) 64 minutes-located
(4) Successful searches were:
(a) I person on board-nil injuries (b) 4 persons on board-nil injuries (d) 4 persons on board-4 fatal (e) 4 persons on board-4 fatal (g) 3 persons on board-3 injured
In cases (d) and (e) fatalities were instantaneous.
In case (g) search time had no bearing on survivors condition.
(5) There has been no fundamental changes in search methods since I July 1976.
Since I July 1976 there has been an increase in the use of direction finding equipment and airborne search meters. Additionally, increasing use is being made of photos reconnaissance and satellite derived information.

Bureau of Transport Economics

(Question No. 3513)

Mr Morris asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

(I) In relation to the operations of the Bureau of Transport Econo!11ics, what is the establishment of the Bureau and how many positions remained unfilled at the date of preparation of
the answer to this question.

(2) What specific vacant positions within the Bureau are proposed not to be filled during 1981-82.

(3) What are the principal reviews or studies to be under-,

taken by the Bureau in 1981-82 and what duties, studies and

reviews previously performed by the Bureau are not proposed

for continuance arising from the report of the Review of Com-

monwealth Functions.

.

Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(I) The Bureau of Transport Economics (BTE) has an establishment of 135 positions. At present, 35 positions are unfilled.

(2) A review of the Bureau's establishment requirements
for 1981-82 is in course. At this stage seven vacant positions
have been identified for withdrawal from establishment. They are one of Clerk Class II, three of Principal research Officer and three of Research Officer Grade I. Other positions are
under review or are to be reviewed as they become vacant, with the object of setting an appropriate relationship between
the establishment and the staff ceiling.

(3) Some of the principal reviews or studies to be undertaken by the Bureau in 1981-82 are:

Air Transport Demand Forecasting System

Department of Transport: Computer System
(Question No. 35]8)
Mr Morris asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:
(I) In relation to Division 655, Sub-Division2, Item 15, Computer Services, of the estimates of expenditure for his Department for 1981-82 explanatory notes, what specific information is he able to provide on progress made on the accommodation of the pilot supply ADP system.
(2) Can he provide additional information to that shown'in the explanatory notes of his Department on page 47 on that nature of the ADP pilot supply system.
Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows.
(I) & (2) The system is concerned with the application of ADP techniques to the ledger keeping activity in Regional warehouses and to the Department's overall inventory control activity. The Department proposes to minimise the in-house design and development work associated with the ADP supply system by utilising one of the commercially available 'packaged' systems. A detailed functional description of the pilot system has been prepared.
Age Pensions: Income Test
(Question No. 357])
Mr Young asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:
(I) What proportion of the 1,377,000 recipients of age pensions were not subject to an income test as at 30 June 1981.
(2) Of the pensions not subject to an income test, what proportion were paid at the (a) standard rate of $51.45 and (b) married rate of $42.90.
(3) What proportion of the pensions subject to an income test were paid according to the (a) standard rate, (b) married rate and (c) wife's rate.
(4) Of the payments to pensioners subject to an income test what proportions received pensions ranging between (a) $0.01 and $6.66, (b) $6.67 and $13.33, (c) $13.34 and $19.99, (d) $20.00 and $26.66, (e) $26.67 and $33.32, (I) $33.33 and $39.99, (g) $40.00 and $46.65, (h) $46.66 and $53.32, (i) $53.33 and $59.98, and (j) $59.99 and $66.65.
Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

(I) Of the 1,377,000 age (and wife) pensioners at 30 June 1981, 61.5 per cent were age pensioners aged 70 years or more and were therefore in receipt of the income test-free component of the basic pension.
(2) Of the age pensioners aged 70 years or more 16.2 per cent were paid the standard rate of $51.45 and 8.2 per cent were paid the married rate of$42.90 at 30 June 1981.
(3) Of age and wife's pensions paid to persons aged less than 70 years at 30 June 1981, the proportions paid at the following rates were:
(a) standard rate-43.8 per cent (b) married rate-50.7 per cent (c) wives' pensions-5.5 per cent.
(4) Of age and wife's pensions paid to persons aged less than 70 years at 30 June 1981, the proportions receiving basic weekly pensions in the following ranges were estimated to be:
(a) $0.01 to $6.66-0.3 per cent (b) $6.67 to $13.33-0.8 per cent (c) $13.34to$19.99-1.5percent (d) $20.00 to $26.66-2.0 per cent (e) $26.67 to $33.32-2.5 per cent (I) $33.33 to $39.99-3.1 per cent (g) $40.00 to $46.65-2.7 per cent (h) $46.66 to $53.32-7.6 per cent (i) $53.33 to $59.98-44.5 per cent
U) $59.99 to $66.65-35.0 per cent
Deportations
(Question No. 3583)
Mr Young asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:
(I) How many persons were deported in each year since 1974.
(2) What was the country of birth of the persons deported in each year and what was the crime of each deportee.
(3) Which countries accepted the persons deported from Australia each year.
(4) Is there a 129 per cent increase in expenditure over that of 1980-81 on deportation proposed for 1981-82.
(5) Is the sum allocated for deportations in 1981-82 $700,000 more than the sum allocated for 1979-80 which was a year in which there were no amnesties or regularisation of status programs.
(6) On what basis is it estimated there will be 800 deportations in 1981-82.
(7) What are the fees charged to deportees in detention centres and prisons and what sums were raised from deportees since the introduction ofthose fees.
(8) Is he able to state what countries punish a person twice for the same crime.
Mr Macphee-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) 1974-497(a); 1975-642; 1976-481(b); 1977-861; 1978-964; 1979-1015; 1980-383(c).
The figures above reRect:
(a) Dispensation extended to Prohibited Immigrants.
(b) Amnesty for Prohibited Immigrants.
(c) Regularisation of Status Program.
(2) Statistics are not kept on the country of birth of deportees nor of type of crime committed by them, if any, for

Answers to Questions

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3191

which they were deported. However, I have provided separately to the honourable member statistics relating to the citizenship of each deportee and the relevant provisions of the Migration Act 1958 under which the persons were deported.
(3) Statistics are not kept on which countries accept deportees from Australia. However persons are deported in most cases to the country of their citizenship.
(4) Yes. Expenditure on deportations in 1980-81 was $738,179 in the appropriation of $750,000. The low level of expenditure was due to the Government's Regularisation of Status Program for prohibited immigrants from 19 June 1980 to 31 December 1980.
(5) No. The appropriation for deportations in 1979-80 was $1,270,000 (expenditure $1,077,167), compared to an appropriation of $1,691,000 for 1981-82 an increase of $421,000 over the 1979-80 appropriation.
(6) The estimate of 800 deportations in 1980-81 is based on the resumption of normal activities following the cessation of the Regularisation of Status Program on 31 December 1980. It represents a modest increase of 48 over the deportation level (752) in 1979-80 a year in which there were no amnesties or regularisation of status programs.
