Major Roads Assessment Study
(Question No. 3585)
Mr Morris asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:
(I) What were the specific reasons for the deferment of the proposed Major Roads Assessment Study for which proposed expenditure was underspent by the Bureau of Transport Economics in 1980-81.
(2) What progress has been made in the conduct of the Roads Assessment Study.
(3) What organisations, firms and individuals are to be consulted during the study and will public hearings be conducted.
(4) When is the study expected to be completed and will he undertake to provide copies of the report of the study to the Parliament as soon as they become available.
Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Two elements of the Bureau of Transport Economics (BTE) Roads Study were deferred, and this led to underspending relative to proposed expenditure by the Bureau in 1980-81. The elements deferred were:

(a) A proposed program of meetings with selected local government authorities throughout Australia was deferred owing to the slow response by local government to an initial formal survey by the BTE. I am advised that some of these visits have since taken place. They are part of the Bureau's efforts to ensure that local government views are properly reflected in its roads studies.
(b) The Director of the Bureau determined that parts of the study would be based on current data on road condition and use being collected and verified by the various State Road Authorities. These data were not available in 1980-81, and hence relevant aspects of the study were deferred pending data availability.
(2) The Bureau of Transport Economics is presently engaged on a number of studies related to its general responsibility for providing advice to me on roads issues. The Director of the Bureau advises me that progress has been made in developing a wider analytical base than that which had been used in the past for studies of this nature. Study procedures using this analytical base have been set up, but further technical investigations are required and additional data will be needed before the full analysis can be carried out and reported.
(3) I am advised that the Bureau is at present consulting a wide range of organisations, including industry, State road authorities, local government, chambers of commerce, residents, associations and community groups. However, the Bureau has no plans to conduct formal public hearings.
(4) The Bureau regards its program of roads studies as a continuing series of investigations. The present series of studies will be reported progressively, with the first reports expected to be available in mid-1982. The present outline program of studies extends to about 1984. As relevant reports are produced, I will give consideration to their release in the usual-way.
Walter Ultra-large Fire Tenders
(Question No. 3586)
Mr Morris asked the Minister for Transport, upon Notice, on 29 October 1981:
(I) What were the dates of receipt by his Department of each of the 9,100 litre Walter Ultra-Large Fire Tenders.
(2) Which of those tenders has been placed on fire line duty.
(3) Which of the 9,100.litre Walter Ultra-Large Fire Tenders has not been brought into use yet, what are the reasons for the delay in bringing each into use and when isit expected that each of them will be available for fire line duty.
(4) What costs in relation to (a) overall running costs and (b) labour have been incurred in respect of each unit following its delivery to his Department.
Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Only two have been received-both on 9 June 1981.
(2) None.
(3) Both; due to a ban by the Federal Firefighters Union over manning principles.
(4) The answers to this part of the question are not readily available and I am not prepared to authorise the use of scarce resources to obtain the information sought.

3192 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Answers to Questions

Education: Capital Grants to Government Schools
(Question No. 3601)
Dr Theophanous asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:
(I) What were the Government's reasons for rejecting the recommendation of the Commonwealth Schools Commission made in June 1981 that the level of Commonwealth capital grants for government schools be determined and maintained on a triennial basis.
(2) What were the Government's reasons for rejecting the Commission's proposal relating to changes in the basis of funding for recurrent grants to government schools.
(3) Will the Government reconsider its decision on these mailers; if not, will he qualify the extent of his control over planning decisions which powers would appear to be invested in the Commonwealth Schools Commission.
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) In its report for the 1982-84 triennium the Commonwealth Schools Commission recommend that the levels of both Commonwealth and State capital programs be determined and maintained on a triennial basis. The Government has decided that it would be appropriate to retain the Hexibility of determining the level of capital grants on an annual basis in the overall budgetary framework. Unlike the grants for universities and colleges of advanced education the government schools capital program is a shared program. In 1979-80 (the latest available figures for State Governments expenditure) the Commonwealth contributed about 30 per cent of the total expenditure in the States on capital programs for government schools. The States likewise determine their capital spending on an annual basis.
(2) Again in the interests of budgetary Hexibility it was decided not to adopt a funding mechanism which tied Commonwealth recurrent grants for government schools to a per capita formula. There is no requirement on the States to either accept the resource standards proposed by the Commission or to determine resource provision on the basis of a fixed standard. Against this background and given that the Commonwealth contributes only about 9 per cent of funds for recurrent costs of government schools the Commonwealth determines its allocations on an annual basis.
(3) The decisions made by the Government on Commonwealth programs for schools in 1982 will stand. The Commonwealth Schools Commission is the Government's chief advisory body on the needs of schools and on policy development relating to those needs. In the final analysis, however, it is the Government which makes decisions on funding policy for Commonwealth programs.
Teacher Shortage
(Question No. 3602)
Dr Theophanous asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:
(I) Has his attention been drawn to the survey by the Council of Academic Staff Associations which suggests that the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission has over-estimated the supply of new graduates available for teaching by approximately 12 per cent for 1982 and that combined with under-estimates of the demand for teachers due to errors in estimated total loss rates, birth rates and migration levels, this over-estimate of total supply by the Commission will serve to create a substantital teacher shortage in several years time.

(2) What steps does he intend to take to rectify this serious prospect of teacher shortages.
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) and (2) My attention has been drawn to Bulletin No. 15/81 published by the Council of Academic Staff Associations of Victorian Colleges of Advanced Education. The conclusions expressed, do, however, appear to be based on doubtful assumptions, for example that teacher resignation rates would increase more than have been allowed for. Even if these assumptions proved correct-and on balance this seemed unlikely-the approach adopted by both the Commonwealth and the States left room for short term adjustments to the numbers of teachers being trained. This could be done by adjusting intakes to one year diploma of education courses. It should also be noted that new graduates were not the only source of teacher recruitment-there were numbers of teachers available with previous experience who wished to reenter the teaching profession.
Recent decisions taken by the Commonwealth Government to consolidate colleges of advanced education should help to create more Hexible institutions that could respond more readily to changes in demand for various types of courses. Any necessary adjustments to intakes to particular courses can be made within the overall level of resources available in each State over the 1982-84 triennium.
Child Care Services for Migrants Learning English
(Question No. 3636)
Mr Young asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 17 November 1981 :
In line with Commonwealth Government policies to make services accessible to potential users will the Government accept its responsibilities for funding child care services in conjunction with English classes so that all migrant parents have access to English language learning.
Mr Macphee-The following answer is provided to the honourable member's question:
The Adult Migrant Education Program provides a choice of English language learning opportunities that allows parents to select arrangements to minimise any problems associated with the care of young children.
The Commonwealth funds quite extensive child care arrangements in association with the Adult Migrant Education Program. In 1980-81 $424,000 was expended from AMEP funds on child care services. In addition, funds totalling some $26,600 in 1980-81 were provided through the Children's Services Program, admininstered by the Department of Social Security, for child care services associated with English classes.
The most extensive child care arrangements are provided at migrant residential centres. Some community migrant education centres have sufficient and suitable accommodation for the provision of child care. A number of community day classes in NSW and Victoria, which are largely attended by women, are supported by volunteer arrangements.
People attending courses can, of course, also make use of general community child care services.
The provision of child care arrangements under the AMEP is currently being examined by my Department.

Answers to Questions

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3193

Funding for Handicapped Persons' Welfare
(Question No. 3646)
Mr Milton asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon -notice, on 17 November, 1981:
(I) Is it a fact that the 198 I-82 Budget allocation for Handicapped Persons' Welfare represents a massive reduction in the total funds for these services.
(2) Is it also a fact that inflation will absorb the Budget increase of $1 00,000 for the salaries component by 7 times.
(3) Will this reduction in real terms mean a cut-back in anticipated new staff appointments for Handicapped Persons' Centres.
(4) Will present staff .levels at Handicapped Persons' Centres need to be cut back as a result of this Budget allocation.
(5) Will the Minister undertake to review this allocation and provide a more positive financial undertaking, especially in this International Year of the Disabled Persons.
Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
( I ) No. The total 1981-82 Budget appropriation of $57.333m for the funding of eligible organisations for the provision of prescribed services under the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act represents an increase of $4.433m over last year's expenditure for these purposes of $52.9m.
(2) No. The overall provision in (I) includes an allocation of $38.323m for salaries of approved officers for both new and existing services, compared with an actual expenditure in 1980-81 of $34.03m-an increase of $4.3m or 12.6 per cent.
(3) See (2). Funds provided for salaries in respect of existing services will permit staffing at last year's levels, plus some allowance for subsidising new approved officers. In addition, $1.32m has been allocated for salaries for approved officers in new services-an increase of $0.9m over last year. Only approved officers, employed in connection with the provision of approved prescribed services, may be subsidised. Organisations should not anticipate subsidy without such approvals having been given.
(4) No, in case of approved staff.
(5) See (I) to (4).
Vacation Care Programs: Funding
(Question No. 3658)
Dr Klugman asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:
(I) Has the Minister received representations regarding the reduction of funding for vacation care centres.
(2) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the particular difficulties caused in the City of Fairfield, New South Wales, leading to a 100 per cent increase in fees and the inability to pay staff all their entitlements.
Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(I) and (2) I have received representations expressing concern that the funds provided by the Commonwealth in 1981-82 towards vacation care programs remained at the previous year's level. I have replied to such representations, including those in respect of services in the Fairfield (New

South Wales) area, advising that the Commonwealth provides funds to all State Governments in the form of an annual block grant as a contribution towards the costs of providing vacation care services. Each State Government is responsible for determining priorities and for the allocation of the Commonwealth and State funds available for this purpose to individual projects, based on the State's assessment of competing areas of need.
Social Welfare Policy Secretaria t's Report on Poverty Measurement
(Question No. 3716)
Mrs Darling asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:
(I) Did the report from the inquiry by the Social Welfare Policy Secretariat dealing with poverty find that on 1978-79 statistics, more than one million people live below the Henderson poverty line, and that in addition, 130,000 single persons under 21 years and independent of their families were estimated to be below the poverty line.
(2) Is it also a fact that an estimate of the Secretariat, which was not included in the report, also put between 100,000 and 200,000 self-employed persons below the Henderson line; if so, why was this estimate not included in the report.
(3) Is it a fact that the report found that the proportion of the Australian population living below the Henderson poverty line had not fallen, but was substantially higher.
(4) Did the report cast doubts about the viability of the Henderson poverty line.
(5) Have the Minister and the Minister's predecessor stated repeatedly over the last two years that the Government had commissioned the report in order to determine a new basis for assessment of poverty.
(6) Has the report established an assessment formula; if not, why not.
(7) In the absence of a measurement of this kind will Australia be deemed as having no officially poor or impoverished citizens.
(8) Without establishing a means of assessment of the number of Australia's poor how will the Department of Social Security be able to effectively assess the social security needs of the poor and eradicate poverty in Australia.
Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(I) The Social Welfare Policy Secretariat's Report on Pov-. erty Measurement included an estimate that, excluding the self-employed, some 9.3 per cent of adult income units comprising over a million people had incomes below the Henderson poverty line in 1978-79. The exclusions of juveniles (unmarried persons aged under 21 who were not responsible for a dependent child) and the self-employed were made to achieve consistency with the Poverty Inquiry figures and because for these groups annual income (as collected in the ABS Survey) may be a most inaccurate measure of their economic well-being. However, the SWPS report suggests that a further 130,000 juveniles may have had incomes in 1978-79 which were below the Henderson poverty line.
(2) No.
(3) The SWPS report concluded that 9.5 per cent of people (9.3 per cent of families) had incomes below the Henderson poverty line in 1978-79, compared with the Poverty Inquiry's estimate for 1972-73 of 8.2 per cent of people (10.2 per cent of

3194 REPRESENTATIVES 18 November 1981

Answers to Questions

families). The SWPS estimates may be more closely comparable with those in an International Labour Organisation publication by Professor Wilfred Beckerman of Oxford University. These estimates indicated that in 1973-74 about 10 per cent of people (about II per cent of families) were in poverty as measured by the Henderson line. Thus it cannot be concluded that the proportion of the Australian population living below the Henderson poverty line was 'substantially higher'in 1978-79 than it had been in the early 1970's.
(4) The SWPS report concluded that the Henderson poverty lines could not be considered as an objective or unambiguous measure of poverty in Australia. The Henderson lines were not based on a study of needs in Australia. The lines were based on an arbitrarily chosen 'poverty line' (a rounded total of the Melbourne basic wage in 1966 plus child endowment) for a standard family of a working husband, a nonworking wife and two children. The equivalence scales used to derive poverty lines for other than standard families were based on relativities between expenditures of different families in New York in 1954. They are at best of doubtful relevance to A~stralia in the 1980's. The SWPS report includes indicative equivalence scales which show important differences from the scales incorporated in the Henderson poverty line.
(5) Senator Guilfoyle stated in the Senate on 28 February 1980 that she had recently asked the Social Welfare Policy Secretariat, in consultation with her own Department, to examine the whole issue of alernative approaches to measure a poverty line that would be relevant to Australia in the 1980's.
(6) The report has not established a new poverty line although, as suggested above, a number of equivalence scales which may have indicative usefulness have been calculated. The Secretariat concluded that there was no objective method of establishing which level of income was adequate or appropriate: that was a matter of personal or political judgment.
(7) and (8) The Government will have a number of sources of information for deciding where such additional funds as become available for social security purposes may best be spent. The SWPS report contains a good deal of information about the groups in the community with the lowest relative incomes. The Government will naturally pay attention to the views expressed by consultative committees, welfare organisations and individuals.

Poverty Guideline
(Question No. 3717)
Mrs Darling asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

(I) Did the Minister's predecessor state on 25 October
1979, that her main objective would be to see what, in then terms and conditions, ought to be the poverty line by which
families in need in Australia could be judged and that she would certainly welcome any.work that could be done to de-
vise a poverty line suited to Australian conditions in the late 1970's.

(2) As it is 2 years since that statement was made, does the Government now have a line by which families can be judged
in need; if not, when does the Minister expect a guide will be established.

Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has

provided the following answer to the honourable

member's question:

.

(I) Yes.

(2) In its recently released Report on Poverty Measurement the Social Welfare Policy Secretariat concluded that there was no objective method of deciding whether a particular amount of income was adequate or appropriate. It did, however, include information on the characteristics of individuals and families with low relative incomes.
Retrenchment Compensation
(Question No. 3721)
Mr Humphreys asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:
(I) Is it a fact that the Committee of Inquiry into Technological Change in Australia (the Myers Report) recommended a 2-part retrenchment compensation scheme that would include temporary income-maintenance to be funded by the Government.
(2) Following the tabling of the Report in Parliament, did he undertake to engage in consultations with employers and the trade union movement concerning improved redundancy arrangements; if so, what has been the outcome of these consultations.
Mr Viner-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes.
(2) The Prime Minister tabled the Committee's Report in the House on 19 August 1980. The Minister for Industry and Commerce provided details of the Government response to the Report in a Ministerial Statement to the House on 18 September 1980. In response to the Committee's recommendation (No. 14) on retrenchment compensation, the Minister stated inter alia that before final decisions were taken the Government would seek full consultation with employers and the union movement.
The relevant recommendations of the Committee were referred to the National Labour Consultative Council (NLCC) for consideration. In the meantime, metal industry unionssupported by the Australian Council of Trade Unionslodged job security claims with the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and further NLCC consideration have been deferred pending the outcome of those claims.

(3) Will he, in the light of these statements, reassess the need for tertiary grant supplementation.

'Includes Lord Howe Island.

Lost Investment
Mr Moore-On 10 September 1981 (Hansard, page 1156) Mr Hayden asked the Acting Prime Minister the following question without notice:
I ask the Acting Prime Minister whether he has seen reports on the case Daly v. Sydney Stock Exchange, in which a claim involving the failed stockbrokers Patrick Partners was discllssed. Is he aware that Mr Justice Powell said he reached his decision with 'considerable regret' because the plaintiffs lost considerable amounts of money by investing in Patrick Partners 'in circumstances which cast not the slightest credit upon the integrity and commercial morality of the former members of the firm'. Is he aware that MrJustice Powell suggested that Parliament might, therefore, look again at the Securities Industry Act to see 'whether some greater or other form of protection is now called for'? Will the Government pursue Mr Justice Powell's recommendation and not be deflected by any pressure which might become immediately apparent to discourage it from doing so?
As the responsible Minister, I have been asked to answer the honourable member's question to the Acting Prime Minister. The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
I am aware of the case of Daly v. Sydney Stock Exchange (no. 1740 of 1978) and the judgment of Mr Justice Powell on 9 September 1981.

This case concerned an application for compensation out of the fidelity fund of the Sydney Stock Exchange under s. 58 of the New South Wales Securities Industry Act 1970. This Act was subsequently replaced by the Securities Industry Act 1975 which, in turn, has been replaced by the Securities Industry (New South Wales) Code under the co-operative companies and securities scheme. While the provision of the securities industry code (s. III) that corresponds to s. 58 of the New South Wales Securities Industry Act 1970 has not been changed in any way that would appear to be material for the purpose of the judgment given by Mr Justice Powell, there have been other changes since 1970 that are relevant to this matter. For example, the securities industry code (s. 67) contains a new provision which requires a dealer in securities to deposit moneys lent by a client in a separate bank account within one business day of their receipt and to retain the moneys in the account until the client indicates how the moneys are to be used. Failure to use the moneys in a manner agreed to by the client is an offence.
Section 67 of the present securities industry code was one of a number of amendments to the ICAC securities industry legislation that was agreed to by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities following its consideration of the recommendations contained in the report dated 21 December 1976 by Mr G. G. Masterman under the New South Wales Securities Industry Act.
The Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities keeps all aspects of the co-operative scheee legislataon under continual review an the light of developments. It is expected that the first series of substantive amendments to this legislation will be included in the proposed Companies and Securities legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1983. Current planning within the Ministerial Council is that a draft of this BiIl will be exposed for public comment for about three months during the second half of 1982.
I would expect that among the matters that may be considered by the Ministerial Council when deciding what amendments should be included in the exposure draft of the 1983 Bill would be the comments made by Mr Justice Powell in Daly v. Sydney Stock Exchange and any relevant recommendations in the Masterman report referred to above.
Migrant Home Tutor Service
(Question No, 3649)
Mr Les McLeay asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:
(I) What sum has been spent on the Migrant Home Tutor Service in each year since 1978-79 and what sum is proposed for 1981-82.
(2) How many (a) tutors and (b) migrants are.involved in the Scheme (i) in total and (ii) by language group.
(3) How many persons referred to in parts (2) (a) and (2) (b) are enrolled in the Ele.ctoral Division of Grayndler.
Mr Macphee-The following answer is provided to the honourable member's question:
(I) Expenditure on the Home Tutor Service, which is a component of the Adult Migrant Education Program, for the years 1978-79 to 1980-81 is as follows:
Australia
1978-79 $223,804 1979-80 $287,914 1980-81 $327,499
The estimated expenditure for 1981-82 is $420,000, including provision for the scheme co-ordinators who are now employed by the State Adult Migrant Education Services in

Answers to Questions

18 November 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3197

South Australia and Queensland rather than by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs as previously.
(2) (a) (i) 4943 tutors (b) (i) 6560 family units enrolled at present, involving at least one member of the family (if more than one member is involved he/she is not counted separately).

The total number of migrants who benefitted from the scheme in the full year 1980/81 is estimated at over 13,000.
(ii) This information is not collected.
(3) (a) Tutors-l06 (b) Family units-l06
